These are the types of the enzymes which fall in the category of absolute specificity .	4.298063997294063

Then we have a number of enzymes which show stereo chemical specificity .	6.852898531461946

That means they recognize the arrangement of atoms at a carbon atom at which stereo isomerism can occur .	3.8852650836181746

There are large varieties of enzymes .	7.364407309277774

If you consider the example of let us say lipase .	6.899622893688712

Lipase from various sources can exhibit specificity , only one of the isomer either l or d isomer .	5.354596676562175

There are a large number of such examples in the chemical literature or the bio chemical literature .	4.828981098807949

The only enzyme which is known to act on both the stereoisomers or the enzymes whose function is to interconvert L and D isomers are usually called as racemases .	3.9110439550758453

For example L - alanine to D - alanine .	6.054511983744462

This is the only one classical example where an enzyme can act on both stereoisomers .	4.968004122058802

Otherwise most of the enzyme will exhibit stereochemical specificity and if there is an asymmetric carbon atom it will only accept one of the isomers and not the other .	5.3637909918000135

The stereochemical specificity can extend to the level that enzyme acting on a non assymetric molecule can produce one of the isomers as a product .	4.540464314603011

The typical example is glycerol kinase .	5.7571505589446055

Glycerol as we know is CH2OH - CHOH - CH2OH .	8.852485427472999

It is a non - assymetric product .	7.931051014546824

The carbon atom in both the ñCH2OH are identical .	7.085874798387994

But the enzyme acts on glycerol molecule and produces L - glycerol - 3 - phosphate .	4.228726867299223

That means the enzyme transfers again the action of ATP to ADP .	4.156534207405069

The enzyme transfers phosporyl group to the third carbon atom of the glycerol molecule .	4.465518640039907

Although the one and three are identical still it is able to exhibit the stereochemical specificity in terms of product formation .	4.882153331425994

What we must appreciate is that the variety of specificity that can occur in the case of enzymatic reaction can be very loosely specific in terms of group specific enzymes , absolute specificity with respect to a single substrate ; it can be stereochemically specific with respect to substrate or with respect to product .	5.311134742768682

Therefore in summary the enzyme will exhibit specificity both with respect to substrate as well as with respect to product .	5.395573933973649

As I explained earlier the glycerol molecule is a symmetric molecule .	5.341662788757193

There is no asymmetry in this .	6.525123632193672

But the enzyme glycerol kinase acts only on the third carbon .	4.5464566834704

You can analyze the product and see where the phosporyl group has gone .	5.263235314318929

Consider the structural conformation of glycerol .	7.541621601221148

This is one , two and three and this acts only on the third one which is on the left hand side .	4.526518822020476

We are expressing here our conformation on a planar diagram .	5.019895091689776

When you look at a three dimensional space , in a three dimensional space the one and three will not be in the same plane .	5.342923752568107

The specificity can have a very large variety and one must also appreciate that the specificity of these enzymes in terms of their catalytic action is attributed to the active sites .	5.238412200035255

As we also saw in the last lecture where the catalytic function was studied , the catalytic functions of the enzymes are responsible for the role played by active site .	4.9277977589845205

The specificity also is the result of the conformation of active site .	5.743045413716774

The active sites must be considered as consisting of two different parts : the binding sites and the functional sites .	5.357987482408112

Another factor of stereospecificity is that prediction of stereospecificity by any ground rule is difficult .	4.042889800824928

We are able to know the specificity only while we determine the amount of product formed on a particular substrate .	6.216578807777453

In the case of a chemical reaction to take place you have ?	5.273859412886474

G value , the free energy change of the reaction , which will give you an idea whether the reaction will take place in the forward direction or reverse direction or there will be an equilibrium established .	5.5276904629060475

But in the case of specificity of enzyme action the only way to understand the specificity is that we monitor the product formed on the substrate and then we can say yes this is specific to the substrates .	5.470152195294095

Once we find the specificity then we can propose hypothesis or mechanisms by which the stereo specificity can be explained .	5.88403482359112

But there are no other thermodynamic or kinetic interpretations which can be applied to the specificity .	5.212792612910906

That is another feature .	7.9208963998212525

One of the most interesting features of enzyme specificity is their stereochemical specificity because when there is a single molecule the functional groups are different , active sites also may have different functional groups to bind them and the steps can be understood .	4.3441252355632

But to understand the stereochemical specificity that how enzyme is able to identify the two different stereoisomers , the minimum requirements on the function of an active sites was proposed by Oxten as early as 1948 .	4.284789471137871

He proposed that at least there must be three sites of different points of interaction on an enzyme active site .	4.485643027936117

Here the bottom one is the whole enzyme molecule and the dotted line represents the active sites .	5.323592603004044

I must again remind you that this is not a planar site .	6.261454553143114

It is a three dimensional structure on the surface of the enzyme molecule and not that all the amino acids on these active sites are located in proximity in the amino acid chain .	5.254827833632499

They are brought in proximity by folding of the enzyme protein .	4.834546082764572

At least it is understood that as proposed by Oxten that the enzyme active site also must have at least three different functional residues on the active site which can interact with the substrate molecule .	4.228130187808657

These three interacting sites let us consider that they are the interaction sites .	6.5476023267439025

Minimum two of them must be binding sites , out of the three at least two on which the substrate molecule can bind to the active site and put the substrate in a very fixed orientation .	6.520673818280604

We have two points .	11.788297097739898

We are holding the enzyme molecule bound to the substrate .	7.284598693682205

This binding has to be oriented in such a way that the third functional group on the substrate which has to undergo reaction is brought in vicinity of the catalytic site .	4.548942537095156

That is one minimum requirement for explaining the specificity of enzyme action that there must be minimum three sites which interact between the enzyme and substrate .	3.770092158998599

Two of them must be at least binding sites and the substrate binds on these two sites to the enzyme molecule whereby it orients the substrate molecule along with the enzyme such that the reactive functional group and the reactive site on enzymes active site come in proximity or in vicinity .	4.912700113814394

Of course the various mechanisms that we discussed it could be a strain on the bond , it could be the entropic factors and it could be various covalent interactions or electro static interactions that might play a role to carry out the catalysis .	4.880189701556832

But as far as the binding is concerned , it has to be specific in terms of bringing the functional group on which the reaction has to take place .	6.3971938118611895

I will try to explain the same points with a particular example of oxidation of a D - amino acid , using D - amino acid oxidase where you have this amino group which undergoes reaction .	4.76955725956898

In the molecule the carboxylic group and the methyl group are bound onto the enzyme active site .	5.2989352779443735

The one which binds methyl group will be hydrophobic in nature and this will be bound predominantly by electrostatic interactions .	5.0649520297121455

These two binding brings the catalytic sites in close vicinity of the amino group which is available for reaction and the catalytic reaction can take place .	5.680666347770689

This is your D - amino acid .	6.199458044503338

You consider corresponding L - amino acid on which the location of H and amino group will be different .	5.372930972728963

Even if the binding takes place this amino group cannot come in the vicinity of the catalytic site , cannot approach the catalytic site and no reaction can occur .	4.091275330950274

That is why the concept of three interacting sites fairly explains the position of enzymes catalytic action as far as their specificity with respect to stereo isomers is concerned .	3.8590928920842944

The situation in the case of different substrates which can have different functional groups can be much simpler .	5.743810813345506

Because the binding site will bind two of the functional group , the third functional group which has to undergo reaction will be only recognized by the catalytic site and no other functional group will be recognized and so reaction cannot take place .	4.5366115561043

One of the very early understanding that as early as 1890 , Oxten proposed such a mechanism which puts a limit just like in the case of rate of a reaction we have a thermo dynamic limit .	4.740744113879928

If there is a reversible reaction , these are the kind of limits like equilibrium constant will be achieved at this point and so on .	5.412647428729254

Similarly Oxten proposed a limit that minimum there must be three points of interaction .	4.919560153080192

In case of very hard core specific enzymes the point of interaction can be more than three also .	5.270679099545243

Instead to two binding sites there can be three binding sites also .	6.144397488407455

That depends on the requirement for the enzyme .	12.78000914766946

As early as in 1890 , Fischer proposed Lock and key hypothesis which explained the enzyme specificity .	4.48326658047796

This explanation of the specificity was purely based on certain observations and analysis of the situation mostly mental and not analytical because not many analytical facilities were available .	4.093676312919242

It was suggested that the enzyme active site and the substrate have a conformation which is analogous to lock and the key .	5.152006235382915

That means the Ö. .. on the key are exactly fitting to the site at which it has to interact with the lock .	4.983707698253804

They are exactly fitting .	9.58322688354127

This is the active site which is analogues to the lock .	5.697779157162447

The binding sites on the substrate come in proximity or bind to the binding site on the active site of the enzyme molecule .	4.64911600066502

Similarly the reactive group on the substrate comes in contact with two catalytic sites and then once the reacting groups gets entangled with the reaction sites on the active sites , the binding is complete and it can exhibit the catalytic function to take place .	4.8534311732586914

Now that was the understanding and they also very clearly understood at that time that both substrate as well as the active site on the enzyme molecule have rigid structures .	4.740846949822254

There is no question of change if they are rigid in nature .	5.70308003621708

They are just like a lock and key ; there is no flexibility .	6.883203391144292

If there is slight modification either in the conformation of the key it will not fit to the lock and thereby the reaction will not occur .	5.399256405756638

In fact the Fischerís lock and key arrangement was not based on any of the analytical probes .	4.175054066325502

It was only a conceptual explanation given because at that time , one thing we must appreciate that , not a very large number of enzyme reactions were understood .	4.894968776825166

Even the stereospecificity was not clearly understood .	6.200293228319937

It was mostly some very common reactions like hydrolysis of sucrose to glucose and fructose , most of the hydrolytic reactions were understood and this mechanism proposed only such a macro understanding that the substrate and the enzyme have rigid conformations which are complementary to each other and which fit in strictly .	3.715329996559802

At the time of Fischerís Lock and key mechanism , the most understood enzymatic reaction was hydrolysis of sucrose by invertase to glucose and fructose and obviously they would look into variety of other sugars like lactose on which the enzyme could not act .	3.4437114531977207

They could distinguish between the conformations of the substrate molecule and have much detailed information .	5.390729273383295

But still the surprising thing is that the concept is not totally invalid today .	5.327510859427691

In many cases it can still explain the whole theory or whole requirements of specificity .	4.141452096654332

Then came number of other developments and particularly the development with respect to the availability of analytical data on enzyme substrate binding .	4.937402640641807

People were able to make enzyme substrate complexes and their analogs , analyze them by NMR or EPR or variety of analytical physical tools and they found that when the enzyme and substrate do bind there is a significant change in the conformation .	4.121076607354688

The conformation is neither the same what was available in the case of enzyme molecule .	6.238669491524489

So there is something going on and keeping those data in view Koshland proposed a hypothesis as late as 1958 what we understand today as Koshland induced fit model .	3.7561433758545015

His proposal was a slight modification of the lock and key arrangement .	4.91067210962601

He said that the substrate has a rigid conformation with its binding sites and the functional site or the reacting groups present at a particular conformation .	5.709628437417405

But the enzyme active site is not a rigid conformation .	7.125972650856642

Itís a flexible conformation .	7.784013611684405

That means as soon as the substrate comes in the proximity of the enzyme active site , initial binding takes place .	4.449452186179138

The enzyme active site binds onto the substrate molecule .	4.9512817184466575

For example this is a functional group and this let us say is substrate .	7.474361263077651

The enzyme active site as soon as it comes in proximity , it wraps around the substrate molecule .	4.94721024984573

He gave an example that the interaction between the substrate and the enzyme is some thing like a hand and the woolen glove .	4.537105988673767

You wear a woolen glove .	8.431148327296466

Your hand is analogues to substrate .	9.760190535875848

Then when you put in the woolen glove it exactly fits into hand depending upon the conformation of your fingers .	4.537194858755225

Everything goes in line and interacts with different fingers and one can be comfortable and the reaction can proceed .	5.114236793774407

For example you have two binding sites .	6.8498985675512065

The free active site on the free enzyme molecule without interaction with the substrate has its particular configuration where the catalytic sites and binding sites are distantly located .	5.547551154553673

As soon as the binding groups come in contact with the binding site as they have interacted here the active site undergo a change in conformation and this catalytic sites are brought in proximity so as to wrap around the reactive group on the substrate molecule and then the ultimate conformation of the enzyme substrate complex which can use one of the mechanism by which catalytic reaction can take place , can be applied .	4.751541239172154

Such a mechanism very effectively can explain the high degree of the specificity for the enzyme molecule .	5.604809655320211

In the case of induced fit hypothesis one can also appreciate that in certain reactions for example even if there is reaction contaminant in the reaction mixture which are very similar to nature in the terms of their conformation to the actual substrate , they will not be able to interact .	4.885885052176273

For example in the case of lock and key mechanism if there are molecules which are similar in conformation they might be able to partly interact with the catalytic site and influence the reaction .	4.5569430403247075

Whereas in the case of the induced fit mechanism once the enzyme active site is totally wrapped around the substrate , the reaction sites are not at all available for any other contaminant and therefore there is no chance of any other contaminant present in the substrate molecule to be able to interact with the enzyme molecule .	4.390369209573718

One of the most typical examples of enzyme catalyzed reaction which was responsible for the elucidation of induced fit model was the hexose kinase .	4.032944082213708

The phosphorylation of D - hexose at the expense of ATP to hexose - 6 - phosphate .	4.866851821877963

In the absence of hexose , the ATP hydrolyzed extremely slowly .	4.831668070750207

The hexose is present in the proximity of the enzyme , the enzyme will bring both hexose and ATP along with the binding sites and then it can flop around the two molecules and the reaction can take place in a very fast speed .	5.943610480411295

The induced fit mechanism can also explain very clearly the bimolecular reactions which were difficult to understand as far as the lock and key arrangement .	4.102745120086495

Lock and key arrangement was very easily able to explain the unimolecular reactions .	5.26351714000979

But in case where two substrates are involved as in the case of hexose phosphorylation , the role of hexose and ATP both participating at the binding site for the reaction to occur could be explained using induced fit mechanism .	4.015948770513947

If you consider all the three explanations that we have considered today like Oxtenís three site interaction model , lock and key mechanism of Fischer or induced fit hypothesis of Koshland , when we talk about the specificity they donít link specificity by any means to the catalytic function .	3.9604123273943492

They consider specificity totally in isolation .	8.455159758203965

None of them is able to provide a suitable explanation for the catalytic function .	5.386892851273788

When we discussed the various ways in which the enzymes are able to catalyze reactions we understood that binding of the enzyme to the substrate was a very important feature in the acceleration of the reaction rate .	5.833372403481006

Binding of the substrate to the enzyme involves some expenditure of energy that is the binding energy involved in it which ultimately gives you an advantage in the reduction in activation energy and there is an initial energy .	5.280345926998993

It is also presumed that this binding energy is not totally a wasteful energy for the enzyme reactions .	4.907848140180774

A part of this binding energy also contributes to specificity and therefore if you look at the effect of strains that are developed , a hypothesis which is called as a strain that means at the stage of binding we understood that in the case of lock and key mechanism they are rigid .	4.165835522539656

But we might assume that the active site is almost complementary to the substrate molecule but is not exactly complementary , a situation which is slightly closer to lock and key mechanism not in absolute terms that they are complementary but they are not exactly complementary .	4.305879743015918

Therefore when the substrate and the enzyme active sites are brought in proximity and the binding takes place between the substrate and the enzyme active site it brings in a strain .	4.848814531230782

You see that the active site here unlike the lock and key mechanism is not exactly complementary .	4.634657500787498

This slot is slightly longer and therefore while the binding takes place it makes a sort of a strain onto the reactive group and it is analogues to the mechanism which we proposed for catalytic function that means strain mechanism and which contributes to reduction in the enthalpic component of the free energy of activation .	4.213479333124386

During this interaction of the enzyme active site with the substrate , the strain produced onto the reactive group as a result of binding process is responsible for specificity as well as part catalytic function .	5.389551926724569

These strain developed may contribute towards the reduction in activation energy but it is a result of binding process .	5.452343386341707

This binding process brings in the specificity and the nature of the binding site or the active site on the enzyme molecule is slightly complementary or of the similar type but not exactly complementary and the complementarity comes only after binding has taken place which results in the distortion of the reacting group and then the complementary comes in .	4.345731479961387

So that is called the strain effect which can take into account both catalytic function as well as specificity .	5.687448009859927

The strain effects have been discussed when we were talking about the ways in which the enzyme reduces energy of activation .	3.936671171341099

The strain on the reacting group was one of the mechanisms .	6.918852623884597

Because the active site is not exactly complementary , after the substrate approaches the binding sites it forces the reacting group to develop a strain so as to bring in complementary to the catalytic sites .	4.809058854604732

Then only these catalytic sites can combine .	7.0824740815394795

Otherwise if it was totally complementary without the strain then the reacting group will come down some where here and no reaction can take place .	4.078000995669486

Only when a strain is developed the reaction takes place and the reaction takes place with the suitable degree of specificity introducing to it .	4.589259262772289

Because the binding has to take place and the binding process requires a strain onto the substrate molecule so that it comes in proximity of the catalytic sites .	4.9036194964916815

If strain is not developed it will remain in the binding site but not at the active site .	5.736408537651936

The enzyme will not be able to provide the catalytic function .	6.055742050887038

Like in the case of other mechanisms or other hypothesis proposed for specificity while we are able to explain that binding will take place , the functional group comes in proximity to the reacting group but it doesnít explain if the reaction will take place or not .	4.8313988046252705

Just coming in proximity could provide you an effect what we discussed like high substrate concentration in the proximity of the active site but does not explain you how the energy of activation is induced .	4.297252652343499

Here in this case this also explains how the energy of activation is reduced in terms of its enthalpic contribution .	5.591623658576856

Another thing which is very well related to this strain mechanism is the mechanism what we understand as transition state stabilization .	5.06043764335861

Here in the case the effect is almost very similar to what we call as strain effect but while the substrate enzyme binding takes place at the active site there are still some unfavorable interactions at the active site of the substrate That means the substrate molecule in the vicinity of the active site is not very comfortable in terms of its interactions .	4.789435397820412

The presence of certain unfavorable interactions at the active site for the substrate when the binding has taken place tends to distort the substrate molecule in the direction so that the enzyme substrate complex tends to become complementary to the transition state .	4.493889324324818

In the first characteristic feature of catalysis we saw that the transition state is complementary to enzyme substrate complex and not the substrate .	4.693507254079324

The enzyme is complementary to enzyme substrate complex , the enzyme active site and not to the substrate itself .	5.891539018159294

Therefore the role of the binding of substrate molecule to the enzyme at the binding site , the substrate doesnít remain very comfortable .	5.938274818306952

There are many unfavorable interactions that is present there and they distort the substrate molecule so that these enzyme substrate binding approaches towards that of transition complex .	4.3083725021823565

The first step is binding of the binding sites onto the active site .	5.706233863179623

Once that takes place , still the catalytic sites are not approached by the functional groups which are likely to undergo reaction .	5.4175654403060625

But in addition to the binding site there are many unfavorable interactions present between the substrate and the active site .	5.581870260492222

Consider three different functional groups .	11.437084747194525

In addition to that on the active site there will be many more amino acid residues which will be in the proximity and they might provide some kind of unfavorable interactions .	5.43130984740477

Now these interactions tend to distort the substrate and this distortion of the substrate is favored towards reaching the transition state .	4.695868829635456

In other words we are developing a strain onto the substrate molecule so that the substrate molecule reacting groups are coming in proximity to the catalytic site .	4.759847717948295

In the hypothesis of the transition state stabilization it is stated that the unfavorable interactions available at the active sites on the substrate favors the distortion of the substrate in such a way that the final enzyme substrate complex approaches the structure of that of transition state .	4.646590336596219

Because partly you have already taken up that path .	7.053110871201511

That is what happened in strain development also .	7.130184712148837

Part of the energy required for energy of activation is already met by strain onto the substrate molecule .	4.8800238000833485

So these are some of the major mechanisms that have been proposed for explaining the specificity of the enzyme action .	4.891050396339086

It is over all rate of reaction in terms of rate of product formation that indicates whether the enzyme is specific to a substrate or not .	6.429536120723784

What is the order of specificity , to what extent it would be specific , what are the impurities which can interfere in the specificity they are all related to the results of reaction that is the rate of formation of product .	5.453934671270306

The specificity also has a very significant role in terms of the industrial applications of enzymes .	5.302981007617128

We must also appreciate that while in the case of the catalytic function we understand that if the rate of reaction is increased its usefulness as a industrial catalyst is also very high because higher the rate of reaction you can very efficiently use it for industrial purposes .	5.044684789792404

But what is the role of specificity .	13.834747831123167

The specificity in fact has both negative as well as positive role .	6.095424140295612

Positive role in the sense , that you can restrict the formation of any of the by - products .	8.186747585042083

Even if your feed history substrate is impure to some extent you will know that only reaction which can be catalyzed specifically by that enzyme which you are providing will take place and no other reaction will take place .	4.753867358783867

Even the side products formed by action of water usually most of the organic chemists consider water for organic chemical reactions as the culprit because it can lead to variety of side products .	4.072777591209159

So all the side products can be absent , which can make our life comfortable as far as the purification of the product is concerned .	4.747986170794729

That means many of the enzymes cannot be produced on a very massive scale because the requirement will be only for single reaction and therefore for a single reaction the requirement will not be very large .	4.786520215511776

That is why the enzymes still remain expensive catalyst compared to chemical catalyst .	3.674357908879049

For example in the case of chemical catalyst Raneyís nickel , it is the catalyst used for all hydrogenation reactions in the organic chemical field and we can produce them in bulk quantities and the cost of production can be reasonably low .	4.5480498910903355

On the other hand if you have to produce glucose oxidase , which acts only on ﬂ - D - glucose not on a - D - glucose or any other hexose , itís requirement will be only for oxidation of glucose which will restrict its application and therefore the scale of operation .	3.6153134620094742

The specificity must be looked in from both the angle and in many cases today people are applying the development of molecular biology particularly in sense of protein engineering to modify the substrate specificity both when we want the absence of side products to make it more specific as well as when we want broad specificity so that the same enzyme can be applied to a large variety of substrates .	4.4856917937237455

We have so far seen that the performance of idealized continuous flow immobilized enzyme reactors depends primarily on the reaction kinetics and the basic assumption for idealized reactors was that the immobilized enzyme preparation does not experience any mass transfer or partitioning effects .	4.486782119771945

The immobilized enzymes experience in addition to the catalytic activity three major external effects during immobilization .	4.366163013470092

One is the conformational changes as a result of which the basic turn over number of the enzyme might be altered ; even the value of Michaelis Menten constant may also be altered .	5.6496116955583

The other effect is partitioning of substrate and product which also results in alteration in the Km value of the enzyme reaction .	4.432899181489262

Then the third effect was mass transfer of substrate and product and this mass transfer as we noticed was at two levels .	3.9883908244957498

Or in a very broader sense if you consider the reaction in immobilized enzyme reactor it will imply that in addition to the biochemical reaction there will be four more resistances involved .	5.903467393747509

One will be transport of the substrate from the bulk to the surface ; from surface the substrate has to transport to the site of the enzymatic reaction which means the enzyme molecules that are located throughout the immobilized enzyme particle and then the reverse process that means the product produced as a result of biochemical reaction has to transport back from the carrier interior to the surface .	4.732160976495693

Therefore the two major matrices which provide resistance to the over all reaction is the thin film around the immobilized enzyme particle and the whole matrix itself and the pores in which the immobilized enzyme is distributed .	5.04419264502435

I think you will also recall what we had seen earlier ; the diagram in which you have a thin film , a stationary film around the particle .	5.137541970672887

This film thickness will depend on various physical properties of the fluid .	6.62737693288079

Then you have enzyme distributed all over the pores in the particle and the substrate has to transport from the surface to those materials and similarly reverse .	4.798800722896667

I like you to have a look at the substrate gradient .	8.097159453664228

If you consider that this regime is the thin film then from the bulk there might be a linear substrate gradient across the thin film and the concentration might drop at the surface and from the surface to the interior of the particle that means to center of the particle there might be again a gradient as a result of biochemical reaction .	4.126659432754692

Because the substrate will be consumed and as the substrate progresses through the particle depth the concentration will be dropping down and there are two possibilities .	5.453847634615991

One is that you have a rather more convenient situation that from here the substrate concentration goes like a profile like this which is more favorable in the sense that around the whole particle there is some substrate available for biochemical reaction to take place .	4.674199632572339

On the other hand it can also happen that the substrate concentration drops to zero earlier than the substrate has reached to the middle point and therefore this portion which is highlighted here is deprived of the substrate and the overall reaction rate that is observed apparently is much smaller .	4.418059586690473

There might be coupled partitioning effects as I have shown in the lower figures in the gradient lower but basically these are the three major issues : biochemical reaction , external film diffusion and internal pore diffusion that are encountered in the case of an immobilized enzyme reactor which need to be considered while we consider the reactor performance .	3.7152436994824125

Although in the idealized reactor performance we have not taken into account but in the actual reactors they need to be taken care while analyzing the steady state reactor performance .	4.626689128661787

An important feature of the performance of immobilized enzyme reactor is that one needs to identify the limiting rate , the step which has a limiting rate the lowest reaction rate .	5.587514533246409

That means a comparison between the biochemical reaction rate and the rate of diffusion by the Ö .	6.145652021111381

film diffusion or the pore diffusion .	12.180507806576806

One must be able to identify by some analytical method or experimental method that which is the rate limiting step and we must analyze or design our reactor keeping in view the rate limiting step .	3.9287266779060332

Consider that we have an immobilized enzyme preparation with a very high enzyme loading .	6.230008410086062

That means the preparation is highly reactive , the rate of reaction can be very high and the rate of diffusion is slow either because of the Ö. .. of the substrate or the chemical nature of the matrix .	5.168023710595127

If the rate of diffusion is slow in that case the diffusion will become rate limiting .	5.184462723173397

If the difference between the rate of diffusion and the rate of biochemical reaction are too large then one of them will be the controlling factor and the whole reactor design must be based on that particular step .	5.266900375332952

Alternatively if you take an immobilized enzyme preparation to be very lean loading that means the loading is very low and the catalyst is not very reactive or alternatively the enzyme Ö .	6.643902327547004

that turn over number is very low and the rate of diffusion is very fast .	5.767223419542356

In that case diffusion effectively will not play a key role in the reactor design and the reactor design can be easily taken care by idealized reactor performance considering the reaction kinetics in picture .	5.068109161794443

Based on these three parameters particularly as I mentioned earlier the conformational changes , mass transfer effects and the partitioning effects , the kinetic parameters for immobilized enzyme are classified into three major classes .	4.3193569907220155

One is intrinsic parameters which are the same as that of soluble enzyme which means no partitioning in a soluble system , no mass transfer limitations ; the sole parameter is the reaction rate and they are called the intrinsic parameters .	5.121370082361724

If we consider the rate expression our classical rate expression v = k2E0S / Km + S will apply to the situation .	4.866931800522385

The second class of the kinetic parameters is defined as inherent parameter .	5.809353479284521

Inherent kinetic parameters are those which are obtained as a result of conformational changes only .	6.260967191628095

That means they are dependent on the method of immobilization .	4.778857617331504

That means the kind of reactants we have used in immobilization , the kind of matrix we have used in immobilization and whatever the interaction between the matrix and the enzyme under the conditions of immobilization , whatever conformational changes have taken place , whatever kinetic parameters have been modified as a result of this interaction are considered in the inherent parameters and we define them as ví = kí2E0S / Kím + S The parameters are just given prime and the inherent parameters have no role to play or not much can be done during the reactor design or reactor operation .	3.8348031350945972

They are the final property of the immobilized enzyme , kinetic property .	7.193522586829317

I must again clearly stress that the inherent parameters do not consider the diffusional effects or the partitioning effects .	4.399364594904534

That means if the system has no partitioning behavior or no diffusional limitations ; diffusion will be there because there is a phase difference .	5.111727695828856

But if the diffusion is not the rate limiting step or rather it is quite fast compared to the reaction rate the inherent parameters will be useful .	5.889598411382134

On the other hand in case the mass transfer effects are very severe they can be totally rate limiting steps .	5.02485325857146

That means the whole rate of reaction is controlled by the rate of diffusion .	5.76808822146819

Biochemical reaction is very fast and the rate of diffusion is slow .	7.153807427777855

The rates may not be absolutely very far apart if the two are very comparable in that case we need to consider our apparent reaction velocity as equal to vapp = kí2E0S / Kappm + S Here when we say that the apparent parameters are those which can be modified , which can be taken care by reactor operation .	4.885980394860517

That means as I mentioned some time earlier that the thickness of the film can be controlled by either increased linear flow velocity in the case of packed bed reactor or by increasing the agitation speed in the case of CSTR .	3.7778403076699028

Similarly on the other hand the internal flow diffusion also can be regulated by controlling the particle size .	5.008018866652641

That means the distance of transport of the substrate into the immobilized enzyme particle is minimized or reduced .	4.792562106237564

Therefore the substrate will be available all across the particle and thus can be modified .	5.839747049939681

Therefore they are called apparent parameters and in all possible analysis we must be interested in the apparent parameters , Kappm .	4.885972743939876

That will dictate if you want to consider diffusional limitations also as a part of our analysis .	5.14480376464723

Therefore we have three distinct approaches to monitor by experimental methods the effect of diffusional limitation in the case of immobilized enzyme particles .	5.528140714414493

By the experimental reactor operations in the laboratory many people have noticed that diffusional limitations play a key role either by varying the agitation speed in the case of a CSTR or by the varying the linear flow velocity in the case of PFR , the rate of reaction can be improved and so diffusional limitations can be overcome if any .	3.4031177478643215

You would recall that in our previous lecture we had discussed what are immobilized enzymes , why should we immobilize enzymes and what are the requirements of immobilization of enzymes and the three major requirements – a soluble enzyme and the carrier and method of immobilization .	4.329041762120628

We were looking into their characteristics .	7.1400117456273025

The soluble enzyme , as we all know , required for immobilization must have certain properties that is it should possess high specific activity and also desirable functional properties that are required for use of immobilization enzyme .	4.466913764855658

A large numbers of methods of immobilization are reported in literature .	5.022978851208544

Most of them can be classified simply into three major categories one is carrier binding methods .	4.816448399022681

Typical examples are adsorption ; covalent binding and we will be discussing them in detail .	5.589078272888607

The other method is cross linking .	6.091600387905022

The enzymes themselves posses a large number of functional groups which can be made to react to each other , thereby aggregating the molecules and making them insoluble in water .	4.6945378472444

Just to repeat the cross linking refers to linking more than one enzyme molecule through their functional residues present on their surface .	4.1352854946029565

Most of the enzyme molecules will have a large number of functional residues .	9.331656091967378

They may be hydrophobic groups ; they may be electrostatic charges or other functional residues .	4.781649177188427

They can be linked under certain conditions , under ambient condition so that their inactivation is not allowed and on those conditions aggregates of the enzymes can be made which can function as immobilized enzymes .	4.417838022092365

The third type of method is entrapment methods where the enzymes are entrapped within a matrix .	4.671297485855637

It could be a gel , it could be a micro capsule and there by you could provide them an environment which is very analogues to a living cell and then use them as immobilize preparations .	4.531428219095115

You can see that a large number of methods are available .	5.113598635271549

Under each category also there are number of methods and we need to choose a suitable method for a particular purpose .	5.957881737287298

There are no general rules .	7.483017035346717

It often goes by trial and error and some available information .	5.01188605994609

Out of the methods available , which we will discuss subsequently , if we have to choose an immobilization method to use for a specific application there are four distinct parameters which should be looked into .	4.822387997238014

The first and probably the foremost is yield of immobilization .	4.030170805401891

That means during immobilization procedure what is the loss of enzyme activity because there is no method which can give you hundred percent recovery of the enzyme activity that you have put into the system .	5.657076085422546

There will be some enzyme which will be deactivated or lost during the immobilization and the loss of enzyme activity has to be kept minimum for all practical purposes .	4.514654040918971

When you consider the yield of an immobilization , it is basically a term which can be considered on the basis of material balance .	6.11470052770777

This is the total picture of all the species that will be available and the loss of enzyme activity , soluble enzyme activity let us say as E0 , residual enzyme activity as Er and the immobilize enzyme activity as Ei , then the loss of enzyme activity is E0 - Er - Ei / E0 That is the loss or rather fractional loss of enzyme activity .	4.052938166890987

Of the total enzyme activity , the activity is distributed into two fractions - the immobilized enzyme as well as the uncoupled enzyme in the residue and these two theoretically should combine and form the total value of E0 but very often at the end of a method there is some balance left and the balance is the loss due to deactivation during immobilization .	4.43111756141367

The yield of the immobilization is defined as r = Ei / E0 - Er Very often there is confusion in reporting these terms and that ’ s why I have tried to put them in the form of an expression .	4.378069863121698

While we talk of a yield we must keep into mind the residual activity in the supernatant .	5.137972218965963

Its not in the total enzyme because part of the enzyme has been recovered in the supernatant which if desired can be recycled .	6.128448076875792

Therefore the yield will be the activity which is recovered in the immobilized form divided by E0 - Ei in the residue .	4.711387982970138

When you talk of Ei that is the activity of immobilized enzyme you are measuring in terms of the activity only .	6.797486290329276

So that means it is active .	8.206476100560709

Right in the beginning I made it very clear that when we talk of quantification of enzyme it is just not a physical quantity like mass or concentration .	4.29999040561213

It is the functional property .	8.151200600948643

Its quantity is functional property and the activity represents functional activity .	5.728646218394022

We are not measuring Ei in terms of protein contents .	6.1585714193467265

I am measuring all these terms E0 , Er and Ei in terms of catalytic activity .	5.079520986657702

So it is functional .	10.421151885595872

This loss , if it is a let us a physical quantity like protein concentration the balance will be perfect .	4.901851618997716

You cannot account for any loss of protein in the system .	5.444420952259848

It is only the loss of activity because of the conformational changes .	7.06514841094179

The other factor which is important to be considered is enzyme loading .	5.080824558559017

When we talk about specific activity higher the specific activity , enzyme is catalytically better .	4.984688775902601

Similarly in case of enzyme loading we talk of international units per gram of carrier or if you take into account the bulk density of the carrier you can also say international units per ml of carrier bed that means you pack the carrier into a bed , packed bed , and then consider the volume .	4.4849325157012645

So enzyme loading is another factor and we want a preparation with as high loading as possible theoretically .	5.654245516385176

The enzyme loading will also have a direct linkage with the mass transfer limitations .	5.467678499290991

We will see subsequently how mass transfer and catalytic activity are linked .	5.180711904670715

Then the third parameter which is important to look at is storage and operational stability .	4.90524818813019

As I mentioned that we have to look for enzyme and one of the major advantage of immobilized enzyme is that they can be reused , they can be repeatedly used , continuously used and therefore they must possess a much higher stability than the soluble enzyme .	5.105550846739232

This stability is not only in terms of use but also during storage and this parameter is usually expressed in terms of half life .	5.337086616909007

Either half life during storage that means the time in which the activity loses to fifty percent of the original activity or during use in a continuous reactor or in a batch reactor that is in terms of number of cycles .	5.519258285662952

You can express in that term .	6.843859713399961

That will be only restricted when you are talking of a fibre or a surface .	5.654391210963457

The most commonly used matrices are beads - the spherical particles and that ’ s why gram or volume and they are packed in a packed bed .	3.9537540309500665

When I say per ml I am referring to a parameter which is analogues to use in a packed bed .	4.547777788308839

But if you this in a surface , in fibre or in a film you can also express in terms of a surface area .	5.266581553445798

That is always allowed .	13.119942725848043

But for all industrial application the surface excepting for biosensors and things like that which are very specific applications , for industrial catalysis it is used in the form of particles and used with the packed bed .	4.357744736296239

We will discuss those aspects subsequently .	6.39607170832633

Iu / m2 also is a feasible parameter that we can define .	9.43240734945857

For example in the case of adsorption you require a carrier .	5.394241420506439

If suppose you want to adsorb by ionic binding , you need a carrier which possesses charges .	4.712101801241678

Similarly if you want a covalent binding you need a carrier which possesses certain functional residues which can be coupled to the enzyme .	5.0442338504068

So each method will have some limitations on the choice of carrier and therefore the cost of the carrier .	5.294894074633516

Another parameter which must be taken into account is regenerability .	5.061173202184569

Very often even after the immobilized enzyme preparation has been exhausted during use the carrier can be recovered and reused .	4.6915770923204745

So the cost of the carrier must be taken into account in terms of per cycle not the absolute cost .	5.524407511353939

You must differentiate between the absolute cost and cost of the carrier per cycle .	5.369591490498791

Because many of the carriers although expensive , can be used for a long period and in number of repeated cycles .	6.362146427521723

Therefore they are still acceptable and desirable because of other desirable property .	4.628707560369496

The first and probably the simplest method of immobilization is by adsorption .	4.727642242383772

The adsorption method is a very broad , non - specific method and it involves binding of the enzyme to the surface of an insoluble carrier that has not been specifically functionalized for covalent coupling .	4.316045977754238

I must mark here particularly the phrase “specifically functionalized for covalent coupling ” .	3.562378313448017

This probably gives you an idea that this is a very broad non - specific method .	6.061598643161972

If we consider all the carrier binding methods excluding those which involve covalent linkage , rest of all the bindings , interactions between the carrier and the enzyme are covered under the term called adsorption .	4.319868184493878

A very broad based method which involves a number of non - specific , multivariant , reversible interactions between the enzyme and the carrier at mild conditions .	4.725070757145197

The second point also builts in a number of phrases .	5.703696002389933

For example the interactions that are involved are non - specific , very often more than one interaction is involved in a particular method , multivariant that means more than one physical property is employed .	4.791125683411342

In most cases the methods based on adsorption are reversible in nature .	3.679068761860194

That means under certain conditions while you can adsorb the enzyme on to a carrier you can also create condition by which you can desorb the enzyme .	4.363144644871553

The basic property of this reversible interaction also makes it a weak binding .	5.142845089504911

Weak binding in the sense while during use , the enzyme can also dissolve slowly over a long period of time and if the carrier characteristics are sturdy they can be regenerated and reused .	4.9286387965223195

Multivariant means that more than one physico - chemical interaction is involved in binding .	6.926220792854937

Another feature is mild conditions and that will apply to most of the immobilization methods and also to adsorption .	6.018297006252876

That means the environmental conditions required for adsorption must be mild and here I think I like to very specifically define the term mild .	4.128276650523392

Mild refers here not to the value one or two it refers to those conditions under which enzyme is conformationally stable .	5.021084878607647

The definition of mild condition refers to those conditions which are environmentally acceptable to the enzyme .	4.280631866353241

If the enzyme is stable at 70ºC , 70ºC is acceptable and can be considered as mild .	5.424957512267646

But if the enzyme is not stable even at 20ºC you may have to go to 4 degrees to immobilize and the definition of mild will remain at 4 degrees .	4.56538363135271

I have purposely not used the word ambient because you refer it to a well definite range .	4.457707873217277

The advantage of the situation is that usually the methods based on adsorption results in high yields .	4.561020235193794

A disadvantage is that the preparations do not have very high operational stability .	6.885896737514718

The method is reversible in nature , the interactions are reversible and so operational stability is usually not very high .	4.404210487680174

Although by various other manipulations like adsorption , coupling with cross linking the operational stability can be improved but intrinsically adsorption based methods are usually operationally high .	3.783421956957322

If suppose in the case of covalent binding half lives are of the order of few months here it may be of the order of few days .	4.472729061473407

So that is what it refers to but allows the regeneration with carrier .	4.435093729357505

On the other hand although the operational stability is not very high but the advantage is that the carrier can be regenerated and reused .	3.919036757923279

That is the plus point .	7.7585174314886185

You have a large variety of carriers that can be used .	5.248610648038919

We will look at some of the examples of the carriers and finally adsorption based methods have been very often used to study the enzymology of systems that naturally occur in biological system because in case of living cells most of the enzymes are supported on a solid matrix through adsorption only .	4.074767388395169

There are no covalent linkages .	7.545895087983349

Either the enzymes are supported on membrane or they are supported on certain particulate matters and therefore the methods based on adsorption are usually very analogues similar to those that are found in the living system .	4.102113210968001

Operational stability is defined in terms of half life .	7.73461583173797

Consider the use of immobilized enzyme in a reactor and pack it in a packed bed , feed in and effluent out .	5.552216924079375

Here X - axis is operational time and Y - axis is fraction of conversion .	6.243774126585902

What you notice is that when you start at zero time the fraction of conversion will keep on going down as the enzyme activity is reduced or lost .	5.190798983127023

If you consider as a first order process then the half life of this that means the time it takes to reach the fifty percent of the original value is half life .	4.777575839630036

If we consider E = E0 e - kdt You can simply calculate half life as t1 / 2 = 0.69 / kd t1 / 2 is less in the case of adsorption .	4.8309113301736994

Other way , compared to covalent binding .	6.258746671573303

Right . Because the interaction is reversible in nature so it keeps leaking .	5.389668810897441

A very crude term could be the enzyme keeps leaking values , very small amounts , slowly not in a very fast rate .	4.2199747654936814

This property of leaking of the enzyme from immobilized preparation has been very advantageously used in many cases of the enzyme therapy purposes , where we want to put an immobilized enzyme preparation onsite at a site where the enzyme is required and the enzyme must leak continuously not in a very high concentration and over a long period of time .	5.065805360522966

Some systems like immobilized …… .	13.804648889615637

has been inserted into the blood stream in the immobilized forms - microcapsules and the enzyme leaks slowly and the immobilized system can remain in blood stream over a few months .	5.409116295154634

You have to give another shot to keep the enzyme activity available in the blood stream .	5.335916601236585

So these methods can have an advantage that the reversible nature can also be used in some cases where you want to use the drug or a therapeutic agent with the requirement of slow availability over a long period of time .	4.209534019375328

As far as study of reactor system is concerned , we are not measuring the enzyme activity every time .	5.946406934625129

What we are measuring is the conversion at the effluent .	6.163863298183999

So that ’ s why the graph is in the form of conversion .	6.438523830675341

Three most common types of adsorption methods are based on physical adsorption which is again a most non - specific type of adsorption where we use hydrogen bonding , electrostatic interactions or Vanderwaal interactions , a variety of interactions where there is no specific reasons and we use a very broad range of carriers like alumina , celite , bentonite , glass etc where which by certain conditions of pH , temperature and salt you can adsorb the enzyme on to the surface and they can be used .	3.5172391335058832

The second method is ionic binding where you take a tailored matrix which has a definite charge on the surface and ion exchange resins are the most commonly used matrices .	4.917228114293667

DEAE - Cellulose , Amberlite etc which are charged particles and these charged particles based on the electrostatic interaction can bind the enzyme molecules at a pH where the net charge is counter .	5.074444600560051

The enzyme at this stage is counter charged at a particular condition .	6.500844548168092

The third category is hydrophobic binding where we predominantly use hydrophobic interactions on the surface of the carrier and the hydrophobic interactions on the surface of the enzyme protein .	3.3619012201503606

Although bulk of the hydrophobic residues are buried inside the residue of enzyme but still on the surface there are very small hydrophobic patches which can be used here for immobilizing on to the surface of a hydrophobic carrier ; carriers like polypropylene beads .	4.5968997301353856

There is a commercial product by the name Accurel , which is a microporous carrier consisting of polypropylene , butyl or hexyl sepharose etc .	3.8136156644276005

There are number of hydrophobic carriers used and which are available for binding of enzyme .	5.187936745651466

Many of the carriers which are available today for adsorption of enzymes are developed for chromatographic separations .	4.877385110397877

For example all the carriers like hydrophobic binding or ionic binding were originally developed for chromatographic separations where the function is same .	3.9514381026864203

That means you are binding through ionic interactions and desorbing it under the conditions of desorption and therefore the same thing applies here .	4.439895469242696

In fact the preparation of immobilized enzyme by adsorption is very much similar to chromatographic separations on ion exchange resin , although we are only interested in the first part of it .	4.778290445636985

Only adsorption part ; desorption is not our interest where as in the case of chromatography both the parts are important .	4.674552744405308

Another important group of adsorption methods is metal salt linkage .	4.81403850766563

Certain metal salts like titanium tetra chloride and ferric chloride form a kind of an inorganic bridge on the surface of the carrier and to which the enzyme molecules can couple .	4.6008744434787

The linkage that is formed , what we have in the literature and what people have used , is the metal salt linkage .	5.031208373397068

It is not a covalent linkage ; it is a physical interaction and there by the enzyme is held but has been very successful method from the practical point of view .	4.874209055888941

We will discuss that in detail .	6.063436192112703

Most of the adsorption methods can be characterized by the classical adsorption isotherms .	5.038904782836231

Depending on the nature of the carrier and nature of the enzyme that we are talking about , the isotherms may vary .	5.805207511697413

Three general types of isotherms are known .	7.2079735559885565

One is linear where q is the concentration of the enzyme protein on to the surface of the carrier ; y is the corresponding concentration in the solution at equilibrium .	5.1279006931157065

If you take a combination of enzyme in carrier concentration and at equilibrium measure the concentration in the solid phase and the liquid and you make an isotherm , then you may end up sometime in some cases a linear relationship where q is equal to k.y To make the isotherm , take different ratios of the carrier and the enzyme activity .	4.402104517413083

That means enzyme activity to carrier ratio is varied and at different combinations you allow equilibrium to be formed and under equilibrium condition you measure the concentration of the enzyme in the liquid phase and also in the solid phase .	4.125566775808292

Each point represents a particular enzyme to carrier ratio .	7.996825763365652

You can find three different types of isotherms : linear is simple ; Freundlich is more general in the sense that it does not fit into any hypothesis but in general you can vary curve fitting .	4.206979900576345

What ever kind of isotherm you get , you just raise to a factor of n and by analysis of your data you will calculate the value of k and n .	4.1526089110749576

You could make a log log plot and you can get the value of k and n .	4.576690430386499

The most established and analytically proven method is Langmuir isotherm .	4.505035057642769

Here q is the concentration of the enzyme protein on to the solid matrix and q0 is the maximum capacity of the matrix .	5.585926824652491

If you take a very high enzyme concentration compared to carrier , allow equilibrium to be established that means the concentration of the enzyme on to the immobilized preparation which will represent the saturation behavior is q0 .	4.232356196669507

You will notice that it is analogues to your Michaelis Menten kinetics .	5.71604547391384

These three expressions the Langmuir isotherm , Michaelis Menten kinetics , hyperbolic expression and also the Mannose equation for cell growth are almost analogues expressions and that indicates that there is some inter relationship or some similarity in their basic physical interpretation .	3.9284353061032293

Langmuir isotherm is based on a theoretical development .	10.909158172957193

One can develop on the basis of number of binding sites on the carrier molecule for enzyme .	6.277155164811201

Here just like we consider the enzyme substrate binding where the enzyme acts as the carrier and the substrate is ligand here the carrier will be the matrix and the protein will be the ligand and on those conditions you can develop it or you can analyze it by a double reciprocal plot .	5.593831249244365

The analogy is that the three expressions , the Langmuir adsorption isotherm , the Michaelis Menten kinetics and Mannose kinetics for cell growth they are analogues terms .	4.154935721924009

In the case of enzyme we are talking of enzyme substrate complex formation .	5.319535564213932

That means enzyme is the matrix , surface is a ligand .	7.723857685066377

If we talk in terms of adsorption , the substrate gets adsorbed on to the enzyme surface .	7.458737407416505

On the other hand here in the case of adsorption the enzyme is itself a ligand and the matrix or the carrier is the surface on which the ligand adsorbs .	5.081381242185632

In the third case , in the case of cell growth , the Mannose model of microbial cell growth it is a substrate which is a ligand just like enzymes but the matrix is the cell mass itself and it reflects the transport of substrate into the cell .	4.642201938415365

So this is adsorption that is transport and enzyme catalyses enzyme substrate binding .	4.1349967247773485

So these three phenomena are intrinsically someway related because they end up in a similar kind of a kinetic expression .	4.660785892798247

As far as the analysis is concerned all the three can also be analyzed by a double reciprocal plot .	4.8921733847853055

That is if you plot 1 / q versus 1 / y you will get a linear plot and you will get the value of q0 and k .	6.020145234533802

The adsorption process for a particular enzyme and for a particular carrier can be analyzed quantitatively .	7.544599669049233

Many physical factors influence the adsorption process .	7.314610301122942

I have listed some of them here .	10.008218965320498

The first parameter is pH .	8.234481839867419

The pH will be a very major parameter which will affect the binding in the case of ionic binding .	6.505349845390594

Even for other forms of binding processes pH plays a key role and very often it has been noted that the binding by adsorption is maximum at its isoelectric points .	4.054411013574971

Large variety of relationships with respect to pH for the quantity adsorbed has been found .	5.183751290250059

There is no general ruling but in general or a common feature can be considered that at the isoelectric point the pH value will be most preferable for the adsorption processes .	4.552812197119623

No . Net charge is zero .	9.35697903894924

It is not that the proteins are not charged at that pH .	4.981102420720576

The negative and positive charges are equal .	7.19262672632162

Not that there is no charge .	10.462174097100911

The second parameter is salts .	6.682448127825345

Salts have a very complex behavior .	18.58698215550895

In fact it has almost opposite behavior .	5.208151892365165

You must have studied also in the case of bio separations particularly the concentration of salt is used for increasing as well as decreasing solubility .	6.3061869735540625

But in most cases the salt concentration is required to be kept at a minimum because salts are very good eluents also .	3.9269159783704755

In ion exchange chromatography very often we use high ionic strength as a medium for elution of the adsorbed material .	4.316504493133814

Therefore at high salt concentration adsorption is usually poor and minimum salt concentration is required to be kept .	4.235176853915043

Protein concentration will be important and we have seen from the adsorption isotherm itself .	7.288069204659102

The definite ratio of protein to carrier will play a particular equilibrium behavior and higher the protein concentration you can reach nearer the saturation level at equilibrium .	4.668531367416255

Temperature again is a very significant parameter which must be understood .	8.196904811641256

If we look at adsorption of a small molecular weight material or a small molecular weight ligands on to a surface the general behavior is that increasing the temperature reduces the adsorption .	4.904678279991143

That means the quantity of ligand adsorbed per unit weight of the carrier for low molecular weight ligands will be less as you increase the temperature and the reason attributed to this is because of the movement of the particles as the temperature increases .	5.384996648778005

That means the movement of particle increases and the tendency is for desorbing rather than adsorption .	4.352476791918058

But in the case of protein adsorption when we are talking about enzymes , we are talking about proteins and macromolecules , adsorption over a narrow range of temperature offers a reverse phenomena .	4.339236358295337

That means adsorption increases with temperature .	6.960472228479341

Mind the word I am using “over a narrow range of temperature increase ” .	4.747026538084318

If you increase to a higher level desorption also might start .	4.845050473277533

But before desorption even inactivation might start .	6.530994489310846

But we consider the adsorption at …… range of temperature .	7.160348420385798

The primary factors responsible for the increase in adsorption with temperature are when the protein binds to a surface there is some unfolding of the protein molecules , which is an endothermic process and the increase of temperature resulting in enhanced adsorption supports the hypothesis that the binding or adsorption of a protein molecule or a polymeric material to a surface is an endothermic process coupled with unfolding of the confirmation .	4.310020731543728

When I say unfolding I am not referring to total deactivation but minor modification in the conformation which extends its total volume or total surface area .	3.709014411586282

The other factor which is important , which is probably attributing to this increase of adsorption with the increase in temperature is the diffusional processes because most of time we are talking about the carrier being a porous material and the ligands or the protein here have to diffuse into the surface , into the internal pore surface and the diffusion process gets increased by increase in temperature .	3.9497000530779207

So both the unfolding of the protein molecule on the surface of the carrier and the diffusional processes involved in the adsorption in the internal pores ultimately leads to give you a phenomenon which represents increase in adsorption with increase in temperature over a narrow range .	4.10439861782506

Carrier properties , depending on the property like surface property of the carrier particles which were used as matrix , will also play a role on the adsorption behaviour depending on the nature may be sometime even the carriers are pre - conditioned , swollen to improve the property .	4.432898638416849

Time of adsorption is another parameter which is significant and important because we are talking about the macromolecular adsorption .	5.354323616350735

So the diffusion is involved and the time required very often is controlled by diffusional limitations and the rate of diffusion controls the time required for adsorption process .	4.971600059488201

This in the case of a small ligand is not a constant .	7.600647220739303

At least four major methods are used for adsorption .	7.602773218685532

The first and probably the most trivial method is the static process .	3.5201533230158275

That means you bring in an enzyme solution in contact with a carrier and leave it over night or over a long period of time .	3.673521270158248

Adsorption takes place without any hesitation .	9.54948859098789

It takes a very long time and that is the process very often many people use in laboratories .	6.423020870478934

The yields are also much lower particularly for porous carrier because of the diffusional limitations .	5.684353105809088

One of the most disadvantageous situations in the case of static process is that the loading of the enzyme is not uniform over the carrier .	5.822471556708135

Even if you allow for a long period the loading is usually not uniform .	5.773758456123181

Suppose this is the carrier particle .	14.52793808572311

You have lot of enzyme molecules on the surface but on the interior it is very , very rarely distributed and the loading is not uniform .	5.854616969613405

The most commonly used method in the laboratories is dynamic batch process in which you mix the two components , the enzyme and the carrier under known conditions or under standard conditions for adsorption , which favours adsorption and agitate them , stir them mechanically , under mild stirring so that the carrier particle should not get degraded and also the enzyme molecules should not be influenced .	4.1473309698768706

The equilibrium is allowed to be reached over a period of time .	3.988630945063968

It usually leads to a fast method and most common method used in the laboratories .	6.303616772292986

In the commercial establishment when we use adsorption as the method of immobilization we use reactor loading process .	4.798278953703038

That means first of all the reactor which is to be used for bio - conversion of the enzymatic reaction is packed with the carrier itself and then the enzyme solution is recirculated constantly through the carrier bed and over a period of time the enzyme gets adsorbed on the matrix .	4.559018411104042

It could not only be packed bed ; it could also be stirred reactor in which the enzyme is added and the enzyme solution is allowed to be stirred along with the carrier and after a period of time when the supernatant enzyme activity has come to minimum value you stop the process .	4.728827577659502

In all these methods which we are talking about , the final step is washing because very often you will have that some of the enzyme will be adhering to the surface of the particles which is not really immobilized in the proper sense .	5.269882211875516

It is not adsorbed ; some adhering along with the liquid and so fresh wash of the buffer at a particular pH should be given so that all the adhering enzyme is washed out and only that which is physically bound by adsorption is retained by the carrier .	3.8607483253690207

The final washing in the case of reactor loading process is done with the substrate solution itself because during the operation it has to meet the environmental conditions which are provided by the substrate solution , the feed .	5.097498990910948

Under those conditions it must remain adsorbed and so the final washing in the case of a reactor loading method is provided by the feed substrate itself so that whatever desorption has to take place under feed substrate condition , takes place and the enzyme is in the stable form .	4.276666229023634

The fourth method is electrodeposition process in which the carrier is placed in proximity to one of the electrodes and the current is applied between the two electrodes and the enzyme particles which are charged usually they get deposited on the carrier particles and at the end the carrier is removed which gets coated by the enzyme particle .	5.332322332704337

One thing we have to keep in mind , a very important feature that during the electro chemical process there will be certain ions which will be removed from the electrodes or from the process .	5.184589688454465

If the ions are important for enzyme activity then they must be provided in the electrolyte itself .	4.600278392726648

Extra quantity of those will be provided in the electrolyte otherwise you will not be having a functional enzyme preparation in the immobilized form .	4.530091132272854

The last method based on the adsorption process is by inorganic bridge formation as I mentioned or metal salt linkage .	4.618518846828614

This was originally developed by British group Barker , Emery and Novais , one of the references I have sited here , in seventy one .	4.027236408261612

It involves the metal salt linkage .	6.017240877624875

The basic principle of the method is the method employs transition metal salts like titanium tetrachloride , zirconium tetrachloride or ferric chloride for linking an enzyme to the carrier .	3.630441224273892

Carriers are usually cellulose , nylon , glass beads etc .	6.093891275984354

If you put cellulose into it , it might get degraded totally .	5.185892798609762

So the time of contact is very important and it is not used mostly more than five minutes and if you take a dilute solution probably you can go higher , followed by filtering and drying of complex at 45ºC .	4.986806516529547

Excess unreacted salt is washed with buffer .	7.741185286766664

The activated carrier is then stirred with the buffered enzyme solution followed by washing of the unbound enzyme .	3.9322642312076104

The method is very simple and involves two steps , activation of the matrix by steeping it in a transition metal salt solution whereby the transition metal salts form an octahedral complex .	4.275468723119473

The chemistry of that can be considered like this .	10.215126425120854

Titanium tetra chloride will exist in different forms and the complexes will be either dominated by water molecules as the ligand in the octahedral complex form .	3.9080150897029946

The titanium tetra chloride solution will exist in different forms complexed with certain ligands .	4.610977024230439

For example in solution water molecule will be present as the ligand and will complex with water and chloride ions .	4.660027837777303

In aqueous form titanium has five water molecules and one chloride .	5.4015978293620535

So when this solution is brought in contact with the matrix , any carbohydrate matrix , cellulose has been a very commonly used matrix , then what happens is that these ligands are replaced by the hydroxyl groups present on the carbohydrate molecule .	3.5714306408450915

One of the major advantages is that you always end up having a distance between the carrier surface and the enzyme molecules .	4.344716225375835

Therefore enzyme molecules and the carrier surface are separated by these linkages , the metal salt linkages .	6.16242133424279

The second major advantage which has been noted in these cases is that if you use a regenerated carrier after the enzyme has been leached out , you again immobilize the enzyme on the regenerated carrier .	4.601195938926634

Now , let us discuss few features of Ziegler - Natta polymerization which is the mechanism , we just talked about the monometallic mechanism .	5.267830244656058

We all talked about that .	11.096956820027842

Let me just summarize one more time the features .	7.018036625001634

So , in this case there is a vacant d - rbital , which is available for complexation with the incoming monomer .	4.130187024709487
