Today we will be talking about the role of effector molecules in the kinetics of enzyme catalyzed reactions .	4.215146253817176

You will recall that so far we have seen the role substrate molecules play to influence the rate of an enzymatic reaction .	4.602265468112272

They bind with the enzyme and have dynamic complexes that ultimately break down to form the product .	5.551896710803076

Now this complex , enzyme substrate complex formation can be effected by a number of other external molecules which are not really directly the players in the enzyme reactions .	5.152918127573881

That means neither they are substrate may or may not be products and such molecules are called effector molecules .	4.501309487038967

Those molecules whose presence in a reaction mixture influences the rate of reaction , if it is in increasing the rate of reaction we call them as activators if it is decreasing the reaction rate , we call them inhibitors .	6.208479696323459

The role of these molecules is very important in the kinetics of enzyme catalyzed reactions for certain reasons .	5.547521536182371

One is that they give you a picture on the reaction rate in the presence of those molecules .	5.70938490937746

You can regulate the reaction rate to an enhanced value or to a decreased value in the presence of those molecules .	4.897159096554761

In fact in the living cells also these molecules provide a regulatory device to control the rate of reaction .	4.323597984126906

We will see when we go on subsequently how many of the molecules control the rate of reaction by inhibiting or activating a particular enzyme in the beginning of a metabolic pathway .	5.55128517197966

Most of the information on the architecture of the active sites , which are the functional groups that are present on the active sites or the mechanism of the specificity , has resulted from the understanding of the interaction of inhibitor molecules or activator molecules in the enzyme catalyzed reactions .	4.86733857309017

Particularly in the case of multisubstrate reactions which we will be dealing subsequently where more than one substrate molecule takes part in the enzyme catalyzed reaction their kinetic mechanism is also understood by the role of certain external effector molecules .	5.023583990598263

That is another major advantage .	6.795391073873245

So these are the issues that provide us a very important understanding towards the role of effector molecules .	4.486497171395945

But even on the practical aspect probably from the industrial aspect also effector molecules are very important because in large number of drugs and the preservatives that are used commercially they basically work on the principle of modulating the enzyme reaction rate .	4.010611603190629

We are aware of many of the sulphur drugs .	7.123586183198283

In fact all the sulphur drugs are basically inhibitors of one or the other enzyme operating in the living system .	4.1600248198870045

The only care that is taken in designing a drug is that the particular molecule which acts as an inhibitor for a particular toxic substance or let us say for an infection should not be toxic to the human beings .	4.604850779854346

Most of the materials that we use , whether they are sulphur drugs or antibiotics , they are inhibitors or activators of certain enzymes .	3.693809950956123

So from that point of view , understanding their interaction is quite important .	5.627588904951905

Activators are molecules , as name suggest , that enhance the rate of enzyme catalyzed reactions .	5.445592125972422

Some of the activator molecules may be absolutely essential for a given enzyme reaction .	5.057346534700125

Some may not be so .	11.251417690238693

They may only provide stability to enzyme substrate complex .	4.7090139027326625

Therefore the nature of activator molecules might differ from case to case .	5.71375201051612

Typical examples of some of the activators are for example in the case of alpha amylase , calcium ions act as activators which is known to stabilize the enzyme substrate complex .	4.642504222338945

In the absence of calcium ions , the enzyme substrate complex is not very stable or the dissociation constant of enzyme substrate complex is relatively high and therefore the rate of reaction will be very , very slow .	4.961040236951121

That is another example of an absolute requirement of an activator .	5.435611854527964

In the absence of magnesium ions the enzyme will not be functionally catalytically active and therefore these activators function by participating or facilitating in either enzyme substrate binding or in stabilizing the enzyme substrate complex .	4.001737377927931

The difference between cofactors and activators is a cofactor will have to participate in the catalytic mechanism .	4.309338454540222

Take for example a cofactor like a NAD .	5.896741310388261

It is used in the oxidation reduction reactions and in the absence of any such residue in the active site which can participate in the oxidation reduction reaction , the NAD provides a molecule which undergoes redox reaction and therefore catalyzes the reaction .	4.419314923287261

It also plays a role in substrate binding and the role of cofactor is absolutely essential .	5.486267614395506

The reaction cannot take place in the absence of cofactor whereas in the case of activator we are only enhancing the rate .	5.1455839495420665

The rate may not come to zero .	7.4459409299883035

It might have a very small insignificant rate in the absence of an activator and in the presence , the rate might enhance .	7.54047972617861

Mg2 + is an absolute requirement .	14.264016816708956

So it falls in the category of both actually .	6.33098717804738

It also participates in the catalytic mechanism .	6.269132937906688

True example of activators will be calcium ions which do not take part in the catalytic function but provides stability to enzyme substrate complex .	4.296681866198852

That means binding process is facilitated .	7.902924740082252

So magnesium is something on interface .	8.62718872473573

Looking at activators from the mechanistic point of view , the role of activators can be considered as binding to the enzyme molecule to give you an activated enzyme .	5.327484204611101

When the activator molecule binds to it , the EA complex becomes an active enzyme complex .	5.224835809880803

This EA complex will bind with the substrate which is the active enzyme substrate complex .	8.868637095287573

This enzyme substrate complex can break down to the active enzyme plus product with k1 , k - 1 and k2 .	5.396797674077855

If we consider that the dissociation constant of activator binding to the enzyme is Ka , then in that case the rate of such reaction can be expressed as Vi = Vm .S Km { 1 + Ka / A } + S You ultimately end up in a rate expression in which the Km term is modified .	5.359039275831652

This can be written as Vm .	7.263278034104505

One can also see that the modified Km value is Km ’ = Km { 1 + Ka / A } That is when A becomes very , very large the activator concentration present in the reaction is much larger in comparison to Ka .	4.965126115065944

That means when we have sufficient quantity of activator present as required , the K ’ m approaches to that of intrinsic Km or K ’ m / Km = 1 .	4.897843099618681

Also when the activator is zero or when there is no activator present , the enzyme reaction will not take place because modified Km value will be too large .	5.5034031503957745

There will be no effective binding taking place and that means the secondary step will be ruled out .	4.895489266878556

Therefore the activator molecules can influence the reaction rate in an enzyme catalyzed process by this simple way to modify the Km value .	5.5047935472408875

The second category of effector molecules that we noted was inhibitors .	4.532942373405327

As the name suggests , these are those molecules which decrease the rate of an enzyme catalyzed reactions when present in the reaction mixture .	5.1979674409919125

They form complexes with enzyme molecule , enzyme substrate molecule , both or one of them .	5.018165720326911

They form dynamic complexes with the enzyme and enzyme substrate complexes and thereby influence the rate of reaction .	4.378209504127911

The inhibition patterns or inhibitors can be classified into two main classes .	4.794200735920167

One is irreversible inhibitors , which means that the inhibitor molecule binds to the enzyme in an irreversible fashion and cannot be recovered or revoked by physical operations .	4.543149845537034

Very often when into a reaction mixture if you have added an inhibitor molecule , one can remove it by physical method say for example by dialysis or ultra filtration or any of those methods .	4.859275935579392

But irreversible inhibitors cannot be removed once added to a reaction mixture and their effect is irreversible .	4.950713405088967

That means ultimately they will tend to reduce the rate of reaction and provide a poisonous effect on the rate of reaction .	4.972759826756823

In fact some times there are also called catalytic poisons because they irreversibly poison the catalyst .	3.9126857011488703

In most of the cases the effect is such that the reaction rate or catalytic function of the enzyme approaches to inactive form and thereby they cannot be used for catalytic functions .	5.717520692523678

Reversible inhibition is caused by chemical modification of one of the amino acids residues on the active site .	4.623623484245234

Most of the chemical modification reagents that are used for modification of the enzyme active sites do play a role in the irreversible inhibition .	5.508797355852033

Most of the alkylating agents will alkylate some of the amino acids residues and thereby make the enzyme inactive .	4.380379301729478

Many of the heavy metals like mercury or some of the poisonous gases also have the same action of irreversible inhibition whereby saving the person become difficult .	3.9455813839630065

The role of irreversible inhibitors can be expressed as ki kin E + I EI Einac k - i The first step shows a reversible process but the process doesn ’ t stop here .	3.565001029970125

Once EI is formed it goes into an inactive first order irreversible step which inactivates the enzyme and the concentration of EI at any given time can be expressed as EI = ( E0 - EI ) .I / ki where ki is the dissociation constant for the inhibitor and then one can write the inactivation rate as Vi = Kin [ EI ] = kin E0 / 1 + ki / I Therefore if I is in excess , if the magnitude of inhibitor is in excess , such that you can consider that there is a constant , then the whole expression is a first order rate constant that is kd.E0 where kd a first order rate constant assuming that I is in excess and can be considered as constant .	4.466564532083973

Such reactions are very often noted to be poisonous in nature .	5.77676075743439

Most of the substances that are technically called poisons whether it is mercury or cyanide or nerve gas and things like that they all behave in the form of irreversible inhibitors .	3.7535217055298733

Except to understand their role to evolve methods to prevent the poisoning they don ’ t have much of industrial value .	4.938141380241149

It is mostly reversible inhibitors which play a key role in most of the industrial processes .	5.327665873696787

In the second category of reversible inhibitors , the inhibitor binds to the enzyme in a reversible manner .	4.412639876230126

That means after the addition of the inhibitor to an enzyme substrate mixture one can physically remove it .	5.234677441019773

The physical methods most commonly used are ultra filtration or dialysis such that the enzyme is fully restored to its initial activity .	4.747769855264803

In the presence of inhibitor their activity will be decreased but once you remove it physically , the original activity of the enzyme is recovered .	5.153427584418722

In a sense these molecules make dynamic complexes with the enzyme which have different catalytic properties to that of the native enzyme .	4.900836829500644

Different inhibitor molecules bind differently to the enzyme molecule or enzyme substrate complex such that the catalytic properties are altered and thereby the rate of reaction is altered .	5.847261271507394

Our total orientation to study the inhibitors will be mostly directed towards the understanding the reversible inhibition .	4.451606104411852

There are certain general patterns which we follow in studying reversible inhibition and before we go to the individual cases I like to highlight that .	3.8862299330006214

The first thing that we must look at is the pattern of binding of inhibitor to enzyme or enzyme substrate complex .	4.7912350467519

How does a particular group of inhibitors bind to the enzyme molecules ?	5.964393437535421

You are proposing an operational reaction mechanism which may be slightly different than that proposed by Michaelis Menten or others earlier as we discussed and that mechanism need to be understood very clearly and that will give you a physical picture of the enzyme substrate binding .	4.5181894738790485

The second thing is , on the basis of this binding process you develop a rate expression .	4.656375009265763

We always tend to compare a rate of expression with that of Michaelis Menten rate expression .	6.584964301528223

Then look at the effect of the inhibitor concentration on Km or Vm or both of the reaction .	6.349280964503067

First we have looked at the binding pattern .	7.923266854244058

Based on the binding pattern , we develop a rate expression compare it to the Michaelis Menten equation and see how the Km and Vm of the native enzyme are influenced by the presence of inhibitors .	4.914943000610898

Then we see the effect on Lineweaver Burk plot .	7.698632178633944

That is another basic expression of kinetic behavior in the case of enzyme catalyzed reaction .	4.661666575570427

If a double reciprocal plot is plotted between 1 / S and 1 / V as a function of inhibitor concentration how does this represent ?	4.80071306676394

Fifthly another important pattern is for each class of inhibition , there is degree of inhibition .	5.0661573029407645

That means we define a term degree of inhibition called i which is nothing but v0 - vi / v0 .	5.116512511636428

If v0 is the rate of uninhibited reaction , classically Michaelis Menten kinetics , and vi is the rate expression for inhibited reaction , the degree of inhibition that is produced by the presence of inhibitor is obtained even from a theoretical rate expression .	5.082140580307858

You can work out an expression for degree of inhibition and that will have a characteristic pattern which can distinguish a particular type of a reversible inhibition .	5.314439323232269

All other reversible inhibition studies will be based on these five approaches in general .	5.1429721218684

Probably one of the simplest and the most commonly encountered pattern of reversible inhibition is what we know as competitive inhibition .	6.165294491843697

As the name suggests , competitive inhibitor combines with the free enzyme on the same site which is the substrate binding site and therefore the inhibitor competes for the binding site with the substrate .	5.312651784378937

Usually both inhibitor and substrate molecules are mutually exclusive and compete with each other .	4.54351807925421

The inhibitor binding site on the enzyme molecule and substrate binding site on the enzyme molecule are identical .	5.046600423602741

This should be taken in a very broad sense .	10.02376445493558

It is not always necessary that the binding site has to be exactly the same as that of substrate .	5.971417741897498

The purpose is that the presence of inhibitor makes the binding of the substrate difficult in a competitive mode .	5.223452941574243

That means the proximity may be such that the inhibitor molecule has such a confirmation that the original binding site is disturbed and substrate binding is not feasible or alternatively after binding of the inhibitor molecule the substrate binding site might be modified in such a way that substrate binding is not feasible .	3.7772691959122446

All those cases , variety of cases will come under the category of competitive inhibition and the purpose is that the presence of inhibitor must reduce because reversible inhibition depends on the concentrations of the two species , inhibitor and substrate and they will affect the binding mechanism .	4.5133908092051

A very typical example and probably the most easily understood example is of oxidation of succinic acid to fumaric acid .	3.984005241562184

This is inhibited by a molecule closely resembling the substrate , malonic acid which has two carboxyl groups but only one methyl group , unlike succinic acid .	3.7417532419093167

It is very similar in confirmation and very often enzyme active site mistakes it for succinic acid and therefore it acts as a competitive inhibitor in the same reaction .	4.959798871915732

It acts as a competitive inhibitor for folic acid biosynthesis from para amino benzoic acid .	3.556086224927355

The amino group on the aromatic ring is identical in both the molecules .	6.042638919899999

This is sulfanilamide and this is para amino benzoic acid .	6.095412010667012

This para amino benzoic acid is the starting substrate for synthesis of folic acid .	4.747495569404331

So to summarize the competitive inhibition , we must notice that the inhibitor molecule binds to an enzyme molecule at a site either on the same side which is ear marked for substrate molecule or at a site in proximity to it in such a way that it interferes or restricts the binding of the substrate molecule onto the enzyme site and therefore it competes for the binding process on the enzyme molecule .	4.109058023064554

There is no binding of the inhibitor molecule with the enzyme substrate molecule once the substrate molecule has bound to the enzyme , the inhibitor is ineffective .	6.9167347419130225

That means the total enzyme concentration is distributed between inhibitor and substrate and that is one .	5.921362752608271

Second thing is the enzyme catalyzed reaction in the presence of a competitive inhibitor results in an increased km value and the Vm value is totally not affected .	5.351196463032462

Third thing is that the effect of the competitive inhibitor can be successfully overcome to a significant extent if you increase the substrate concentration to a very large value as compared to inhibitor concentration .	5.747948974098107

Because they are competing on the same side , if the concentration of substrate is much , much larger than inhibitor then the possibility of substrate molecule binding to enzyme is much more and once substrate molecule is bound the enzyme will no longer be available for inhibitor to act upon .	4.684841459576618

Today we shall discuss about the effect of immobilization on functional properties of the enzyme molecules .	5.914970464435164

We have seen a number of immobilization methods that we have discussed in previous classes .	5.819434118434694

We see that in most cases the enzyme undergoes loss of activity during immobilization .	5.81710749824486

In fact no method can ensure that you can recover the enzyme in hundred percent yield .	6.062857065067341

The yield can vary depending on the method of immobilization , depending on the carrier and the stability of the enzyme itself with respect to the conditions of immobilization .	4.981477396484616

By real I mean that you cannot recover , after the immobilization , the original enzyme activity by physical interventions .	5.616861181221884

On the other hand the apparent loss refers to the reduced enzyme activity that you are measuring but by certain physical interventions the original activity can be restored .	3.9013303245488644

It is not a permanent loss of activity but due to certain physical forces which make a interplay with the catalytic function , the enzyme activity seems apparently to have been lost .	4.383874636420557

The reasons for the two types of losses , the real and apparent , could be attributed to one or more of the following four factors that are listed here .	4.030309010427009

The first and foremost factor is the change in the enzyme conformation itself .	6.087461645898484

When the soluble enzyme is immobilized on to a matrix the interaction between the matrix and the enzyme amino acids might lead to certain conformational changes possibly due to the result of involvement of some of the amino acids residues in the immobilization process .	4.7311462726958124

Very often it has been noticed that a very common feature is that upon immobilization an enzyme may undergo some kind of unfolding ; some kind of a stretching .	4.623131330034812

There are no parameters which can be simply measured .	8.038066230710275

A detailed analysis or detailed study on the conformation , just like what we do as for identification of the globular structure the tertiary structure of the enzyme , one can study .	4.967760510222543

But other wise a quick quantitative measure of the conformational loss is only through measurement of enzyme activity .	4.7229813560245

For example here you see that this is a typical soluble enzyme shown here .	4.666867002620198

It has been immobilized on to a solid matrix by some bonds ; it could be an electrostatic bond ; it could be a metal salt linkage ; it could be covalent bond or it could also be as an entrapment within a gel .	4.4357218095470845

Entrapment within a gel fortunately does not involve the amino acids of the enzyme protein and therefore the chances of any conformational change during gel entrapment are minimum .	5.637200716946813

Then during immobilization , the enzyme may under go some conformational changes .	6.330545656483437

Just a hypothetical change I have shown here .	5.440852977429812

It could be in any shape .	8.203652721325586

It could be simply unfolding ; it could be some kind of stretching and it may lead to a totally inactive enzyme preparation or a reduced activity of an enzyme preparation .	4.994008050269357

Reduced activity means that the protein content will be reduced .	9.64518625261256

The specific activity of the enzyme that means the enzyme activity in terms of international units per milligram of protein might get reduced .	5.303367667725296

There have been certain exceptions .	7.958202176859414

I am saying exceptions which are rare examples where the enzyme activity after the immobilization has also been analyzed .	5.721032670499846

If the conformational changes are more favorable to the factors that are responsible for reduction in activation energy either by strain or any other mechanism that we discussed earlier by entropic or enthalpic changes which reduce the energy of activation for the enzyme catalyzed reaction , it might also lead to favorable conformational change .	4.1999299678670186

But those examples are indeed rare and not very common examples .	6.622410659338656

Then the second factor which is responsible for loss of enzyme activity is steric hindrance .	4.41651772524477

In many cases the immobilization process might involve the reduction in the access of the substrate molecule to the enzyme active site .	4.5576422530336504

You have achieved a good binding but the enzyme active sites are hindered from access to the substrate molecule .	4.747899527267071

A typical case is shown here .	6.552053586861638

In this case , the enzyme has been immobilized on sites which are in very great proximity to the active site and therefore the participation or the involvement of the substrate with the active sites is reduced and that also results in reduced enzyme activity .	4.787878159543069

However such a enzyme activity can be recovered or this phenomena can be reduced if you can use a proper choice of the method for immobilization .	5.090307934499183

In some of the cases the steric hindrances can be minimized by introduction of the spacer arm .	4.778051291576774

That means between the binding sites introduction of a spacer arm which is usually a hydrocarbon chain and which can make the binding more flexible and there by the steric hindrances can be reduced .	4.567793622656326

But in a particular method of immobilization the steric hindrance results in a definite loss of enzyme activity which is a real loss and cannot be recovered by physical methods .	4.822224551854842

For example if you have covalently bound an enzyme i.e. , by covalent bond depending on the method of binding if you have not involved a spacer arm the loss will remain there .	4.33334349040607

But you cannot recover that .	10.117336756664757

Unless you modify enzyme immobilization procedure whereby a spacer arm is introduced then you can reduce the steric hindrance .	4.565959026059713

The method can be modified to result in reduced loss as a result of steric hindrance .	4.757882903672844

But once a preparation has been made with a definite amount of steric hindrance , the loss is real .	4.98746864470752

The third factor which contributes to loss of enzyme activity is partitioning effect .	4.463003783798105

We must consider immobilized enzymes in the light of a shift from homogenous catalysis to heterogeneous catalysis .	4.1194021126928275

Instead of looking at the catalytic reaction in a homogenous phase where the catalyst is dissolved in the same medium as the reactant here the catalyst has a different phase - solid phase and the substrate is in the liquid phase .	5.076487756894005

You lead into a heterogeneous catalysis and the various species that are involved in the reaction , it could be a substrate ; it could be inhibitor ; it could be simple hydrogen ions which contribute to the pH ; they might get partitioned in the two phases depending on the chemical nature of the bulk and the carrier particles and this partition effect can also lead to an apparent loss of enzyme activity in a particular situation .	4.508275947831856

The fourth is the diffusional limitations .	6.82901572680478

A result of incorporation of a solid particle in a reaction mixture and particularly we consider a porous solid particle where most of the enzyme has been immobilized on the interior of the particle .	4.092176929222657

When a solid particle is immersed into a liquid phase there is also bound to be a stationary film of liquid around the particle .	4.473752208397715

This film thickness can vary depending on the physical properties of the substrate solution ; for example viscosity or density .	5.295783237163774

They may control the film thickness and these might call also a diffusional constraint particularly with respect to transport of the substrate from the bulk to the site of enzyme catalyzed reaction .	3.621865461381531

The two effects the partitioning effect and the mass transfer of the diffusional effect can be visualized here If you notice here for example in the right hand side diagram we have assumed a hypothetical carrier preparation which is poly anionic in nature .	4.512711515361507

That means it is highly negatively charged and an enzyme molecule is entrapped or located in the midst of negative charges .	3.9666633910804134

The total charge inside the carrier particle or around enzyme where the catalysis is going to take place will be different than in the bulk .	5.551699090089437

If in case the substrate also happens to be a charged molecule , so there will be some partitioning effects of the substrate between the bulk and so the real substrate concentration what we are considering in the bulk phase will not be same at the site of the enzyme reactions .	5.612798686857581

I will come to that .	5.526282846793059

I am just describing the right hand side one .	6.514159250041766

There could be very clear cut partitioning effects with respect to hydrogen ions because they are positively charged and a poly ionic carrier will definitely have preference for hydrogen ions .	4.056711518807299

Therefore the hydrogen ion concentration inside the carrier will be greater than the bulk .	5.4212456581892345

Similarly if the substrate is also positively charged you are going to have higher substrate concentration in the carrier or at the site of enzyme rather than the bulk or it could be the other way .	5.446224485433716

If suppose the substrate is also negatively charged the reverse might happen .	5.1646765744779

That means the bulk concentration vary more than at the site of the reaction .	4.406396873026518

That might lead to the apparent effect on the enzyme activity .	9.490065421556945

On the left hand side I have shown the diffusional effects .	4.964716355139178

In fact a very large percentage , more than ninety percent of the enzyme will be distributed on the porous network within the particle .	4.95268914865639

Only very small fraction will be on the surface and for the reaction to take place the substrate has to diffuse from the bulk to the site of the enzyme reaction .	4.8294781306469385

Here you notice that in the case of the immobilize enzyme unlike a soluble enzyme what we are conventionally used to where the enzyme is in direct proximity with the substrate and can interact and reaction can take place without any resistance other than the chemical reaction , the biochemical reaction .	4.844401421081272

Here in addition to biochemical reaction you have another limitation .	8.878661141857599

That means the bulk substrate has to diffuse through the stationary film which is on the surface of the particle .	4.149903600248183

This surface , they have a thickness delta on the basis of the physical properties of the substrate molecule and the carrier particle .	5.497053612040532

The thickness of the stationary film can be reduced by changing the flow properties in the reactor stream and as we will see further that the effect of thickness of the stationary film can be reduced if you increase the linear field velocity in a continuous reactor or increase agitation speed in a stirred vessel in a stirred reactor .	4.150392278646421

So you can reduce it .	10.23545472905048

But any way it has to transfer from the bulk phase to the stationary phase and their might be some concentration gradient in the substrate .	5.8546141627269614

From the surface , the substrate has to move to the enzyme active site and the enzyme is distributed all over the particle .	5.836487791744252

Depending on the particle thickness , let us say diameter of the particle is dp the substrate might be able to reach only up to a part of the carrier .	5.708330415070931

Let us say it reaches up to here .	6.056198898982694

The substrate value comes down to zero .	5.9897459640985975

This means that a fraction of the total enzyme available in the immobilize preparation is not able to interact with the substrate because of diffusion limitations .	4.71879607575461

This will depend on the relative rate of diffusion vis - à - vis , the rate of biochemical catalysis .	5.836669199733465

The slower rate will dominate the effect .	7.888702287285569

If suppose the biochemical reaction rate is very fast compared to rate of diffusion of the substrate into the carrier particle , it might happen that soon after the surface of the catalyst particle the substrate concentration might drop to a very small level or even to zero depending on the rate of diffusion which is smaller than that .	5.43006466427989

So in case of enzyme reactions where enzymes have a very high activity or in other words a few are able to make a preparation which has a very high enzyme loading that means the amount of enzymes in terms of international units per gram of the carrier particle if that can be increased to a significant level , then the system can be operated which is under diffusion limitations .	4.770588458944799

If you are able to prepare an immobilize enzyme preparation with a very high enzyme loading that means the catalytic rate is very high .	4.118093577183239

Enzyme loading high means the catalytic rate will be very high because the enzyme activity in terms of international units , the reaction rate per unit weight of the carrier , if that is very high compared to the rate of diffusion then the whole system can be conceived to be totally diffusion limited .	5.634480300647935

The biochemical reaction kinetics will not have a major role to play and the whole thing will be controlled by the physical diffusion .	5.413298771461424

I have told you two kinds of effect of diffusion .	6.115973658957361

One is the external film diffusion .	5.89176044594061

The other is the diffusional limitations caused by the boundary layer film , inert film on the boundary as external film diffusion .	3.6961033994385235

On the other hand , the diffusional process within the pores of the particle or internal pore diffusion .	3.131843243425165

The two types of diffusion , we will subsequently see their quantitative analysis in relation to the biochemical reaction but we shall understand that these two processes will put you four additional resistances over and above the biochemical reaction .	3.6478522257091193

Ultimately for all practical purposes our measurements or monitoring will be in the bulk .	5.508963299877247

So the product has to also transport and it might also undergo a kind of a gradient .	5.218306764666008

Just to illustrate a little more detail on the transport behavior consider a typical spherical particle with an external film shown here .	3.658837206880739

This is substrate concentration .	12.414986643968662

“a ” is shown as substrate concentration at the bulk phase , that means at the entry of the boundary layer .	4.80962632330875

There will be a gradient of substrate in the boundary layer .	6.572227370777317

This gradient will depend on the thickness of the boundary layer and you can minimize this by increasing a very high agitation speed in the stirred reactor or increase a very high linear flow velocity in a continuous reactor .	4.490258915264106

There is a reduction but in the internal porous structure the substrate concentration may undergo also a gradient .	5.601450319377979

This gradient it might so happen that it comes down to zero .	4.62029482104325

The substrate concentration comes down to zero at this point and therefore all the enzyme present in this phase is not available and apparently it will look as if there is an enzyme activity loss .	5.408328327043919

So the enzyme activity loss as a result of diffusional limitations is a totally apparent loss .	6.176610871060165

If you reduce the particle size to the extent that the rate of diffusion is enough to counter or enough to take the substrate up to the interior of the particle .	3.832247018599409

That means if you can reduce the particle let us say if this particle was only of this much size and this is the center , then it could happen that the enzyme might reach up to the center of the particle .	4.579726400131759

The substrate might reach at the centre of the particle and all the particle is interacting with the substrate .	5.357060907851452

So there is no activity loss and that is what really I meant by the apparent loss of the enzyme activity that means by some physical interventions , by reducing the particle size one can overcome the internal pore diffusion .	4.073250979064956

Similarly by increasing the agitation speed in the stirred vessel one can reduce or totally reduce the thickness of the film and thereby the gradient on the external film diffusion can be minimized .	3.677695628829726

In the part b and c , you notice the combined effect of partitioning and diffusion .	4.883417471805615

You see here in the bulk phase , the part b shows that in the carrier particle the diffusional limitations are not very high .	6.138724590705518

Although there is a very , very mild concentration gradient , the substrate is present all through the carrier particle .	6.0211994052082565

But the concentration of the substrate in the carrier is higher than the bulk .	7.035292912000368

So there is a partitioning effect .	5.609823151485106

That means the chemical nature of the carrier has more affinity for the substrate than the bulk .	5.190051143560241

In the c part the reverse is there .	7.431464939663711

The substrate has lower affinity that means suddenly from this boundary surface the concentration drops and there is a partitioning .	4.63578225060807

So these pictures shows the first one is totally diffusion ; the b and c part indicate the combined effect of diffusion and partitioning .	4.2475308771758336

These are the four major parameters or the factors which cause the various effects on the functional properties of the enzymatic reaction .	4.453919238426899

Whenever we have to look at any particular feature of an immobilized enzyme reaction , we have to look into these four effects and try to find an answer to the observed behavior .	5.0326282325431695

Let us look at some of them .	7.386692178805911

The first is effect of pH .	8.97349745813819

Very often we look at enzyme catalyzed reaction unknown to have an optimum pH and particularly in the case of immobilization by ionic binding it has been noted that there is an apparent shift in the optimum pH .	4.953316193832825

When you take a soluble enzyme , a native enzyme and determine its optimum pH as against the optimum pH of an immobilized preparation you find that the optimum pH has shifted and this shift is attributed mainly to the partitioning of hydrogen ions between bulk and the carrier particles .	4.281763600058065

That means the partitioning effect of the hydrogen ions between the bulk and the carrier particle depends on the nature of charge .	4.90815820657644

If suppose the carrier is negatively charged , there will be higher concentration of the hydrogen ions compared to the bulk and vice versa and therefore in the case of a negatively charged carrier , the apparent shift in pH will be on the alkaline side .	5.046078277287253

Because for the higher pH in the bulk the actual pH in the carrier particle will be lower .	5.863610821311119

Hydrogen ion concentration is more in the carrier .	11.266276580744211

So there will be apparent shift in the pH optimum because what we are considering we are not varying the pH in the carrier particle ; we are varying the bulk pH .	5.12404369749336

So at even a higher bulk pH at the enzyme reactive site the pH will be lower and so we will consider it almost like an apparent shift in the optimum pH on the alkaline side and the reverse is true .	4.528048166662882

If suppose you take a polycationic carrier , the shift will be on the acidic side .	5.459447237746121

The second effect of pH is on pH stability ; the same thing , the same partitioning effect .	5.249312115911605

Particularly in some cases of the enzymes which are known to be more stable under alkaline side or acidic side , an immobilization can lead to increased or decreased stability of the enzyme depending on their behavior , although the pH stability as well as optimum pH in the real sense at the molecular level does not change .	4.287426783108944

The behavior remains the same .	9.523754391414448

It ’ s only an apparent change in the monitoring system because we are measuring in the bulk and therefore the two effects are noted .	5.6943259516797875

If you consider the stability fact of the enzyme with respect to pH certain enzymes are more stable under alkaline conditions .	4.303323805583741

So the immobilization to an anionic polymer will be able to give you a more stable preparation with respect to pH .	5.215289825664867

I am talking of stability with respect to pH and not thermal .	5.147382015286141

There will be no effect on thermal as a partitioning effect .	5.23225725555562

But there will be some effect on the pH stability because the pH what you are offering to the enzyme particle in the bulk is not the same at the enzyme active site .	6.084399700650346

It is reduced and if it is less stable at the alkaline pH , then even at the higher pH the enzyme particle may show higher pH stability .	4.921986323926399

Right . They are the same .	16.322114959137405

The physical reason which attributes to both the effects is identical .	4.8802467146850805

That is partitioning of the hydrogen ions between the bulk and the carrier particle .	3.7562745288800614

As an example if you look at some of the optimum pH of the immobilized preparations , which are reported in literature you notice that in most cases here the effects are mostly on ionic binding .	5.124134060671287

But the pH effects are noted on a minor site in cases of gel entrapment and non - specific binding and particularly crosslinking effects also .	4.209355905530619

But they may be a result of a very complex system which cannot be defined very accurately but ionic binding can be defined very accurately .	5.3320411576391935

In trypsin by binding on to DEAE Sephadex the free enzyme pH which was 8.5 was reduced to 7.0 .	5.126595340026148

Similarly on invertase DEAE cellulose , 5.4 to 3.3 , the immobilized enzyme optimum pH is reduced .	6.205467593248863

Yes . Diethylaminoethylether has lot of amino groups with positively charged matrix and therefore the enzyme activity is reversed .	5.289479509616087

On the other hand look at an example here on physical absorption on bentonite .	3.743638292471648

Bentonite is clay with high negative charge and this attributes to an increase in the optimum pH .	5.075568709452127

Some optimum pH changes have also been reported in the case of crosslinking but their effect of change in the optimum pH is a result of some other conformational interactions and not due to partitioning .	5.034428821629257

Particularly the last example of the immobilization of NADH hydrogenase by crosslinking also indicates the shift of the optimum pH but here the optimum pH shift will not be attributed to partitioning effect .	5.119224757571105

It could be due to some of the conformational changes as a result of crosslinking because conformational changes also can bring in some change in the optimum pH .	4.156128129704929

A quantitative analysis of the partitioning effect can be given in terms of a factor what we can call the partitioning coefficient , the partition factor which is the ratio of concentration of any specie on the enzyme active site divided by the concentration in the bulk If you consider the pH effects or hydrogen ion concentration it can be described in the two phases .	5.953080998682772

That means at the solid phase in the enzyme active site and in the bulk phase by Boltzmann type of distribution where you can give the concentration in the enzyme phase that is in the carrier matrix given by H + E = H + B exp ( - e ?	5.496475707509107

I must give you an example of glucose isomerase .	8.155630569867704

Glucose isomerase , some of the native enzymes have a pH optimum of about 7.5 - 8 , alkaline .	7.155372614264021

An alkaline pH for isomerisation of glucose is not a desirable feature because it will undergo a lot of non - specific , non - catalytic , non - enzymatic reactions on glucose isomerisation producing products other than fructose .	4.3746902168437725

A very significant property of apparent change in the enzyme optimum pH has bee used by immobilizing those enzymes to a positively charged matrix .	4.064129502976308

You can use the enzyme in the bulk lower pH although the actual pH of the active site will be same 7.5 or 8 whatever is the optimum pH of the native enzyme .	5.033829512212677

But if the reaction can be carried out at a pH in the bulk which is lower , the side reactions can be totally overcome .	6.360295301718884

So that gives you another major advantage for using an immobilized preparation .	4.891797092126565

The other effect of this immobilization is on the kinetic parameters .	5.7658046782176235

Can kinetic parameters also undergo some apparent change ?	7.192848991261633

Although the kinetic parameters of the enzymes does not change in the real sense but there are apparent changes in the kinetic parameters .	5.674867927401171

First we consider the km , the Michaelis Menten constant .	7.205379262975084

In most cases you will notice , if you look into literature , that the km value undergo a change .	5.409889861120531

The changes can be of various nature .	8.542479295100891

Different methods have yielded increase in km value , decrease in km value and sometimes no change in km also .	4.889321592100455

The change in km value can be attributed to diffusional limitations as well as partitioning of substrate .	5.64252969370059

Very often wherever the substrate is also a charged molecule similar partitioning effect will take place .	5.1822844239408274

There will be a difference in the substrate concentration between the bulk and the enzyme active site as we saw in the substrate profile of the immobilized enzyme particle that in the bulk phase and in the immobilized carrier particle , there will be a substrate gradient and depending on the chemical nature that will undergo and kappm can also be related to km of the native enzyme by kappm = kmez.e. ?	4.866354787983138

/ kt where z is the number of charges .	8.250778159469524

It ’ s an observed change .	8.418569828762301

…… does not change really ; on the on the substrate if we consider the charges on the substrate .	7.21932468483103

The second reason for the apparent change in km would be attributed to diffusional limitations .	4.142015783489716

The effects due to diffusional limitations on km have been clearly demonstrated by experimental data because if you just use an immobilized enzyme preparation in a reactor and measure km by reducing the particle size you are able to come to a km value which is of the native enzyme which only implies that the diffusional limitations are playing a role .	4.033857044609247

One of the result reports the km value of the immobilized glucoamylase on different substrates : soluble starch , amylopectin , amylose and maltose ; four different substrates which can be acted upon by glucoamylase or amyloglucosidase .	3.9259655868040726

For the free enzyme the km values are given here on the left hand side .	4.860617655084196

For the immobilized enzyme you see the km values have significantly increased except on maltose where it has decreased .	5.43687521408064

This also gives you the feature that the molecular weight of the substrate can also influence the partitioning effect because the maltose being the smallest molecular weight molecule substrate here , it can easily and freely pass through a carrier particle and thereby one can achieve a much higher km value compared to the insoluble one .	4.803533982583458

km in the case of maltose has decreased .	10.320226539368193

It has decreased means higher affinity ; the concentration of the substrate in the enzyme active site is much higher .	5.551238228234543

So it affects particularly high molecular weights substrates and they behave in a reverse way .	5.1057611419252495

This has to be taken care while preparing the immobilized enzyme preparation so that the km value does not increase because otherwise it will lead to a less sufficient catalysis .	4.604879535921072

Another data is on the influence of particle size on the Michaelis constant of immobilized enzyme .	6.157504598814186

If you look at soluble starch as substrate as a function of particle size , particle size being in micro meters the km value increases as the particle size increases .	4.356235725690718

For example roughly about two fold increase causes 19.3 grams per liter to 31.6 , a very significant increase in km value .	4.675163862785598

Similarly on the external film diffusion also the linear velocity of the immobilized glucoamylase using the 30 % weight by weight 40DE corn syrup , the data here are important in the case of starch syrup because starch syrup when we use for hydrolysis we use a very thick syrup .	4.1327451287819965

Even in the case of glucose isomerase when we carry out the industrial reactions , the substrate concentration which is used is about 2.5 - 3 molar glucose which means almost about 45 - 50 % weight by volume .	5.033984264951531

So it is very thick syrup and at such thick syrup , the boundary film can be very thick .	4.723910899739367

The film thickness can be very high and external film diffusion in those cases where we use substrates as very thick syrup is usually very high and external film also becomes a major parameter and as shown here if you consider a packed bag reactor with a liner flow velocity from 0.85cm / min to almost as high as 14.5 almost twenty fold increase gives you a km value which decreases from 7.76 to 3.79 almost half the initial value of km .	3.9532010167774922

That means if you are able to overcome external film diffusion the increase in linear velocity means you are reducing the thickness of the boundary film and that ’ s why when we talk of km we are talking only apparent change and not the real change .	4.79516735585771

The other parameter which is important in the case of kinetic parameter is change in k2 that is the turn over number or in other words you can say if you multiply with the enzyme concentration it becomes Vm¬ .	4.816075502052593

Enzyme k2 change is solely attributed to conformational changes .	5.373490907881936

That is if the enzyme undergoes a conformational change its specific activity will undergo a change .	4.5202061483968965

In some cases the change has been favorable .	6.026035330511508

There have been reports , although rare not very common , that the enzyme activity increases as a consequence of immobilization .	5.2434161042734635

Another functional parameter is temperature which is important for all catalyzed reactions .	6.9278733358430316

Just like optimum pH , we also need an optimum temperature for a reaction which is known for a native enzyme .	5.466450833107406

In many cases there has been report in the change in the optimum temperature also .	4.82149347767159

The change in the optimum temperature is a result of temperature gradient across the bulk and the enzyme particle and this is very prominent when you talk of gel entrapped enzyme preparation .	6.421085473087209

The gel acts almost like a thermal insulating material and therefore the temperature at this site is relatively much less as compared to the bulk temperature and therefore apparently the apparent optimum temperature will be higher than what is required .	4.896750031532983

At the active site it is the real optimum temperature but in the bulk it is slightly higher because there is a gradient of temperature between the bulk .	6.783134108020747

Optimum temperature has also been attributed to conformational changes particularly in the case of adsorbed enzyme preparation or covalently coupled preparations where there is no likelihood of any temperature or you can even notice the temperature changes in the case of a non - porous matrix where all the enzyme is just immobilized on the surface of the matrix .	4.342414029954988

There is no porous network and in those cases if there is optimum temperature change it is attributed to conformational change and diffusional effects are also very prominent with respect to temperature effects mainly because the diffusion itself is a process which is very significantly affected by temperature .	4.421084787344109

In fact the diffusion process is much more sensitive to temperature effects than many of the catalytic reaction rates .	6.15953001553711

The rate of diffusion can be enhanced significantly as a result of increase in temperature and particularly in the case where the system is diffusion controlled the temperature optimum might undergo significant change .	4.797983625280322

In the case of enzymes which are immobilized by carrier binding methods , for example , either by adsorption or by covalent binding where there are no there are no likelihood of much temperatures gradient in the bulk and the enzyme active site this can be very easily checked .	4.656152236460187

In case if you consider a non - porous matrix where all the enzyme is supposed to be on the surface there is no porous network .	5.532634851726352

In those cases the change in the optimum temperature will be attributed to conformational effects only because there is no chance of any diffusional effects .	4.027501575969356

There is no chance of any temperature gradient .	5.011663770532095

In different cases different kinds of changes in optimum temperature have been noticed .	5.271186537162858

Then the second parameter which is affected by the temperature is the energy of activation .	4.951059080004146

The effect of temperature on reaction rate gives you a parameter activation energy and which is considered also to be a characteristic parameter for any chemical reaction and in the case of activation energy the major reason , the contributing factor is the diffusional limitations that is the rate of diffusion because as I mentioned that the diffusion process itself is highly sensitive to temperature and the activation energy in the case of immobilized enzyme preparation is a net resultant of the two temperature dependent processes the chemical reaction and the diffusion .	5.145027720845558

So the net effect of the temperature on the overall reaction rate which is a combined parameter between the rate of diffusion and the rate of reaction can be different than the native enzyme because there is no diffusional limitation .	4.676988797017778

There is increase in activation energy there are reports on decrease in activation energy .	4.836785860545521

But one parameter what is understood as storage stability which is attributed to the thermal deactivation of the enzyme with time is always favorable in the case of immobilized enzyme preparation mainly because of the additional intermolecular forces and the intermolecular forces that are involved which keep the process of deactivation to a minimum .	4.601004135538826

In almost all cases of the immobilized preparation the storage stability has noted to be higher in terms of its half life .	6.20332707595578

So that is almost a proven fact and that is one advantage we have to take of immobilized enzyme for all operational purposes .	5.581874919840432

Take an example of optimum temperature of various immobilized invertases .	7.673002465584266

As you notice here the native invertase has the optimum temperature of 55ºC and by immobilized preparation by different methods or like physical adsorption on activated carbon is 40ºC , ionic binding to DEAE cellulose is 30ºC which is a very significant change .	3.8499456521713014

As I mentioned some time earlier also that the adsorption process undergoes slight unfolding of the enzyme protein and unfolding of the enzyme protein is an endothermic process which results in reduction in the optimum temperature ; alkylation by covalent binding is 45ºC , entrapment is 50ºC .	4.0632419213563775

Here entrapment is solely as a result of insulation effect , the temperature gradient .	6.163599890729931

In the case of gradient , but here that means there is some conformational change also occurring .	4.050992921507692

There are some minor conformational changes but not as high as alkylation or ionic binding but there is some conformational change also occurring .	3.405132321512946

In fact optimum temperature should be higher than entrapment if it is solely by temperature gradient .	5.6365661473780895

No . I am not talking about the stability .	11.68312383471712

I am talking of the initial reaction rate as a function of temperature ; not stability .	4.573998485234863

Look at the data on the activation energy of various immobilized aminoacylases .	6.445674073586418

I will come to operational stability a little later .	5.028281963749057

As you will notice that in both the types of behavior there is a significant increase on DEAE - cellulose by ionic binding or DEAE - Sephadex slightly less increase but on covalent binding there is decrease in activation energy and these change in the activation energy is a resultant sum total of the diffusional effects and the biochemical reactions and the entrapment in polyacrylamide also results in decrease in the activation energy .	3.945621478804738

Why ? It should decrease .	14.096146793303042

Finally the most important parameter which we are concerned within the case of immobilized enzyme is their use in continuous reactors or long term reactions whether we can use them in a stirred vessel or in a packed bed or in a ……… reactors or a variety of reactor configuration that are known to us from chemical reaction engineering and we can see that the parameter which is most important to look at the immobilized enzyme preparation property is operational stability that over a period of time when we use it , it should remain stable .	5.002825424810126

And in case of by the mechanism which you can synthesize polymer you can divide polymer into two classes by step polymerization or by chain growth polymerization .	5.336585209962517

Now , if you remember from the last lecture that in in case of chain growth polymers , the monomers are not started the polymerization reaction by itself , you need to have external agent which will initiate the polymer chain and once the chain starts , monomer can add one after one and thus completing the chain quickly .	4.879448232824102

And in this case we have seen or we have discussed in last lecture that the rate of initiation is typically much lower compared to the rate at which the chain propagates and completes .	5.456912067368261

Now , in case of step growth polymerization , we also talked about that you know you typically have a monomer react with monomer at the beginning gives you a dimer .	5.930909140124655

So , if I want to compare between the chain and step growth polymerization , percentage conversion verses molecular weight .	4.4031082424308465

Now , in some cases the chain polymerization can gives you a situation like this where the molecular weight increases linearly with the conversion .	5.950787986155133

It arises situation where the rate of initiation is faster compared to rate of propagation and also the reactions which were responsible for terminating a reactive species , reactive chain were absent in this case .	4.827406257019251

So , in the first case , in this case which is the normal you know which is , most of the general the chain reaction the initiation is slower compared to the propagation , chain propagation or the formation of polymer chain which means as the chain gets initiated it completes very fast .	5.953654445129762

So , you get high polymer , high molecular weight polymer at the beginning and as time goes more and more chains get initiated .	4.866489033841476

So , let us compare between the two polymerization processes one more time in the chain and step polymers .	5.46656558130497

So , it takes much longer time compared to chain reactions where the reactions happen quickly in a shorter time .	4.459827384518964

Obviously as the reaction , reactivity of the functional groups are lower you need high reaction temperature to overcome the activation energy , which requires your your reactions to be done at very high temperature .	4.4188436890714655

Now , high temperature reaction is not only to increase the reactivities in or the equilibrium constant of the reaction , but also if you want to remove , if somebody wants to remove the bi product like say water in polyester formation or say example , a water formation water form polyester formation to take out the water you have to increase the temperature high and put a high vacuum so that you can take out the water from the system which will give you the equilibration towards product side towards right hand side which will lead to formation of polymer molecules .	4.356626327309554

And in other case of chain reaction you can do it with lower reaction temperature as well because the reactivity of these monomers are quite high .	4.822928944977319

In case of step growth polymers you generally get a bi product formation and , but if there are example where this reaction happen without formation of bi product formation and in case of chain polymers there is no bi product formation .	4.434267149414426

In case of step polymers the monomers as you have seen from the earlier pages that monomers disappears early from the reaction whereas , in case of chain polymers the monomers disappears steadily with time and as monomers disappears you get high molecular chains forming and typically even step growth polymers you have heteroatom in the backbone whereas , in the chain polymers typically are formed by the carbon backbone .	4.494264656128866

Now , this classification of step and chain growth polymers also is not completely unambiguous .	4.971900824049683

For example if I have a monomer like this , propylene oxide and I make a polymer from this .	4.168177895978951

Now , by from looking at the structure of this molecule or in polymer molecule it is , because it is , has a heteroatom in the backbone with the group it seems like it is a chain growth , step growth polymers , but it is the mechanism of this polymers resembles more of a chain polymers of the type I mentioned in last page , so more close to chain polymerization .	4.895387138251918

So , this type of ring opening polymers by structure you may confuse with this , with the step growth polymers , but actually from mechanism the way it is synthesized this is more close to a chain polymerization of this type than a step growth polymers where the polymers are formed step wise , dimer , trimer , tetramer and so on .	4.503491973911847

In this case the formation happens by addition of monomers towards the chain end .	5.285546694094274

More more example of such can be given where this classification is not completely unambiguous .	5.81188654331405

So , what the conclusion , what the final message you should remember that this addition and chain polymers or chain growth polymers they should not be used interchangeably and so as your condensation and step polymers .	3.780468425272415

So , you should remember that though this addition and chain polymers are quite quite similar in terms of the structure and most of the chain polymers are made by addition reactions and most of the step polymers are synthesized by condensation reaction , but they are different they should not be used interchangeably .	4.791899368729372

Some U , IUPAC has suggested that this should be named as poly condensation in then instead of step polymers or step growth polymerization , but step growth polymers is much more broader nomenclature compared to a term like poly condensation which is which is narrower .	4.800595972636103

How do you name polymer molecules ?	6.067294996670989

Having discussed some of the characteristic features of enzymes in the light of their chemical nature , today we will discuss the functional nature of the enzymes and as most of you are familiar , catalysis is the universal property of enzymes .	4.548934465157893

The essential characteristic of a catalyst is to accelerate the rate of reaction that it is supposed to catalyze , but in the process it is not used up in itself and in an ideal situation it must be possible to recover the catalyst at the end of the reaction .	4.825728527512297

As a biocatalyst in the living systems two very significant characteristic properties of enzymes are noted that is the catalytic efficiency .	5.553712166047259

As you will notice , as we go further , that the enzymes provide a much more efficient catalytic system than their chemical counter part .	5.113399712580299

There are basic intrinsic mechanisms and the confirmation of the chemical nature of enzymes is the responsible factor for providing the catalytic efficiency .	4.399278374313082

We look into the basic factors that provide the catalytic efficiency .	6.28045249886182

When I say catalytic efficiency , I normally mean the magnitude by which it is able to increase the rate of reaction compared to an uncatalyzed reaction or the turn over number of the enzyme that means number of moles of substrate converted to product per unit time per mole of the catalyst .	4.172909969471885

The other feature which is very important is their specificity which is again not attributed to chemical catalyst and the enzymes provide a very specific catalytic system specific to the extent that we can recognize even the isomers they can distinguish .	4.71637764637033

Therefore it will be interesting to note how they catalyze the reactions such that these properties are built in , in the system .	4.271064130977817

Another feature which I think must be important to note is that an enzyme like any other chemical catalyst does not influence the thermodynamic status of the reaction .	3.801776026674057

That means whether it is the free energy change or the equilibrium constant of the reaction , it remains unaltered during the process .	5.893986277085881

It only accelerates the reaction rate by an order of magnitude .	7.716290472506264

Now just as an example if you look at isomerization of glucose to fructose , the reaction can be catalyzed by an alkali say NaOH .	4.444881101360434

You can get isomerization .	9.20148578091274

You can also carry out isomerization by enzymatic route using the glucose isomerase .	3.9853999455016953

In both the cases the equilibrium constant of the reaction is approximately equal to one .	5.037619883589211

So whether you carry out the reaction by alkali or by the presence of glucose isomerase , the reaction will end up under equilibrium conditions at an equimolar mixture of glucose and fructose and that remains unchanged .	4.325818777067128

The only difference , lies by the virtue of the presence of a catalyst or an enzyme in this case , will be that you can reach to the equilibrium status much faster than in the case of an uncatalyzed reaction .	4.852895109623006

Besides the equilibrium conversion or equilibrium constant of the reaction , the catalysis or the enzyme catalysis also follows all thermodynamic concepts that are applied to chemical reactions .	4.592470397085072

Some times it may look in the case of living systems that certain reactions that are catalyzed are in totality have a positive free energy change .	5.195053894347337

An example could be cited of conversion of carboxylation of Acetyl coenzyme A to Melonyl coenzyme A .	4.200431948274897

The enzyme carboxylase catalyses the reaction .	6.6478412656443355

The reaction has a free energy change of + 4.5 kilo calories per mole .	4.523312200227938

The reaction must be non - spontaneous , should not take place as per the normal thermodynamic concepts .	4.929001389940672

But we all know that this conversion does take place in the living cells .	5.399267472630012

Apparently it may look as if enzyme is doing something which is not allowed by a chemical thermodynamics but in practice it is not so because the reaction is catalyzed in association with another hydrolytic reaction which is energy yielding , which has a much higher negative free energy change and that is hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and inorganic phosphate .	4.722346345107329

The free energy change of this is highly negative – 8.9 kilo calories per mole .	4.922834464452413

While the reaction takes place as a coupled reaction of the two systems , the net reaction is a coupled reaction where the acetyl coenzyme carboxylation is coupled to hydrolysis of ATP .	4.451202267214639

But in practice the reaction does take place in a living cell as shown in the second half .	4.575062557483171

That is the enzyme which uses biotin as a cofactor activates the carbon dioxide at the expense of energy of hydrolysis of ATP and you get activated carbon dioxide with a negative free energy change which is a spontaneous reaction and this activated carbon dioxide then carboxylates the acetyl coenzyme A to melonyl coenzyme A , an enzyme along with the cofactor biotin is released free .	4.058621740770503

The second reaction is also a negative free energy change and therefore it is also carried out and the net reaction is the sum total of the two reactions , what we have shown here .	5.607697016334575

Therefore another feature is that the enzymes often show certain behavior which can be explained on the basis of coupling of more than one enzyme reactions where by we are able to produce certain net results which may look apparently to be non feasible but otherwise they follow all the laws of chemical reaction kinetics as well as thermodynamics .	4.484067385861573

The catalytic behavior of enzymes can be probably best illustrated by chemical reaction rate theory .	4.845565701141196

One of the most accepted theoretical interpretation of chemical catalyzes can be considered from point of view of chemical reaction rate theory which illustrates that molecules can react only if they come in contact with each other .	3.8289259139850462

That means the molecules do undergo certain collisions .	5.89621231163431

Therefore for different molecules of reactants to react collisions must take place .	5.100957781353001

Any factor or any parameter which increases the frequency of these collisions between the molecules will tend to increase the rate of reaction .	4.643802557069143

Of the two of the most sort after parameters , one is temperature .	6.939571236531099

We know that if we increase the temperature of a reaction system the frequency of collisions will increase and there by the rate of reaction .	4.522562441517526

Another is if you increase the reactant concentration again there also the frequency of collisions will increase and therefore rate of reaction will also increase .	4.771976812819437

However while collisions among the molecules might lead to product formation as per this chemical reaction rate theory , it is also understood by virtue of some of the studies on the distribution of molecules which undergo reaction that not all the molecules that collide will result into the product .	4.299502577675573

Only certain molecules which have sufficient energy to undergo reaction will result into the product formation and it will be only a fraction of the total molecules that participate in the collisions process are able to yield the product .	5.127153042154145

If you consider two molecules in a binary reaction , bimolecular reaction that is A and B and both of them are in their ground state keeping in view all their electronic , vibrational and rotational ground state but possess translational energy which makes them to move for the collisions to take place .	3.5067218519388295

If they are to react when they collide the rearrangement of the electronic confirmation in each molecule must take place .	3.6160534599990966

Consider two molecules say for example A and B which are supposed to react in the presence of a catalyst or without a catalyst .	5.043539765246607

If the reaction has to take place , then they must start colliding with each other .	4.140009060347886

Initially they will be at a ground state of their electronic , vibrational and rotational ground states but they will posses the translational energy which can make them move and collide .	4.2570385605139895

They can only react when the rearrangement of the electronic distribution in each molecule perhaps by transfer of atoms from one molecule to the other takes place .	4.337829267061998

It is clearly pointed out by Eyring in his transition state theory that every chemical reaction proceeds via formation of the unstable intermediate between reactants and the products .	3.4581679000841055

Take the example of hydrolysis of an ester , a very common reaction even occurring in the case of enzymatic reaction .	5.298737593443449

To the ester molecule a water molecule is added .	6.3703911801587525

This addition of water molecule results into an unstable transition state compound , which has partial bonds , partial negative and positive charges at the molecule .	4.005880796290268

This is a stable molecule which has much higher free energy change than the reactants and will break down to give the corresponding acid and the alcohol .	4.961200869894201

Eyring ’ s transition state theory states that for each reaction to occur it must pass through a transition state which is an unstable state of the molecules or unstable state some where in between the reactants and the products and which has much higher energy than possessed by the reactants of the ground state .	4.107140516215178

This energy requirement is considered as the energy of activation .	4.913805413269805

That means the free energy required for the reactants to reach the level of transition state compound is considered as the energy of activation .	4.135524609381148

The transition state compound will ultimately break down to give you the product or in other word the energy of activation acts a barrier .	5.470727186536196

Unless the reactant molecules cross the barrier they cannot get converted to the product .	5.748237085673188

From the energy diagram , consider the first stage which is an uncatalyzed reaction .	6.268654974519616

In the case of this reaction you see the reactants are at a ground state .	5.624973593153123

The X - axis denotes the extent of reaction the Y - axis is the energy content and then the molecules have to undergo an increase in energy till the point where a transition state is reached and then this transition state will break down , will undergo reduction in energy and lead to the products .	4.829332824427216

These are the reactants and these are the products .	7.389274075810344

The difference between the ground state and the maximum level of energy at which the transition state is generated is called as energy of activation .	5.382738889608994

That means the transition state will be able to break down and form the products .	6.564070692227486

Rest of the molecules which have much lower energy content will not be able to lead to product formation.On the other hand when we consider the second area where we use a catalyst the main role of a catalyst as we will also further confirm is to reduce this energy of activation by some means .	4.742521440412394

Whether it is chemical catalysis or enzymatic catalysis the primary function or the primary route by which a catalyst functions is by reduction in this activation energy .	3.766626518532699

You see that the energy of activation from here is reduced to this level .	5.409628300722389

The number of molecules , the fraction of total number of molecules has increased , which possess sufficient energy for the transition state molecule to break down into product , and large number of molecules can then take part in the reaction and result ultimately into the product .	5.584645748812578

In conclusion by lowering the energy of activation for the reaction , a catalyst makes it possible for substrate molecules with a smaller internal energy to react .	4.607971023840896

Even at a smaller internal energy level the product formation can take place .	5.63032318957023

You can see the related concentration of the shaded portion in the two cases without the catalyst and in the presence of catalyst .	5.538650212569311

That will illustrate the point .	9.466812518355091

If we look deeper into the transition state , the formation of transition state can be described as a very easily studied , as an ordinary chemical equilibrium process .	4.224443297593237

As I mentioned earlier the reactant molecule has to pass through a transition state .	3.5458664709413235

The formation of transition state starting from A and B can be considered as a simple chemical equilibrium process .	4.843776650686448

That means A and B combining to give you an activated complex AB * with an equilibrium constant of Keq or you can put it as say K * .	5.049715287182036

K * = [ AB * ] / [ A ] [ B ] [ AB * ] = K * [ A ] [ B ] ( 1 ) This chemical equilibrium follows the other relationships .	5.3514988092675635

That is the free energy of activation which is required in this whole process can also be given by E * = - RT ln Keq ( 2 ) Rate of reaction between A and B mind that we have not undergone the whole reaction process .	5.286792365226404

We have only come to the transition state complex and the rate of reaction will depend upon the concentration of AB * .	5.617699279968871

The larger this concentration of the transition state complex , the higher will be the rate of reaction and this rate will depend upon the frequency at which the activated complex will decompose and this rate of decomposition will depend upon the vibrational frequency of the bond that is breaking .	4.785455424313926

From transition state some bonds have to break some has to form .	5.473211354472577

Ultimately the transition state complex is somewhere intermediate between the reactant and the product .	5.4094675737434965

Some bonds are partially formed , they will be completely formed .	7.005914580516564

Some bonds are still in the formation stage and therefore the vibrational frequency of the bond that is breaking will determine the rate of the reaction .	4.329326794214408

This frequency can be arrived at from the theoretical treatment from two routes , by quantum mechanics as well as from classical mechanics .	4.694458334018271

Consider the frequency of energy of excited oscillator by quantum mechanics you get E = h ?	4.868446697242826

The general concept that the enzymes have certain substrate binding sites on molecule but conformationally it is more complementary to the substrate transition state and that was the contribution which was stated in very clear terms by Linus Pauling that enzymes are molecules that are complementary in structure to the activated complexes of the reactants they catalyse .	4.187766691983721

The attraction of the enzyme for the activated complex would thus lead to a decrease in its energy and hence decrease the energy of activation for reaction and to an increase in rate of reaction .	4.856059225503113

Stabilization of transition state means that the enzyme because of its confirmation which is complimentary to the transition state , binds and stabilizes the transition state complex .	5.4576713259700576

So at any given equilibrium the concentration of the EAB * that is the product of this binding is much , much higher than as if enzyme does not take part .	6.159200191988393

Coming back to the role of the energy of activation on the reaction rate constant , if you take arbitrary value of energy of activation , say from 25kcal mol - 1 downwards to 5kcal mol - 1 , a decrease of activation energy results in a very significant increase in the reaction rate .	4.720089192499865

That means an increase of magnitude by 1015 fold of the rate constant .	5.571169457187617

It is a very , very significant increase in the reaction rate constant and it will give the rate of reaction under any given set of conditions .	6.387861675903034

That means if you maintain same temperature and pressure and substrate concentration increase in the reaction rate constant by a factor of 4.58 x 103 fold can be achieved for every drop of 5kcal mol - 1 which is a very , very large .	4.5058564591001

So therefore even a decrease of the energy of activation by 5kcal mol - 1 can lead to an increase of the reaction rate by a factor of 4.5 x 103 .	4.762094009843992
