Continuing with the methods for immobilization of enzymes , we shall be talking today about the entrapment methods .	4.710934825636949

So far we have discussed various methods under the category of adsorption including ionic binding and metal salt linkage , cross linking and covalent bond formation .	3.512238904405752

That means the enzyme molecules are entrapped within a definite region of a space ; it could be a lattice of a polymeric matrix or a semi permeable membrane .	3.8622431499870986

This matrix within which the enzyme is entrapped must be tight enough to prevent the release of the protein and allow the substrate or product molecule to pass through the boundaries .	4.798463001715521

It means that when we have an enzyme which is entrapped within a gel matrix the gel should be porous enough so that within the pores it can retain the enzyme molecules which are large molecular weight in size of that of a protein but the porous structure must be such that the small molecular weight substrate or product molecules are allowed to pass through and therefore the reaction can be carried out .	4.668293134413595

On the other hand if the entrapped preparation is like a micro capsule which also consist of a semi permeable membrane boundary the permeability of the membrane must be such that the enzyme molecules are not allowed to be leaked out while the substrate and the product molecule can pass through easily .	3.639887819586743

Some of the important characteristics of these preparations is that only reactions involving relatively small substrate or product molecules can be carried out successfully using entrapped enzyme preparations .	4.266582792613666

Because the enzyme is entrapped it does not have any interactions or modifications or involvement or coupling of the amino acid residues of the protein molecules with that of the matrix of the immobilize enzyme preparation and therefore the sole force that keeps the enzyme molecules bound to the matrix is the porous network and purely by molecular size .	4.707874345981691

Therefore only small molecular weight substrate and products can be processed while the large molecular weight substrate or products cannot be processed using entrapped immobilized enzyme preparations .	4.198441738199628

The major advantage of this method is that it does not require any modification or involvements of the amino acids residues of the enzyme which results in the high yield and stability because there is no modification of the enzyme structure involved in the entrapment methods .	5.276767908342494

It is purely a physical restriction constraint of the enzyme molecule within a narrow region of a space and therefore the enzyme does not undergo any deactivation and usually the yields obtained by the method are quite high .	4.030776835556721

Second thing is that the micro environment of the enzyme can also be tailored to suite its stability .	6.078615483030265

While immobilizing the preparation , one can add substrate molecules or other stabilizing agents so that they are retained along with the enzymes and stable preparations can be obtained .	4.967210786887955

Two major types of entrapments methods that have been extensively followed are by gel entrapment .	4.576850400043789

That means you have a polymeric gel matrix and an enzyme molecule is entrapped within the lattices or interstitial spaces of these gel just by physical confinement .	4.091873985115001

There are varieties of methods to make the gel network .	6.848413566035699

We will discuss that and on the other hand the second method is microencapsulation where you tend to form a kind of a artificial cell with its boundary of a semi permeable membrane and the enzyme molecules are entrapped within this membrane and these micro capsules can be used as the immobilized enzyme preparations .	3.6917194500591193

Looking at the first method that is the gel entrapment it involves entrapping the enzyme within the interstitial spaces of cross linked water soluble polymeric gels .	4.233795774411259

Look at some of the phrases which I mentioned ; cross linked water insoluble polymeric gels .	5.592387256020146

In most cases we start either with the monomer or a water soluble polymer .	6.319425428947526

We start with a monomer unit and only those cases where the polymerization can be carried out under mild reaction conditions in the presence of enzyme .	5.166100830868732

The monomer solution which is usually water soluble is mixed with the enzyme solution and conditions are created so that polymerization can take place under mild reaction conditions with the help of a catalyst or initiator or some other conditions and the network of polymeric gel is formed which is water insoluble and then the enzyme is entrapped within the interstitial spaces .	4.003253362371928

Therefore it could be either by change of solvent , it could be change of by certain ions , it could be by temperature ; the usual parameters which can induce insolubility or it can affect the solubility of the polymer .	4.83585536502273

The polymeric network can be obtained from monomers , oligomers or polymeric precursors by changing the solubility variables .	4.364236551447805

So there are two approaches by which these preparations are made by changing the solubility variables like solvent , temperature , pH and ionic strength or the cross linking reactions .	3.9037362494806085

If it is a water soluble polymer , one can also induce cross linking by certain conditions so that it becomes water insoluble and the enzyme gets trapped into the matrix .	4.547541913569546

The purpose is if we start with water soluble polymer it will usually not have any cross linking .	5.273134480754972

It will be water soluble with lot of hydrophilic groups and the enzyme can easily mix with the solution .	5.101789478597442

Once you induce cross linking into it by any method , it could be by a cross linking bifunctional reagent like butyraldehyde , it could be ferric chloride .	4.666652310853139

Variety of methods has been employed and after cross linking is induced the whole network becomes water insoluble and the enzyme molecules are entrapped .	4.190274158253017

On the other hand when we are starting with a monomer unit which is water soluble , then to get water insoluble gel you include a cross linking agent .	4.134958011413017

These two parameters are in …. .. .	8.83388463915151

One is the degree of cross linking and the other is to change the solubility parameter .	6.3212242457132755

The ultimate matrix must be insoluble in water and also it should be in a proper range of cross linking such that the porosity can be regulated .	5.3307113702080935

Cross linking helps in a very significant manner to control the porosity of the matrix ; higher the cross linking smaller is the porosity .	5.915512820748773

One of the most commonly used methods is the poly acrylamide gel entrapment .	4.100248032398529

More than 50 % of the total literature cited on entrapment methods would probably be devoted to polyacrylamide gel entrapment .	3.8951503417584847

It was one of the earliest methods also because the poly acrylamide gel preparation was an existing methodology even for gel electrophoresis .	4.027254903922585

So we will use the same method to prepare an enzyme containing gels .	5.281318754345588

The method is very simple .	5.4624887194348375

We start with an acrylamide monomer which is water soluble .	6.327780865077434

To this a cross linking reagent usually N , N - methylene bisacrylamide usually often called as BIS is added and an enzyme solution is mixed with it .	4.353986859573018

The three water soluble materials are mixed to which an initiator is added .	4.856377934065335

It could be ammonium persulphate or potassium per sulphate or riboflavin .	4.038061032019493

They are initiators ; that means it is a free radical polymerization .	5.730300173708462

So you need an initiator molecule which can initiate the free radical reaction and TEMED , N , N , N ’ , N ’ tetra methyl ethylene diamine is used as the catalyst .	4.108849068768179

The two parameters which are very important to control here is the absence of oxygen .	7.399220676594674

So it is very important that all the reagents that have been used are free of oxygen .	5.890564760243181

If you bubble nitrogen through the reagents you can get them free of oxygen .	5.469092977465661

But even traces of oxygen can reduce degree of polymerization in the polymerization reaction .	5.77631315123377

The second parameter is that the reaction must be carried out at less then ten degree centigrade .	5.307325807119137

The reaction temperature while it will control the reaction rate it will carry out the reaction at a slow rate and it has also been seen in the polymerization reaction that slower the rate degree of the polymerization can be taken up to a higher level .	5.503715460905854

Secondly it is also important to keep the enzyme in a good state that is not to allow inactivation of the enzyme .	6.098934345528788

The reaction is exothermic and lot of heat is generated .	4.92957274172496

So you have to make arrangement for dissipation of heat so that the temperature can be maintained at less than ten degree centigrade and the enzyme is not deactivated .	4.393018181565965

It ’ s a very fast reaction .	6.902781464552975

The whole reaction will be over in a couple of minutes .	6.182063501857593

In a couple of minutes you get a polymeric network of chains .	6.312355983048907

It ’ s a three dimensional network .	6.300574471686767

These are the chains which are shown in the dotted lines and indicate the cross linkages which are vertical to the plane of the paper So the three dimensional network is formed and enzyme molecules are entrapped within the interstitial spaces which are created by the cross linkages that are maintained and you get a smooth solid block in the form of a gel .	3.60971643331807

The porosity of the gel can be maintained by the concentration of the cross linking agent that is BIS .	4.222102042206344

Temperature also can control the degree of polymerization and all the parameters can be optimized for a given condition so that the maximum yield of the enzyme activity is recovered at the end of the reaction .	5.538185241882901

You end up in a three dimensional network which is water insoluble and in the form of a block .	6.161258216424559

Here some of the cross linkages are shown ending with the dots .	7.746925069462412

These ones are perpendicular to the plane of paper to indicate a three dimensional network and the enzyme being entrapped within the space .	4.602333459118922

The conditions of concentration of the acrylamide monomer , the concentration of the cross linking agent , that is BIS , the reaction temperature are the three major parameters which control the degree of polymerization and porosity of the gel .	4.6248709835541755

After the gel is formed , the gel is mechanically ruptured into small pieces in the form of a small granules or cut into small pieces and then can be used as a packing material in the reactors .	3.898894007357795

In addition to this another very common group of methods which has been used are the use of photocrosslinkable reagent prepolymers .	4.819508653924248

A large number of methods are based on the use of photocrosslinkable prepolymers .	4.938168830009964

I have shown here some of the reagents like ENT which is water soluble derivative of poly ethylene glycol , ENTP is a water insoluble derivative of polypropylene glycol and ENTB is a water insoluble derivative of polybutadiene .	3.8460287472057226

PBM is malic polybutadiene and PU is polyurethane and these are the precursors of certain photocrosslinkable polymers .	4.907121386483057

These molecules can be polymerized using UV radiations in the presence of a photoinducer , a catalyst , and benzoin ethylether is used in most cases as an inducer for photocrosslinking .	4.925284902266524

These materials can be dissolved along with the enzyme and then polymerization can be started by exposing them to ultra violet light at 360nm for few minutes and then in few minutes the reaction is over and the gel preparation containing the enzyme molecule is made available .	4.4749847971864565

Another group of entrapment methods , gel entrapment method rather , is from the long chain polymers .	5.188314284679768

There are two major approaches by which these gel entrapment preparations are made from long chain pre formed polymers .	3.937284224734814

In the two earlier methods we have talked about the use of a monomer and an oligomer a prepolymer .	6.167179935221421

On the other hand here we are using a ready made polymer .	4.811009688047036

The first method which is also a very commonly used method is ionotropic gelation in which the whole process of insolubilization of the polymer is based on ionic exchange .	6.021869317186507

The enzyme , water soluble enzyme is mixed with an aqueous solution of the appropriate polyelectrolyte .	5.11456573043385

Most of the polymers used here are polyelectrolytes which can be mixed with the enzyme solution and a typical preparation which has been reported is sodium alginate .	5.006142632097255

It is a polysaccharide , negatively charged polyelectrolyte .	5.050659782714792

This polyelectrolyte is then mixed with the enzyme solution and this mixture is then added drop wise with addition into a solution of counter ions .	4.273396453004195

The sodium is replaced by calcium .	8.784902560963788

Calcium has been most commonly used so instead of sodium alginate you end up in calcium alginate which is water insoluble .	4.678509115334816

While sodium alginate is water soluble polymer , it can mix with the enzyme solution and then this mixture is extruded through a fine syringe into a calcium chloride solution and agitated .	4.462359625870825

By the exchange of ions the sodium gets exchanged with the calcium , you get water insoluble beads .	3.7476341577398657

One of the major advantages of this method is that while in the case of previous methods you get the block of the gel and the gel block has to be mechanically dispersed into a particular shape for use in a reactor , here you can prepare the beads , the immobilized enzyme preparation , almost in the bead form so that that can be directly used .	4.391426740113519

One of the disadvantages here is the stability of this material .	6.383145952305876

For example calcium alginate although insoluble in aqueous medium gets solubilised by certain ions like phosphate ions .	4.165975285885462

If your medium contains phosphate ions , calcium alginate will slowly get dislodged and you will end up in dissolution of immobilized preparation and sometimes instead of calcium , barium or aluminium is used as a counter ion .	3.6671285733980468

Such methods are very commonly used not only for enzymes but even for some of other biocatalysts like …… cells , this provides a very viable method for immobilization .	4.171722941857739

Second method is based on precipitation .	11.946030412706993

That means you change certain conditions in a way that the mixture of the enzyme and the prepolymer changes the solubility behavior and gets precipitated .	4.818752557804955

Some of the natural synthetic polymers that are very commonly used are : collagen , gelatin and agarose .	4.309844218074405

A large variety of natural polymers are used by changing one or more of the parameters in the solution .	5.858635414069994

Collagen which is a structure of protein , is found in the slaughter house waste .	6.944966030670842

Collagen can be taken mixed with the enzyme solution and you make a dispersion of the enzyme with the collagen solution .	6.321433976524829

You don ’ t really get a good solution .	6.379008720900819

Being a structural protein , you get a real dispersion of the enzyme .	7.427858193956844

This dispersion is then cast on a sheet so that you can get thin film of the enzyme entrapped in the collagen membrane .	5.470144029782138

To provide stability to this film usually this film is subjected to crosslinking either by butyraldehyde or by ferric chloride .	3.914395565319279

Different methods have been used ; so crosslinking becomes an important parameter to provide stability to the immobilized preparation .	4.776291244861984

Similarly in the case of gelatin , one can mix the gelatin solution with the enzyme solution and pull it .	4.483243360914128

Pulling will reduce the solubility and we will get a gel .	9.801819136123195

Collagen is not so good .	13.491644846145574

It forms the dispersion with the enzyme molecule and a collagen method is not exactly like a gel as we consider a poly acrylamide gel or an agarose gel or any starch gel .	4.5283862876686385

It is a dispersion which is cast into a thin film .	4.5036387863364435

Dispersion of collagen and enzyme in water is spread over a film , thin film usually .	5.165580763144369

Preparation like this are made in the form of thin films and then to give the stability they are crosslinked and after it is crosslinked it becomes a permanent .	4.764694887069893

You just add the cross linking agent after a film has been made .	5.566781135568995

Yes algenic acid .	17.603314496829668

Another method , a very useful method , again for immobilizing mostly microbial cells is fiber entrapment .	4.372861236560835

The physical entrapment of an enzyme is achieved by dissolving a fiber forming polymer like cellulose triacetate which is water insoluble .	4.16571993040259

This is dissolved in a non - polar solvent like chloroform or carbon tetrachloride , methylenechloride and this organic solution of cellulose triacetate is then emulsified with the aqueous enzyme solution .	3.7336232051822935

Stir the two solutions inorganic as well as the aqueous phase ; agitate it and you get a fine emulsion .	6.3342330437269485

This time emulsion is extruded through a spinneret just like you make nylon fibers and pass through a fine spinneret and the extruded fibers or the filaments are then dipped into a liquid coagulant like toluene or petroleum ether .	3.236184938845282

When these fibers are passed through toluene , they get coagulated , the polymer gets coagulated with the water droplets , the aqueous droplet of enzyme being entrapped in the fiber .	4.1445974256891445

This is a spinneret .	9.549265750956327

This is put into a trough containing toluene .	5.923780702243633

When it passes through toluene after residence time in toluene , the polymer cellulose triacetate gets coagulated ; it is no longer soluble and then the fiber that are formed contain the enzyme micro - droplets which was earlier emulsified into the solution of cellulose triacetate which are entrapped in the fibers .	3.7938017485315645

Then these fibers can be used in a variety of modes in a reactor .	7.061040817203935

Even people have tried to make fabric out of immobilized cells which then can be used for variety of industrial applications .	5.143213311601876

The second group of entrapment method is on microencapsulation and in the case of micro encapsulation , as I mentioned earlier , the enzyme is enclosed within a semi permeable membrane ; polymeric membrane permeable to substrate and product .	4.233410632671605

Enzyme does not pass through but substrate or product must be able to pass through the membrane in the system .	4.607102499845379

One of the major advantages is that it provides extremely large surface area for the enzyme substrate complex and the enzyme substrate contact within a small volume .	4.455382922182204

But the preparations are too fragile because this semipermeable membrane is very , very thin and it provides you a very , very fragile preparation .	4.821965568115325

Therefore its use in a number of industrial reactors is probably very difficult because it will not be able to withstand the shear and the mechanical load which an industrial reactor for chemical processing will require .	4.593118333876652

But this method has been very extensively and very favorably used particularly for biomedical applications .	4.390781163216235

For example the references as I have listed here by Chand and associates , which was reported in 1971 had asparagine in nylon microcapsules .	3.765392368174182

In the preparation of nylon microcapsules , an aqueous solution of the enzyme and hydrophilic monomer like hexamethylene diamine is dissolved in a buffer .	4.852445844892922

This is emulsified in a water immiscible organic solvent which is cyclohexane , chloroform mixture .	4.8853476036060455

To the emulsified monomer solution , you add another hydrophobic monomer dissolved in the same solvent .	4.096579273730917

Hydrophobic monomer , in this case is sebacoyl chloride .	9.706103983880057

At the interface the two monomers gets polymerized and the reaction gives you a polymer what we know as nylon .	6.3908198004115

So the chain continues and you get nylon .	7.923137933061448

This method has been used very significantly for immobilizing an enzyme called asparaginase which is used as a therapeutic agent for persons suffering from leukemia .	4.356675432348139

One major advantage here is that the nylon molecule being non - immunogenic provides a much better material for putting into the human system .	4.509088249239939

Carbohydrates or proteins are known to generate immunogenic reactions in the body whereas nylon is relatively inert as far as the immunogenecity is concerned and these capsules have been used for treatment of leukemia .	4.4508724692587105

For most of the patients suffering from leukemia one of the problems is their lack of asparagine .	5.296849359220779

They lose the asparaginase enzyme , the enzyme which hydrolyses the asparagine in the system .	5.62670945876791

While these methods have academic significance from the point of view of providing certain characteristics features but for industrial reactors they are not very suitable .	4.029422364385407

I found applications in only biomedical applications .	6.6291063661892595

What you have done is initially you have taken a hydrophilic monomer and the enzyme solution in a buffer , in an aqueous buffer , mixed it into an organic solvent .	4.916956471311378

So you make a fine droplet , fine emulsion .	6.489798759059284

To this emulsion we add the hydrophobic monomer dissolved in the same solvent .	4.621501178596238

So at the interface of the hydrophilic and hydrophobic monomer they polymerize and the enzyme gets entrapped into and these microcapsules are very fine in size .	4.233379671815872

The size can be varied from almost about two to three microns to ten microns almost like an artificial cell , a yeast cell for example .	4.109513791637962

Almost they will be the size of yeast cells .	12.42761538289581

We have seen so far a large variety of immobilization methods .	4.653351476914835

If one has to really study various methods I think one must compare the various methods and to evaluate various methods for a particular job then these are the parameters which are needed to be looked into .	4.594332970536662

On the right hand side I have given you the various methods that we have talked about .	4.818849082779187

On the left hand side are the parameters which are important to be compared and there is no method absolutely reported in literature which can meet all the requirements .	4.222090429689048

There is no ideal immobilization method and each method has to be weighed in terms of its applicability and the parameters that are important are : method of preparation , binding force for example I have mentioned adsorption as a weak binding force as compared to covalent binding .	4.017673549809271

If you require a very strong binding force use covalent coupling .	5.464072936619692

Yield is a very important parameter .	14.145143082712561

Enzyme loading … .	27.90681883219377

per unit carrier how much of the enzyme can be loaded and it is something like specific activity of a soluble enzyme preparation .	6.875484649415437

That means in so much of protein what activity can be carried out ?	5.125659777952804

Similarly enzyme loading in terms of carrier loading .	12.389983576675982

Then the choice of carrier and in the choice of carrier the regeneration of the carrier is also associated .	5.405482299515238

The cost of the carrier and the regeneration capacity are directly linked .	4.788281761824478

The stability of the preparation and protection from microbial attack .	6.30329594055446

Most of the entrapment methods have a major advantage of protection from microbial attack because they are constrained within the four walls of a structure almost like microbial cells where all the enzymes or proteins are enclosed within a cell wall in the membrane and within a living cell the enzyme remains safe from microbial attack .	3.484704001774608

Similar situations can be looked from entrapment methods and finally the over riding factor often comes as cost .	4.300858760436498

So all the methods are mostly considered in terms of these parameters .	6.596963011464609

When we talk of the immobilization for industrial reactors the major factor is the cost and in terms of the cost it is desirable that when we produce them on a commercial scale using microbial cells , those enzymes which are intercellular in nature they could be used almost in the form of ….. ... .	4.267845942123809

You need not disrupt the cells and then isolate and purify the enzyme and then immobilize .	5.302278533910197

Because isolation , purification is a very cost intensive operation for intercellular enzymes .	6.282049581688451

So in many cases of intercellular enzymes efforts have been made to immobilize the whole cell itself and the immobilization of the whole cell is a desirable feature particularly in the case of intercellular enzymes .	4.575638471106273

If the enzyme , the glucose isomerase is an intercellular enzyme and if one has to really isolate , purify and then immobilize probably the process will not be viable .	4.759692259190861

Today the process is used industrially , commercially almost in half of the world wherever sucrose is not abundantly available , as a sweetener for glucose fructose mixture because the product cost is not very high .	3.8375178332515434

Therefore the use of immobilized cells provides a very viable alternative .	4.79637893362168

The conditions that are imposed on the use of immobilized cells are that the cells should not contain the interfering enzymes catalyzing the side reactions .	3.9408720432767623

That means for example if you are using glucose as a substrate for a particular reaction , then the cell should not contain the enzymes that can also act on glucose and produce the side effects .	4.853042656869091

Glucose is a substrate .	14.870133106090567

You will all agree that it is very difficult to look at the living cell or a microbial cell which will not have more than one enzyme and which will use glucose as substrate .	5.5830932772535355

In the case of glucose isomerase or the immobilized glucose isomer is the form of … .	4.656404889706062

we take advantage of the thermal stability of the enzyme .	7.194015736162321

The enzyme glucose isomerase is a very thermo tolerant enzyme of the order that the optimum temperature of the glucose isomer ranges between 70 to 80ºc and therefore you can take the cells give a heat treatment whereby most of the other enzymes which are able to act on glucose are inactivated but glucose isomerase still remains active and use that heat treated cells for immobilization .	4.370312416294357

So the cell should not contain any interfering enzyme .	4.763036641270831

There are many preparations like for example preparation of fumaric acid from aspartic acid where the enzymes are too specific and usually there are no other enzymes present in the cell which will be able to utilize those substrate .	4.409125890191914

Then the substrate product should also pass through the cell membrane .	5.769549423213723

So the cell membrane should be able to transport the substrate and the product across the boundary otherwise you cannot make the reaction feasible .	4.664932640466435

For immobilized cell although theoretically almost all methods , variety of methods starting from adsorption to entrapment have been used sparingly , the bulk of the methods that had been used rather …. .. on industrial scale are based on adsorption or entrapment .	4.076529146649188

Most of the entrapment methods very commonly have been used to entrap the microbial cells and as you will notice that entrapment within calcium alginate beads , polyacrylamide gel and cellulose acetate fibers have been commonly used methods for immobilizing .	3.634499617980531

The method remains the same as we have talked about the enzyme molecules .	6.819660329376647

The entrapment of cells is much more because of their larger size than the enzyme molecule .	6.038030009993426

There are four adsorption methods which are based mostly on ionic binding because most of the cells have negative charge on the surface and therefore any positively charged matrix can be used to adsorb the cells on to the surface .	4.134469397208568

These adsorb preparations are usually in dynamic equilibrium .	6.997460397591569

That means if it is a growing cell then part of the cell will attach and some of the cells will be leaking out also .	5.77980404525409

But in the case of non - viable cells usually entrapment methods are the method of choice .	5.186373776915943

We must here also probably make a distinction between living and non - viable cells .	4.042661508834854

Living cells are usually used in those cases of bio - conversion processes where we require a series of enzyme reaction .	5.45668361535555

More than one enzyme reactions is involved usually with a co factor regeneration that means a metabolic path way is involved with a metabolite to be produced or else if a single enzyme is desirable then it is always desirable to use non - viable cells .	3.9610122273679442

For living cells usually adsorption has been a method which had been very commonly used while for non - viable cells , entrapment is the method which has been most widely used .	5.015130432023627

When we talk of immobilization of microbial cells we could think of the cells which are viable , which can multiply .	4.584824864161141

These multiplying cells or living cells are needed in those cases where the process requires a full metabolic path way which means a series of enzyme reactions which are interlinked for co - factor regeneration or for some other metabolite I mean uptake and production .	3.9259386695714693

In those cases living cells are used and usually these living cells have been immobilized by adsorption method because when they are living on the adsorption method although it is a method which regularly leaks out the cells from surface but then the new cells which are growing during growth phase they can also bind to the surface and then … .	4.243877635317

in a dynamic balance .	14.669807806816017

On the other hand if a single enzyme catalyzed reaction is the desired feature , then non - viable cells are desirable and they can be immobilized safely by one of the entrapment methods that we have talked about .	4.5639724433349755

Having looked into a variety of immobilization methods , we should also have a code to characterize an immobilized enzyme preparation by any method .	4.900023969656403

Somebody has reported an immobilization method for a particular biocatalyst .	8.30565467117876

There has to be a common feature by which the immobilized preparation can be characterized so that the purpose of characterization is that the method should be reproducible by anybody .	5.941854982818731

Minimum information should be provided so that anybody who wants to reproduce the method can use it for further work .	4.07150926139243

Some of these steps which I have listed here provide this .	6.641194635149291

These three things must be clearly outlined .	5.942552100648987

What is the reaction we are looking at ?	6.698821766763421

That means also involves which enzyme we want and what are the source of enzyme and the carrier which is required to be used for any method .	5.521582826116046

The second step is method of immobilization .	6.402404004572678

That means how do you prepare ; what are the reaction conditions ?	6.715522447200509

That means the reaction conditions and particularly more important is yield , loss of activity and the activity left in the supernatent .	4.741983649002227

Then the characteristics feature is physical - chemical characterization which means the biocatalyst shape , mean particle diameter or wet particle diameter .	4.362745376770955

Finally kinetics and stability of immobilized biocatalyst a very important feature which probably dictates the choice of the immobilized enzyme preparation .	4.7335269578822725

As far as kinetics is concerned , as we have seen for the soluble enzyme , the substrate concentration versus initial reaction velocity that means the effect of substrate concentration on initial reaction velocity was the major kinetic characterization of soluble enzyme which gives you information about km , Vm and other kinetic parameters and normally by convention we represent the kinetic parameter for an immobilized enzyme or immobilized biocatalyst by k ’ m and V ’ m .	4.5302872492884845

Prime is added just to indicate that we are reporting an immobilized preparation , just as a convention .	6.0525947921216074

Now the key issue is that all these functions in the living cell , may it be a microbial cell , may it be a plant cell or it might be an animal cell , they are mediated by the catalyst known as enzymes .	3.629607397313491

Therefore the enzymes play a very central role in the function of living cells or in other words you can say that they are one of the most important executives in a living cell .	4.333386260776961

If you look at some of the aspect of enzymes and the process via catalyst , a very broad picture which refers to the role of enzymes as the bio catalyst , we must be aware that all these enzymes functions at the ambient conditions at the conditions at which living cells are known to live .	4.175191407002295

That is the basis of their energetic efficiency .	6.615904739722492

That means the energy requirement of those reactions they catalyze could be very meager .	4.4628083042198545

They have high turn over number .	6.47453114247456

When we discuss the reaction mechanism we will see that they are very efficient catalyst and when I say very efficient catalyst our counter part to compare is the chemical catalyst .	5.216125107788405

There are a large number of reactions which can be catalyzed both by enzymes as well as by chemical catalyst and the subtle mechanisms that are involved in the enzymatic catalysis make them very efficient catalyst meaning a high turn over number or a significant reduction in the energy of activation of reaction .	4.062472864492674

The very characteristic feature of enzyme is their specificity .	6.182738865232088

It is advantageous in the sense that specificity will bring in lack of any byproducts because it will not act on any of the other substrate molecule which are present as additions or contaminant in the …… stream and you will only be reacting the desired substrate and converting it to product .	4.210729266942296

On the other hand the disadvantage is from industrial point of view .	3.368607686031057

You cannot produce them in very large quantity because you require small quantities of catalyst for specific reactions .	4.770996295292731

For example vanadium pentoxide or colloidal platinum can act as oxidation catalyst for n number of reactions or Raney nickel for hydrogenation .	4.054111400107181

Whatever has to be hydrogenated it can be used .	10.286917869984029

But the same scenario doesn ’ t happen .	5.903706725071715

You need a very specific enzyme and that brings in some sort of disadvantage as far as their role as industrial catalyst is concerned .	4.304066621980101

Two of the definitely undesirable features of an enzyme as catalyst is they are relatively fragile in nature and with very mild deviations from their normal operating conditions they can be deactivated .	4.284899544270449

The whole function is dependent upon a very subtle conformation .	5.76341514035775

This conformation is result of not only covalent interactions but of a large number of non covalent interactions which can be disturbed very easily and that is why the deactivation of enzymes can occur and deactivation from industrial point of view is some kind of a loss .	4.321800332903806

The other factor is cost which is again an undesirable feature which probably applies to any commodity we want to use for industrial purposes .	4.248376169920329

We will always like to choose a commodity which is less expensive and does the job and because the enzymes are produced in small amounts by the living cell and the only source of enzyme to us are living cells and they are synthesized in very small quantities .	4.719683749582228

So obviously their cost per unit quantity is comparably very high and coupled with their stability it becomes an expensive proposition .	4.367809404589504

But we are also aware of the some of recent developments in biotechnology , molecular biology and other sciences which involve isolation , purification , as well as stabilization .	4.135246165175764

The costs have been brought down , the concentration of the enzyme protein which can be synthesized has gone up and this situation is changing .	6.128216560571842

Another very significant equation as far as enzymes as processed via catalysts are concerned is between availability and applications .	4.250576873680835

We saw that they carry out lot a large number of reactions .	6.138736052499721

But although in a living cell various enzymes , which carry out these reactions are available their availability in large quantities for commercial applications are limited .	4.550264863541568

As matter of fact only those enzymes which are required in bulk , when I say bulk I am referring to at least , if not tons , quintals many of them in tons really , they cannot be produced on a mass scale and their availability for commercial applications is limited .	3.9092535401945825

There are certain classical examples of amylases , glucoisomerase , cellulase , lipase , proteases , which are the enzymes that are produced in bulk and are available in large quantity .	4.152293530390371

The other part is because of their bulk production the cost has also come down and become reasonable for commercial applications .	4.851288007202055

The issue of availability is very intrinsically linked with the applications of enzymes .	4.97644180622529

Unless applications emerge one will not like to produce them in large quantities .	5.7314958083436816

The paradox remains .	19.422067189009802

The applications do not emerge till they are available in large quantity .	4.532353546614366

There are a large number of examples which will illustrate my point .	3.9651439854498314

Take for example a candidate like lipase - the enzyme that hydrolyses lipids into the consequent fatty acids and glycerol .	3.87650307144256

Obviously the enzyme is not available in the quantities that many of the other enzymes , like amylases and proteases , are available .	5.286790244343189

But there is a potential that it can be produced provided the applications emerge so that the scale of operations which is required for bulk operation can be easily maintained and so the reversible interaction between availability and application is a very intrinsic feature and probably will illustrate the story of many of the enzymes which have become commercially viable today .	4.5888607643649495

As far as availability is concerned there are two major factors .	5.744999679056783

One is that we have to synthesize them .	8.765238588275858

Theoretically one can produce enzymes from any living source microbial , plant or animals but the trend in the reason past has been that the microorganism has been the preferred choice for variety of reasons .	3.7971562678641244

Some of you may be familiar with them and most important one is diversity .	4.532131952034191

Secondly you can choose micro organism which will be able to act on a particular substrate , synthesize required enzyme .	5.280692267204558

On the other hand you also have a very clear understanding of the genetic machinery of the cell , the microbial cell that controls the enzyme synthesis , which you will manipulate leading to hyper production of the enzyme .	3.660411088526632

Their bulk productions , their bulk growth is very simple .	5.4280105273606285

The parameters , the equipment are all standardized thanks to many other products which are produced microbially that gives an edge for microbial biosynthesis of enzymes .	3.7937990338849823

The other important part is isolation , purification and stability .	5.543076779954003

In isolation and purification one of the very characteristic features is that most of the enzymes are purified by a series of steps .	5.422941806879994

An electrophoretically homogeneous protein means it is a perfectly pure enzyme .	7.142895395011606

For most of the industrial applications except for some of the medical or diagnostic applications you will not require a highly purified enzyme .	5.062673219844462

For bulk industrial processing we have to stop at purity level somewhere in between .	5.772689234155731

Compared to this crude enzyme where this specific activity is very low to a level where the contaminating enzyme that can disturb the process are revoked .	4.6474895143043184

But note that all the contaminants are revoked which may not be required because any order of purification will mean additional cost , enhancement in the value of the product .	4.777261913385399

As far as the applications are concerned a lot of engineering inputs are required particularly for the extended use of the catalyst and we don ’ t want to use it just once .	4.9071833680762795

As a matter of fact I think one can take a clue again here from a living cell .	4.2921792619778785

The cell maintains a very perfect economy in terms of its energy as well as materials to synthesize proteins .	5.372861901743531

It doesn ’ t use the proteins only once .	5.837709628615428

It uses in a cycle and over a period of time .	4.1905080167443165

There is always a maintenance part where it has to maintain the protein synthesis but it is being used repeatedly and in many of the organs of the cell , the enzymes are supported on certain organelles so that they behave almost in a fashion of insolublised enzymes .	4.534099171769824

On the basis of the same concept one can immobilize the enzymes on a support , insoluble support what we call as immobilize enzyme and use them for processes that can be used in continuous mode like any other chemical process , the term very commonly used in the chemical industry is heterogeneous catalysis .	4.375027245100528

Then a very important aspect is bulk environment design .	7.403764181445284

This today is probably not a very perfect statement because a number of enzymes have been shown to function even in a non aqueous environment or in other words more accurately micro aqueous environment where you require a very small concentration of water , rest of the bulk environment will be replaced by an organic solvent and that can give us a whole new range of chemical reactions which can be carried out using the enzymes and biocatalyst particularly a transition from hydrolysis to synthesis and many of these reactions have become commercially viable today .	4.152997960133712

Ultimately for any process application of the enzymes you need to engineer the systems even after you have done immobilization , even after you have studied the optimum reaction parameter , the whole systems has to be engineered .	4.734230999023275

I mean to say that you have to develop particular hardware reactor , an enzyme reactor in which the whole reactions can be carried out with maximum productivity because ultimately the whole concept or the whole interest between will be on the productivity and which can be tailored by doing the proper process engineering .	4.642932422098079

Then you may need to monitor certain parameters , the instrumentation control , down stream processing of the product , all has to be integrated so as to have a complete application route .	4.707589620295006

In summary the broad objective of this course as I mentioned so far will be to study various scientific , technological and engineering aspects associated with the application of enzymes as a bio catalyst in process industry .	4.253741204154114

This in brief terms can be the broad definition of or broad objective of this course .	3.9009139973939058

I like you to be very critical about the scientific , technological and engineering aspects .	4.246783798613821

Almost an analogy with the biotechnology in general even the enzyme technology also has a very multidisciplinary nature .	4.798118472225614

Another important aspect which I think I will like to touch upon in today ’ s lecture will be on enzyme classification .	4.440120744698367

Now you will be surprised to know that so far globally about three thousand enzymes have been isolated , characterized and reported in literature .	4.145774740326368

It ’ s not a very large number compared to the feasibility of combinations that are feasible .	5.480629445898536

If we look at enzymes as a polymer consisting of nineteen different amino acids with an average length , let us say 150 or 200 amino acids linked together .	4.220531268960374

With nineteen different amino acids probably the possibility of , variety of , diversity of proteins that are feasible is enormous almost approaching infinity .	4.339237681587191

We have been able to isolate and characterize only about three thousand .	4.480905808853439

In fact this job was done way back in early seventies by international union of pure and applied chemistry , what you know as IUPAC .	3.738192190886564

They gave a classification system which is acceptable globally today and it classifies all the enzymes into six major classes ’ : oxidoreductases , transferases , hydrolases , lyases , isomerases and ligases .	3.7722898522539343

The whole range of chemical reactions or bio chemical reactions that take place in a living cell are mediated by these different classes .	4.260990637124554

We must know that some of the reactions are not independent .	8.673156760797568

They are coupled there by producing effect which could be a polymerization reaction .	5.270773397315723

Directly a polymerization doesn ’ t take place as it is .	6.499205058832509

It is mediated by series of transferases and then ultimately the transferases and ligases .	4.3563945089606175

Ultimately you end up with the polymer of different monomers .	9.23431946995067

But basic enzymes can be classified and each of this class is also characterized in sub classes .	5.908501830182286

Sub classes refer to the type of substrate or the type of the product that is produced by those enzymes .	7.047751818344881

So basically the whole range of each of the class here oxidoreductases a bulk of the oxidases , reductases and the hydrolases fall under this category .	4.028251090643707

Transferases involve group transfer reactions where one of the functional group with a substrate molecule is phosphorylated .	7.020226671612013

Usually they are bisubstrate reactions involving two substrates .	6.090428788035813

In hydrolases by and large the most commonly employed industrial catalyst is used mainly because of simplicity .	6.390234515794282

Because the co - substrate is water which is present in large quantity and one can use them for hydrolytic reactions .	5.984126177833664

By changing the bulk environment hydrolysis can be tailored to be used for synthetic reactions as well .	5.363480777499886

In lyases an additive enzyme which catalyses the elimination reactions that result in the double bond formation is used .	4.987470405929633

Isomerases are another important catalyst of industrial enzymes which isomerises one molecule into other isomerable molecule .	4.5164238997448445

One of the most significant enzymes under this class is isomerization of glucose to fructose .	3.618159600916755

Ligases join two molecules at the expense of energy source .	6.866123360764797

In most biochemical reactions ATP is the energy currency which is consumed and regenerated through catabolic processes and such reactions are classified under ligases .	3.9552731981835825

This is the classification based on the IUPAC nomenclature more from the scientific point of view .	4.620707031010156

But from the industrial point of view or from the application point of view another important type of classification which is made is in terms of three classes what we know as bulk , diagnostic and therapeutic .	4.576570933605535

This classification is based on the cost of the enzymes .	10.735111344016744

In fact the cost of the enzyme is directly linked with the concentrations in the starting material .	5.314904783213374

It could be a fermentation broth in most cases .	5.945718379182294

In the fermentation broth if the concentration of the product or the desired enzymes is very low the cost is very high and second factor of cost is the application and the degree of purity you need for that particular application .	5.784262827753273

The bulk enzymes as you can see here they fall in this category .	5.978126438690427

The concentration in the starting material is of the order of about one kg per meter cube which is significant enough to recover and you don ’ t require for the most cases a very high degree of purity and therefore their cost is also reasonably low say for example about thousand US dollars per kg .	3.840957195699603

The next category is diagnostic .	8.32057609264611

It includes also analytical enzymes .	10.107764466812869

This is the concentration in grams per meter cube level which is much lower .	4.843331335818049

Degree of purification required is also larger because you will not like any protein contaminant present in the sample and their cost is therefore significantly high of the order of about 106 US dollars per kg .	4.349463113346941

You should not get threatened by the amount of cost of 106dollars .	6.433870203535794

The quantity required is also in micrograms .	9.069861329631335

They are not in kilograms like other molecules .	5.7460264333097015

So they are affordable .	9.032943656492746

The third and probably most expensive classes are therapeutic enzymes which are exclusively required for medical applications almost like life saving drugs .	3.7393725454745286

Their cost is immaterial and you don ’ t make choice on the basis of cost .	5.337606524402223

But if effectiveness is the same the cost is the principle determining factor .	6.444606323827786

In the case of therapeutic products , the choice is not on the basis of cost but on the basis of its need if it is a life saving drug .	4.7875106523063

Many of the therapeutic enzymes particularly the recombinant proteins that are available from the enzymes like streptokinase and urokinase are blood clot dissolving enzymes .	3.7735724138635947

Similarly a number of other such therapeutic proteins or enzymes are available like asparaginase , for patients suffering from leukemia , which is again life saving .	4.469836693456113

The cost is also of a very high order but the quantity required is of less than micro gram quantities but in a very highly purified state .	4.674452654899311

But I said , that in practice , in industry , when one makes a step polymer , seldom the distribution , the PDI value comes to around 2 , always it is found to be slightly above 2 , say between 2 to 2.5 and so on .	4.105977889080152

So , it depends upon both .	13.07342900826156

Now , we started discussing about the thermodynamic factor .	6.405231100548627

Thermodynamic factor is nothing but the stability of the forming cyclic rings .	6.180072191814469

For example , we know from our organic chemistry knowledge , that general order , general order of stability of different , of different ring structure follows in the following order , that a ring containing three or four atom in a ring is least stable or lowest , lowest compared to a 5 - membered or 7 to 13 - membered ring , which is even lower stable than 6 - membered or a 14 - membered ring and higher and that we know from our organic chemistry knowledge .	3.3919991426356235

That is because we have , in a small ring we have more ring strain and torsional in a big chain you have a torsional strain as well .	4.954321539155778

So , obviously , formation of 6 - membered or 4 - membered or higher membered ring will be always preferred thermodynamically compared to a ring size having 3 - membered or 4 - membered in it .	3.8319165816043843

So , which means , that in thermodynamics , factors will favor formation of a 6 - membered or 4 - membered or higher membered ring in case of cyclic formation .	4.001382662390717

Now , does it mean , that always you have formation of cyclic , for example , 14 and higher members ?	5.4052480625298225

This is true for almost every possible ring .	6.886607249121915

Now , I was talking about , that if you have a larger ring , larger linear molecules , say having 14 or higher number of atoms in the , in the ring , in the linear molecules , then they have so many conformation , this , as the more or the higher is the number of atoms or longer is the chain , you have more number of conformation of that molecule possible .	4.7013820348439666

So , in terms of kinetic factor the higher the chain length , the lower is the possibility of formation of ring .	6.8524043749109245

Now , if you talk about the rate of polymerization , which will help us in designing reaction conditions , which will minimize the cyclic formation , let us look at the rate of ring formation or cyclization and , and the linear polymerization .	5.041466730928177

So , I can write the rate of cyclization versus rate of linear polymerization is k c rate constant for cyclization and because it is a unimolecular intramolecular reaction , so we have this .	4.6284595692192685

And rate of k , polymer , polymerization and because it is a bimolecular reaction , so we have M square , which gives us k c by k p 1 by M .	5.869761060485368

Now , as long , as long as M is less than 1 , molar cyclization will be preferred .	6.9109300429289675

If M is higher than 1 molar , then linear polymerization will be preferred that you can see from this expression .	6.076997441679575

Let us , only from the concentration of the monomer you can find out , that if it is below 1 , then rate of this , rate of cyclization will be higher and if it is above 1 , this will be a fraction .	6.670582551791666

So , the linear formation will be rate of polymerization will be higher .	5.954164814192488

So , it is always advisable , it is always advisable , that to minimize the cyclization , we always use the maximum possible concentration of the monomers and the base can , we can do if you do a bulk polymerization , that means , which we are doing the reaction with the monomers and , and the catalyst , if required .	4.704895972067881

So , so that is the maximum possible concentration you can have in , in to minimize the cyclization .	6.766725712114068

As , as a reaction progresses or the conversion goes up , now as we know , that k p is independent of , independent of conversion or the reaction , time of reaction and which comes from the fact of the assumption of equal reactivity of the functional group and we have seen in earlier lectures , that experimentally , that is also true , that rate is independent , rate independent on the conversion .	4.532612632665045

So , k p is constant throughout this process .	7.253180344083274

So , now what happens , what happen to k c , rate constant for cyclization ?	5.676302152801526

Now , as we have seen just now from the last page , that if you grow the chain , as the reaction progresses , that more and more conversion happens , the chain grows .	4.872426752944375

Now , as the chain grows , the possibility , the kinetic feasibility of the two functional groups present at the end coming and reacting to form ring , ring , comes down , which means , that k c comes down as a reaction progresses because the kinetic feasibility , that the longer the chain , that chances , that two end will come and react each other forming intra - molecular reaction , forming a ring , is always lower .	4.045194903295752

So , as the reaction progresses , as p progresses , k c comes down .	4.165254573606889

So , then the rate of cyclization also should increase in that process .	6.469986827645623

So , if the k c come down with concentration , with conversion , the cyclization should come down , whereas this is acting in opposite direction .	4.067446052526756

As the concentration of monomers comes down , the rate of cyclization will go up .	7.696801653441352

Now , it , it has been generally found fortunately , that this effect is less compared to this , which means , for general step polymers when you go for higher and higher conversion , the rate of cyclization comes down because the k c , the value of k c comes down because of kinetic feasibility .	4.913001642036554

So , that is , that is good .	6.754275219469063

So , as we , in most cases the cyclization tendency comes down as we make higher and higher molecular weight .	4.681959682146792

Now , what is the , what is the problem if I have some , few cyclic molecules in , in the polymer at the end of the polymerization ?	5.263164297320067

First of all , we have seen , that presence of this small molecular cyclics will increase the polydispersity index , which means , the distribution of the polymers chains and which effect property in , in several cases , not coming to specific examples , but it , it , it does effect the polymer property in , in several cases .	4.4867098010202655

And also , if this cyclics are present in the polymer mixture , they are sometimes very detrimental in the polymer property .	6.133573313051963

Because during the polymer processing , when you take this polymer and process mix with something compound and then take that compound at granules to make some final product by say , molding process , being low molecular weight this cyclic molecules tend to come up to the surface .	4.046406397071245

They , they preferred , they are , they prefer to be in surface .	5.906925966386205

So , during the molding process , they actually migrate to the surface and they prefer to be in the surface , which actually is very detrimental from the products properly point of view .	4.061228101373207

So , in most cases it is preferred , it is done , that at the end of the reaction some additional steps are done to strip off the cyclic molecules , small cyclic molecules from the final product , so that when you take that polymer , which is in the , at the end of the reaction , which you are taking forward for molding process , which will be , have least amount of cyclic , cyclic molecule present .	4.3749245942341

The issues that I will be talking today are ones which are still posing challenge and are restricted to laboratory investigations so far and it is likely that some of them in a very short time will come out as industrial processing concepts .	4.918965535798767

First issue that I want to draw your attention is the bio processing with co - factor linked enzymes .	4.624016187773613

As I mentioned earlier that a large number of enzymes that are known are mediated through co - enzymes or co - factors as you know and most of the applications that we talked earlier , they related to only hydrolytic enzymes which do not require co - factors with the sole exception of glucose isomerase which is an isomerase and it also does not require co - factor .	4.162967521515437

The large number of cofactor linked enzymes therefore opens a big challenge to the industry or to the scientist who are concerned with the diversification of application of enzymes .	4.156415764209266

The basic motivation or rational for the use of co - factor linked enzymes comes from the function of living cell in which a number of co - factor linked enzymes are operational in various metabolic path ways which are used by cells for carrying out their various catabolic as well as anabolic reactions .	4.243507724842971

The basic concept in a living cell , when it comes to cofactor linked enzymes , relates to cycling of the cofactor between two enzyme catalyzed reactions .	3.6910814067638245

The two enzyme catalyzed reactions are coupled in a cell in such a way that the cofactor which is used in one direction is recycled back through another reaction with which it is linked and the total equilibrium is in favor of the desired intermediate the direct part to be synthesized by the cell .	3.9522373699533797

As far as their industrial application is concerned the issue is restricted to mainly three issues : one is that the coenzyme and the enzyme must be retained in the reactor .	4.411237442283301

We have seen in our earlier deliberations where we have talked about immobilized enzymes that the enzyme can be retained in the reactor and used over a long period of time .	3.7006111482699757

A similar concept has to be developed for co - enzyme retention in the reactor .	5.869381541658739

Although it is little more difficult in the sense that while enzymes provide you a large molecular size as well as a number of functional groups on the molecule which can be used for coupling to matrix where the required enzyme is a small molecular weight compound not such a large molecule and also the number of functional groups available on the molecule are very restricted .	4.613060096966037

So exactly the same concept may not be applied , but still one needs to retain the co - enzyme so that it is not consumed during the reaction .	5.047722426783749

The basic concept to retain the enzyme as listed here is the use of the water soluble polymer bound coenzyme .	4.869253796820956

For retention of the coenzyme we use instead of a small molecular weight coenzyme , a water soluble polymer bound coenzyme .	4.460302930151929

Because of binding purposes we add another functional group which can be used for coupling to a water soluble polymer which may not be present on the original coenzyme as it is and therefore you need an analogue .	5.198333142301391

When I say analogue I am referring to some chemical and structural modifications but the role of coenzyme is retained by the molecule .	4.131996696497981

The second issue is regeneration of the coenzyme .	5.22680906184875

The regeneration of the co - enzyme like in a living cell can be carried out by coupling to enzyme catalyzed reaction , as you see here .	6.364308273334738

In a membrane reactor in which a reaction has to be carried out , I illustrate a general redox reaction , AH plus B going to A plus BH .	4.626047015859507

If this co - enzyme is NAD , this has to be coupled to a polymer so that the coenzyme is not lost during use .	6.243740883667777

Another important feature is that the product needs to be separated to drive the coupled reaction and the separation of product is mediated by use of membrane reactor in which the high molecular weight enzyme as well as the coenzyme , which is now made to be high molecular weight , is retained in the reactor and thereby the product can be separated from the reaction mixture and the reaction can be driven in the desired direction .	4.810417877999143

I will illustrate the point with one of the examples .	6.068967453554514

There is lot of chemistry involved because different people have proposed different kind of chemical reactions .	4.080055410144189

I am not interested to give you detailed chemistry .	7.3575147450597695

Just to explain the concept for example you take polyacrylamide , which is a water soluble polymer .	5.959694595440512

This is derivatised by hydrogen hydrate to polyacrylamide hydrazide and this polyacrylamide hydrazide then is coupled to a co - enzyme NAD which is derivatised in the form of carboxymethyl NAD .	3.7306462580568853

So therefore a carboxymethyl group is generated here and carboxymethyl NAD is then activated by carbodiimide , the reaction which you are familiar , with the carboxylic group containing enzymes by activation by carbodiimide and therefore you get an activated co - enzyme molecule .	3.841725041362545

A carboxymethyl which is NAD analogue is activated using carbodiimide under acidic conditions to give you an activated NAD .	4.127306767208145

This activated NAD is coupled with the polyacrlyamide hydrazide and this on coupling gives you a water soluble large molecular weight coenzyme analogue which is functionally compatible with the dehydrogenase which you want to use and similar systems can be designed for use .	4.114393778018785
