Today we will discuss two of those cases that do not represent the reaction velocity profile in terms of hyperbolic kinetics .	6.317419324258119

One of them is substrate inhibition the other is sigmoidal kinetics particularly as it applies to multisite and allosteric enzymes .	4.017934150447604

If you look into the reaction profile , a typical substrate verses initial reaction velocity profile , for a hyperbolic kinetics goes like this with an asymptotic reaction velocity Vm .	4.071008429304335

In the case of substrate inhibition the reaction velocity when you increase substrate concentration does not reach to a saturation level rather even earlier than that it deviates and passes through a maximum .	3.382032684507139

When substrate concentration goes high the reaction velocity starts dropping and does not retain saturation level .	5.150921803273547

On the other hand in the sigmoidal kinetics instead of a reaction profile being represented by rectangular hyperbola it is in the form of a sigma .	3.702693557752618

Ultimately it can reach the same kind of saturation behavior but the initial profile will be different in the case of a sigmoidal profile .	4.830126659248406

Coming to the first case of substrate inhibition , the reaction profile passes through a maximum and at a particular substrate concentration it reaches a maximum value and then it starts dropping .	5.0781498182168034

This substrate concentration corresponds to maximum reaction velocity .	5.1382411362061156

This substrate concentration corresponding to maximum reaction velocity is not really something which is corresponding to maximum reaction velocity of enzyme catalyzed reaction .	4.280080568508737

It is as a result of certain enzyme substrate interactions such that the rate gets tapered even before the saturation level reaches .	4.662042114206506

This effect can also be visualized when you look for the classical Lineweaver plot .	6.195291504290055

Instead of giving you a straight line it becomes convexed to the x axis and it can meet .	5.0183122659281825

That can give an indication that the enzyme catalyzed reaction is having some kind of a substrate .	5.655754650494186

There are number of examples in practice for such kind of a behavior in the reaction .	5.482295162577564

One of the most conventional and simplest examples could be hydrolysis of sucrose to glucose and fructose by invertase .	3.44690304193921

A very classical example , where at a substrate concentration of greater than 0.1M , 0.1M is not a very high substrate concentration , is about say 3.4 or 3.5 % .	5.469962969009965

Even at that level the effect of substrate concentration inhibition is noticed and the reaction velocity starts dropping .	5.573533520233827

Another example of substrate inhibition is in the form of succinic dehydrogenase which catalyzes the interconversion of succinate to fumerate , a reaction which catalyzes the formation of a double bond .	4.2091777946856705

Succinate as a substrate has two carboxylic groups .	9.776995164837325

As per the normal function of the enzyme the two carboxylic groups of the substrate are required to be bound to the enzyme molecule .	5.586582120679076

When substrate concentration becomes very high , the possibility or the statistical feasibility of one carboxylic group from each of the two substrate molecule binding to the same enzyme molecule becomes much higher .	5.180330289630456

In that process when the two substrate molecules gets bound to one enzyme molecule and one carboxylic group of each of the substrate molecule then the reaction is not catalyzed and then ultimate enzyme substrate complex is a dead end complex .	4.514901653057388

The structure of succinic acid is - OOC - CH2 - CH2 - COO - .	5.099221196664007

As per the normal reaction of succinic dehydrogenase two carboxylic group of substrate molecule are required to be bound to the enzyme active sites and at low concentration of substrate this can very well happen .	4.507613238982326

So therefore the active sites are not functional yet because instead of one molecule there are two molecules attached and the enzyme substrate complex so results in the form of dead end complex which doesn ’ t go into the final product forming stage .	4.924713172053266

For such a reaction there is a feasibility that you may end up in an enzyme molecule having such kind of a confirmation , instead of having the two carboxylic group of the same substrate molecule bound to the enzyme , there are two substrate molecules bound to the same enzyme and one carboxylic group of each of the substrate molecule and such a complex does not form the product .	5.006601338962762

Similarly in the case of hydrolysis of sucrose by invertase also by one of the possible mechanistic models when one substrate molecule binds , the enzyme substrate complex leads to a product formation .	5.01504224480552

If the enzyme is bound to two substrate molecule a dead end complex is formed .	5.000716841837389

A simple reaction mechanism can be expressed like E + S ES E + P + S ESS We can write exactly in our nomenclature of k1 , k - 1 , k2 and this equilibrium of the second substrate binding can be expressed by dissociation constant of Ks , individual rate constant being ks and k - s .	4.424315146946366

This ESS is a dead end complex .	6.2046620779048345

That means the product formation will take place from the substrate complex .	5.542895705566814

This will not lead to any product formation and whatever fraction of the total enzyme is bound in the form of ESS will not participate in the reaction with the result that reaction velocity will drop .	5.120895186927901

That means at the saturation level you are assuming that the entire enzyme is bound to the substrate .	4.433289745422387

The entire enzyme is not bound to the substrate here .	8.579265232606804

Increasing the substrate concentration leads to more of ESS formation .	7.72178628213684

On the basis of equilibrium kinetics one can write the rate expression of such a system as Vi / Vm = S Km + S ( 1 + S / Ks ) The Vm is the true maximum reaction velocity if there was no such substrate inhibition to take place and Km is , the classical ( k - 1 + k2 / k1 ) , the Michaelis Menten constant and ks is the dissociation constant of the second substrate binding .	4.4798153568326295

This can also be written as Vi = Vm S / Km + S + S2 / Ks If you plot such profile the rate expression will pass through maxima and if you differentiate that dv over ds and equate it to zero you will end up in maxima and the maximum reaction velocity will be obtained at substrate concentration which is Sm = vKm .	3.9717584736107874

In such cases you notice that such enzymes do not really strictly follow the typical Michaelis Menten kinetics .	3.801038802221547

There are another group of enzymes which are multisite .	7.534176622535122

In the second and more complex case when we talk of co - operative binding if you consider two binding sites on enzyme molecule they may be identical .	5.4505113544748465

There are number of mechanistic hypothesis which have been proved .	6.318426386140249

The first binding site is free for all the substrate molecule and once this is bound if it makes a change on the confirmation of the other binding sites such that the affinity of the substrate to the binding site gets altered , if you want a positive favorable effect , the affinity must increase or the Km value must decrease , dissociation constant must decrease .	4.4054633580577205

If the km value of the subsequent binding sites decreases with the binding of the first substrate molecule we call it co - operative binding .	6.050878372293447

The significance of co - operative binding lies in actual practice in the case of allosteric enzymes .	4.49275075485869

All of you know probably with your background in the biochemical metabolism that with each metabolic path way you have certain regulatory enzymes which behave in allosteric manner .	3.783019775663035

By allosteric manner I mean that substrate binding process in case of those enzymes is co - operative in nature and they do not exhibit the typical hyperbolic kinetics rather they exhibit sigmoidal kinetics .	4.674692499871292

If you just compare the two kinds of profiles , this is a sigmoidal profile and this is the hyperbolic profile .	6.390881987833588

For two different enzymes which are coincidentally having the same velocity at substrate concentration let us say nine arbitrary units in both the cases whether it follows a hyperbolic kinetics or sigmoidal kinetics the enzyme velocity reaches the same value at a particular substrate concentration .	4.157291503960721

Only initial phase changes and the first one is typical hyperbolic profile , the second one is the sigmoidal profile which is exhibited by allosteric enzymes .	4.607749068723455

The allosteric behavior has in some way an advantageous situation for the regulatory enzymes to function .	4.572897926974751

The role of regulatory enzymes in a metabolic pathway is the control of metabolic pathway .	4.082503154891217

That means it should be able to switch on and off the path way with a very subtle change in substrate concentration .	4.827318454177614

These two profiles have identical reaction velocity at high substrate concentration .	4.831255340178844

For the two enzymes to act , in the early phases when substrate concentration increases from zero to three arbitrary units whatever are the units , in the case of sigmoidal kinetics the reaction velocity is only 0.1 in some arbitrary units .	4.320747822843974

Whereas in the case of a saturation kinetics or hyperbolic kinetics the reaction velocity can reach to almost 0.75 , 75 % of the saturation value , a very high level .	4.416020653503896

That means at a very small change of concentration , the reaction velocity can be very high .	5.408391076499736

In the case of saturation kinetics or hyperbolic kinetics the ratio of the concentration of substrates for the two levels to reach will be almost about twenty seven times .	4.5071204520942825

That means at 0.1 , it can reach only at a very small substrate concentration here .	5.894287605758766

The ratio is twenty seven fold .	7.530480522627523

On the other hand in the case of sigmoidal kinetics this ratio is only 2.3 .	3.8493675746813825

In the case of living cells the intercellular concentration of substrate does not change over a very large range .	5.6206016826128335

Whereas for control purposes it will require a very small concentration change by which the reaction velocity can be regulated and that is what can happen in the case of a sigmoidal kinetics .	5.116391593200619

That means just by changing concentration ratio of two to three fold you will notice that the reaction velocity can be altered from 0.1 to 0.75 and that is the advantage with this kind of reaction behavior the regulatory enzymes obtained in the case of cellular metabolism With this kind of a kinetic behavior the enzymes are able to act almost like an on and off switch .	4.456062710534198

That means if the substrate concentration comes down reaction velocity is very slow ; the metabolic pathway is slowed down ; it is not made to zero .	5.3813259765011585

If the substrate concentration slightly increases the pathway is fully on and the product formation or whatever is corresponding intermediate in pathway are fully available and that advantage provides to the cellular metabolism .	3.976512972922474

Such a behavior of sigmoidal kinetics has been very appropriately explained at least by two mechanistic hypotheses .	4.361073828609244

One and probably in its simplest form is on the basis of sequential interaction model .	5.306504785479048

This is an extension of Koshland ’ s induced fit hypothesis which we discussed when we were talking about the specificity and how the enzymes obtain their specific action .	3.9540860340656385

We talked about the Koshland ’ s induced fit hypothesis whereby when the substrate molecule binds to one of the binding sites the enzyme undergo a conformational change so as to fit on to the substrate molecule .	4.595390895365917

For each binding of the substrate to a binding site the affinity reduces by a factor let us say a , as interaction factor .	5.516013184437434

That is what you see in a diagrammatic picture like here .	5.251281223003214

The conformational change leads to the dissociation constant or Michaelis Menten constant for the second binding site and then second binding site also gets bound .	5.38657705638046

It is logical that if this dissociation constant is low the substrate will have much more affinity for the second binding site .	4.935794534093155

Similarly if it initially binds with Ks on to other binding site it can influence the conformational change on the other binding site and it can meet .	4.733671618536188

The second binding process is represented by dissociation constant of a Ks either here or here .	4.305552481019359

The product formation with ES will be E + P .	7.372767722044224

Similarly when both the binding sites are occupied , the product formation rate will be twice the Kp because then it can go either to SE or ES , there is no difference .	4.773334367789037

The situation which I have shown here is rather too simplistic .	5.859360100428684

To simplify the situation there is an equation available corresponding to Michaelis Menten equation which can be applied to allosteric enzymes .	5.075590301306037

This was given by Hill .	10.006174273925469

One of the basic assumptions here which we made is that the interaction factors , what I mentioned earlier as Ks and a Ks , the ratio alpha is very , very small than one .	4.849734331046084

That means the co - operativity is very high .	5.260300479885645

Once a substrate molecule binds to one of the binding sites it makes a drastic conformational change so that the affinity is increased very significantly .	5.471243664990837

If you consider n binding sites what will happen in such a situation is that with each binding site being occupied by the substrate , the next subsequent binding sites will have much more affinity .	4.654514208765381

Ultimately at equilibrium or in steady state condition the net effect will be that the bulk of the enzyme will be in the form of ESS .	5.0171662161324075

Theoretically at equilibrium the enzyme must be available in the form of E , ES , ES2 , …… , ESn .	5.361126350055586

Normally if there are n binding sites and the binding process continues sequentially then the enzyme must be available in different species in difference forms as E , ES , ES2 , up to ESn .	4.445599508545921

But if the interaction factor alpha is very , very small , at each stage affinity will increase by a very significant level or what we understand as co - operativity is very high .	4.178493968589344

In that case the assumption by Hill was that most of the enzyme will exist in the form of ESn .	4.803135371335148

There will be small concentrations but they can be neglected .	8.085905296049615

Based on that assumption then he gave a rate expression which is v / Vm = Sn / K ’ + Sn This is called Hills equation .	3.661028519113972

Here n is the number of binding sites per enzyme molecule and K ’ is the Hill ’ s constant .	5.062111492761523

This K ’ is different than the Michaelis Menten constant .	6.553765536600641

Michaelis Menten constant is the substrate concentration at which reaction velocity is 50 % of that of the maximum reaction velocity .	7.221409535922821

That situation will not apply here , if you analyze .	8.21535114225687

If you put n = 1 , then the equation will get into Michaelis Menten kinetics .	4.425768015842005

Vm here is the maximum reaction velocity when all the binding sites are occupied by the substrate .	5.683450568577518

The substrate concentration is high enough but again this is not identical to the Vm of the Michaelis Menten equation because Vm of the Michaelis Menten equation is an asymptotic value .	4.671885353925748

You can never approach it practically .	7.662671072298009

It is a theoretical value .	7.797101076827288

Whereas in this case of Vm , you can approach to that value when all the enzyme binding sites are totally occupied by the substrate molecule .	5.313377959387718

GPC is also called SEC size exclusion chromatography , because we will know now itself that the principle behind the separation of this polymer molecules is based on the exclusion of size .	5.4457639252298655

Now , this is apparatus of GPC gel permeation chromatography of solvent reservoir which pump the solvent through the columns .	3.875998256357597

Now , to have a steady flow , you might have a pulse dampener which gives the flow at a steady flow rate and you can have a filter which will filter the solvent .	4.652006848504088

So , that no dust particle goes in here you inject sample basically sample goes in the column you can have one or more columns connected in a series , and the polymer sample gets separated according to their size hydrodynamic volume in this columns , and when they come out you have a detector which detect the polymer molecules , and with the help of computer you can analyze this data .	4.439844545268962

So , basically in feasible you inject the polymer samples in a column which is consist of highly cross linked gel beads ; the beads are typically having diameter of 5 microns to 10 microns and they have definite pore size which can start from say for 10 to the power 100 Armstrong or 50 Armstrong to 10 to the power 5 Armstrong .	3.6397876023586018

So , pore size might vary from very low to moderately high and they are packed with having beads of diameter of 5 micron to 10 micron .	3.972202260431866

These beads are pores with a pore size varies between say 50 Armstrong in to 10 to the power 5 Armstrong .	4.338577612060855

And the polymers gets separated in this column and then you can get detect the polymers using detectors concentration detectors like UV , IR or refractive index detector .	4.476007904856178

So , the principle is that you have pores in the column and the polymer molecules which are higher size they do not or cannot go inside this pores .	5.725507921342748

So , they come out fast and the polymers which have lower size they can go inside the pores which makes their path length which are longer compared to a higher sized polymer molecules ; and as a results they elute or come out column at a later time .	4.361412254271079

So , basically if you put a mixture of different size polymer in this case only two size is shown here ; may be big and small molecule .	4.880123372544613

So , it is not that all the pores are having same size , the pores size also have some distribution .	4.695397791794195

So , with flow when this polymer mixture goes through the columns , the larger ones move faster ; as a result at the end of the column or end of the path , the larger ones come out earlier and you get the smaller ones come out later .	4.665209249482594

So , when the polymers come out you need to have a detectors which will detect and in most of the cases , because we want to get the concentration of the polymers which are coming out ; we usually use concentration detectors in GPC and most common use is refractive index detector ; and also in some cases we also UV visible spectrometer which basically is the polymer has some groups which absorb in visible region then we can get the concentration of polymer in that solution by UV visible spectroscopy .	4.71011495879221

So , what we get ?	9.169111792885898

In our previous lecture , we had discussed some issues regarding the enzyme science particularly the sciences that are associated with the study of enzymes , the nomenclature of enzymes and key issues that relate to the importance of enzymes in the over all perspective of biotechnology .	3.7179604853826778

Today we will be discussing some of the characteristic features of enzymes particularly as proteins and their chemical nature .	4.309964827156832

All of you may be aware that all the enzymes that are known so far are proteins in chemical nature .	4.599999011892657

When I say proteins we immediately understand a chain of amino acids .	4.4306985907569

Twenty different amino acids that are linked through peptide bonds and the size of the chain may extend some where from 100 amino acids to 300 amino acids in different enzymes .	4.733927367340425

They are macromolecules of different amino acids in a sense they are hetero macromolecules , hetero polymers ; that means the monomer units are not identical in nature .	4.568885032378683

They vary among the twenty different amino acids and their sequence and the number of amino acids or the relative concentration of each of the amino acid may determine the particular type of enzymes , its characteristic properties as well as its functional aspects .	4.719160762771071

As a macromolecule , we will notice that the properties of a macromolecule will largely depend upon the constituent monomers .	5.695664613246718

In the case of amino acids , they vary in terms of their various properties particularly ionic nature , their hydrophobic nature and their size .	3.979134840652286

There is large variation and therefore the relative proportion of these amino acids also influence the properties of the consequent macromolecule what we know as proteins .	4.783606962211947

Besides a macromolecule of various combinations of amino acids , the enzymes may also be considered as a catalyst .	5.9488946747892655

Only those proteins which have catalytic function , that means they can accelerate the rate of a particular reaction , can be termed as enzymes .	5.8783080307313655

Proteins as you all may be aware have diverse functions in a living cell like structure , transport molecules , example - haemoglobin or myoglobin , defense molecules like antibodies and the fact remains that their more significant function in a living cell is catalytic .	3.5395564425111723

Enzymes therefore can be termed as active proteins which have catalytic function in a living cell .	3.955450070121321

Alternatively some of the protein molecules which are known to be enzymes but may not be intrinsically catalytically active may require the role of an associated molecule what we term as cofactor for them to be catalytically active .	4.3365881709486

That means the protein molecule itself is not catalytically functional but in the presence of the cofactor the molecule may become a catalyst and may be considered as an enzyme .	5.141778775613501

These cofactors again could range from a small molecular weight organic molecule .	6.101323703556994

This may be required to be externally added like for example NAD , ATP , FAD or a variety of cofactor that you are familiar with in many of the bio chemical reactions or they could be or they could be as simple as metal ions and the fact that because in the absence of these cofactors the protein is not catalytically active , it implies that these cofactors have a very significant role in the catalytic mechanism which these molecules display .	4.2552104888480065

Also these proteins may be very simple proteins for example a simple amino acid polymeric chain .	5.475831210829811

They could also be conjugated proteins .	8.428902570993925

By conjugated proteins we mean in addition to the amino acids the proteins chain will also be associated with some other non - amino acid molecules .	4.2957688900378015

Very commonly encountered proteins are glycoproteins , many of the enzymes , particularly those which are isolated from eukaryotes , a glycoproteins which means that in addition to the amino acids the protein molecule is associated with an oligosaccharide , monosaccharide or an oligosaccharide , they could lipo proteins a lipid molecule , they could be nucleoproteins and a large number of proteins which are metalloproteins containing metal enzymes where the metal ions acts as a cofactor are known .	3.5796276248369234

Another characteristic feature of these proteins as a constituent or as a chemical body of the enzyme is that in many cases there may be single chain of amino acids , a single chain protein and many of the industrial enzymes particularly hydrolytic enzymes are single chains which means that the backbone of the protein consists of only one polymeric chain and in many cases they could be even multimeric proteins that means more than one chain constitute the whole enzyme molecule .	4.654771278188048

A single chain is not functionally active .	8.735772662141327

The arrangement or the organization of the multiple chains could be two chains ; there could be three chains or four chains .	4.487368025835604

The organization of those chains provides certain natures which are responsible for the catalytic function and these multimeric chains or the multimeric proteins as some of you are familiar have a distinct role in regulatory aspect of the cellular metabolism .	3.471144135899663

As I was talking about the synthesis of the macromolecule the basic backbone of the protein chain in the case of a protein lies in the condensation of two different amino acids .	4.970196767516443

Here R1 and R2 indicate the distinction between two amino acids and the carboxylic group of one and amino group of other amino acid condense and form a - CONH bond which is known as peptide bond .	4.911932673861603

These peptide bonds have a resonance structure .	7.621985231795448

It has a very peculiar property which is really carried forward in the function and structure of the enzyme molecules .	5.323706091010551

This is the resonance structure and also the peptide units are rigid and planar in nature and the most important property which contributes to its secondary structure is the capability of free rotation about the alpha carbon and nitrogen and alpha carbon and carbon .	4.0147426313911705

At these two sites they can freely rotate .	7.439374607696663

The bond can freely rotate and thereby can give rise to hydrogen bonding between the different amino acid residues in the chain and constitute the subsequent structural organization of the macromolecule .	4.392505534461367

When we look at quantification of an enzyme molecule or enzyme sample or what we know as assay methods they also take into account these two major characteristics .	4.358561087055465

The quantification methods could be classified into two categories mainly or the two constituents could form the basis of assay methods .	4.471616612472487

One is based on the protein concentration that means an enzyme sample can be quantified on the basis of a protein sample .	5.769191814266703

That means what is the concentration of protein in a given sample and in terms of say milligram per liter .	5.876226826579957

One could determine by any method that is known to us and I will talk about it a little later .	5.430451062649224

The other way could be and which is probably more important for assay of an enzyme is its catalytic function .	4.827470212483617

That means you assay it or you determine its capability to carry out a biochemical reaction and represent its concentration in the form of initial reaction rate .	4.391265222331171

Any catalyst or any chemical reaction if you look at the reaction profile it can be indicated as between time and product formed and ultimately the rate of the reaction at duration dp / dt at the zero time will give you the initial reaction rate .	4.986274660530257

This initial reaction rate is considered one of the parameters for determining the concentration of any enzyme sample .	8.726247606165305

As a convention the quantity of enzyme which converts one micro mole of substrate into product per minute is termed as the rate .	4.31366812990122

Quantity of enzyme which can exhibit this kind of a rate , initial rate is termed as one international unit .	5.739138000892144

That is the conventional , internationally accepted unit of an enzyme activity .	6.164353881027201

One international unit of enzyme is the quantity of that enzyme or the concentration of that enzyme which can convert one micro mole of substrate into product in unit time per minute .	5.422632679784667

One macro mole of product formed per minute of the reaction can be considered as one international unit .	6.15095465963301

One of the limitations is that this is not a SI unit which is an internationally accepted system of units .	5.665604685734459

In the case of enzyme activity the SI unit is katal .	5.127925625701367

If we look into basic units of the international SI system , a katal in terms of rate terms will be the quantity of enzyme that produce one mole of product per second .	4.215739159928333

One mole of product per second is a very large unit .	7.398231789351104

If you make a comparison between the international unit and katal , katal is a very large unit and one katal could correspond to 106 x 60 international units because convert moles into macro moles and minutes into seconds .	3.4051641381574025

A unit of katal is much larger and one can interconvert .	7.617769254706074

The initial reaction rate is the basic philosophy in determining the enzyme concentration .	6.7129614426381385

On the other hand the protein concentration also gives us an idea of the amount of an enzyme present in a given sample .	5.123133607575551

Although it may not always be true if the protein is not in its functional form , it will loose its status of the enzyme .	4.506488925500301

It may remain as the protein .	8.172972652744791

But the importance of the protein concentration lies in the fact that it gives you an idea about the purity of the sample .	5.104169792471066

In case of mixture of proteins you can identify what proportion of the total protein is the enzyme molecule or what proportion of the total protein is the catalytically functional enzyme molecule and therefore protein concentration determination is important .	3.7072512748362447

Whenever we analyze any given enzyme sample , we usually resort to both the basis : its initial reaction rate as well as protein concentration .	4.745687639718893

A large number of methods are used to determine protein concentration , as you may be familiar with , and all of them are linked or based on the native structure of protein , the constituent amino acids of a protein .	4.185887694622811

The most simple system probably you are familiar is by ultra violent absorption .	5.008847972455798

We determine the absorbance at 280 which gives you very precise information about the concentration of protein in the sample and this absorbance is based on the content of amino acid residues tyrosine and tryptophan in the protein which are more or less universally present in most of the enzyme samples .	4.970274289554952

One of the major limitations of this method is that it will have the interference or some kind of error involved if the impurities contain molecules that also absorb near this wave length .	3.942242361490801

Major contaminant in biological samples are nucleic acids which also have absorbance at about 260 nm and therefore sometime how to make an account of protein concentration taking in view the absorbance as a result of nucleic acid and very often the ?	3.98197679436252

280 - ?	101.60939562511696

260 with some appropriate factors are used to determine the absolute protein concentration in a given sample .	5.331188892609204

Another method which is very popular is Loury ’ s method which is based on the production of a blue purple color which absorbs maximum at 660nm with a sodium tungstate molybdenum phosphate reagent what we call as fallacy of call to the reagent which is usually a standard which is available and reagent is very accurate in the sense that you can monitor the protein concentration as low as ten milligram per litre .	3.684603249471751

A very accurate method which also has many other merits is in terms of lack of interference .	5.491498885077475

Another method is biuret method which is based on the reduction with alkaline Copper sulphate solution which contains sodium potassium tartrate and the cupric ions form a co - ordination complex with the amino groups or the - NH group present in the peptide bond .	3.3294820858948593

The basic advantage here is that the method is based on the peptide bond which is very unique as far as the proteins are concerned .	5.625342862797348

The other polymers or other molecules present as contaminant will not contribute to error in the case of a biuret method .	4.859382202802653

Biuret method is based on the development of a blue color with an alkaline copper sulphate solution containing sodium potassium tartrate .	4.430497631150893

This cupric ions after reduction forms a co - ordination complex with the –NH group present in the peptide bond .	3.864713120871078

The specificity of this method is based on co - ordination complex formation with the peptide bond which is a unique property or a basic property in all proteins .	4.7023975377216205

Unlike in the case of other methods which are based on tyrosine or tryptophan as residues , the relative concentration of these amino acids in the protein will give you a different reading .	4.850826594309363

But biuret reagent will give you a very uniform method in case of all proteins .	7.355356208437674

You have other methods which are based on dye binding or silver binding method where the protein can bind certain molecules and the binding is assayed quantitatively and expressed in terms of protein content .	4.272910432871677

But all these methods have a unique linkage or they have been standardized right from beginning in a more basic fundamental method what we know as Kjeldhal method .	4.339457239902523

The basis of Kjeldhal method is primarily estimation of nitrogen content .	4.862994000856125

Just like peptide bond , the nitrogen content is also intrinsic component of any protein .	4.257290016829636

You digest the protein sample with concentrated sulphuric acid in the presence of a catalyst .	4.803908455745584

Ammonia is produced and the ammonia then is absorbed into dilute acid solution which is titrated and the quantity of amino generated can be calculated .	4.5343412166156165

There are minor modification in terms of automation and macronization of these methods which are available today commercially but the basis is to determine the nitrogen content in any given sample which gives you an estimate of crude protein in the sample .	4.135063338904699

It is assumed that any given protein contains approximately 16 % of nitrogen .	5.467741009443291

So if you multiply nitrogen content by 6.8 you get the net protein .	6.058803603306239

But it will be called crude protein in the sense that it will also measure all those molecules which contains nitrogen in addition to proteins .	4.865805562166689

But still it is one of the earliest methods that we had known and had been used .	5.367297996961383

So a very important aspect is assay which you should be very clear .	6.523518039878279

Another point which I like to highlight here before I proceed further is about the SI .	4.803708853834573

The best way to ensure such clarity is that instead of taking one sample we take at least two or three dilutions of the same sample which are let us say two fold , four fold , six fold , known dilutions and the final reaction rate which has been obtained must be proportional to the dilution .	4.331313305254174

Unless you get two different samples in the same linear range you cannot depend on the result because if you take a higher concentration of the enzyme you may be able to measure this reaction rate which is much lower than you would have got in a diluted sample .	5.45348409513704

One of the conventional ways is that we try to ensure that the reaction rate measured in the low dilution region or low concentration region can be easily measured by taking more than two samples of known dilution.The next important property of proteins is their ionic behavior .	4.120069895160001

This ionic behavior results from the monomer units that are present in the amino acid which are present in the macro molecule and when we consider a long protein chain bulk of the amino groups and the carboxylic groups in the amino chain will be involved in the formation of peptide bond .	5.5032454393451635

It will be only the residual amino acids and the two ends one will have a carboxylic group and other will have an amino group free and both these groups will be free to ionize at any given pH .	4.355626546476537

Having both positive and negative group at the end will ensure that at any given pH the molecule will have some charge .	5.203102597537222

If you look at a very general system where I am assuming that all the R ’ s that are mentioned here are non - ionisable .	4.48712208508837

So we have only two groups with net positive charge .	5.51812496877241

At a low pH the molecule will act like a cation and as we increase the pH it will be negatively charged and it will behave like anion and some where in between there will be a zero net charge that means it will have both positive and negative charge of equal magnitude , what we call as zwitterion in the case of amino acids .	4.534523894891682

That will entirely depend on the pka value of the two charges .	5.378581181027071

It will not be at pH 7 .	9.824200780505029

It will depend upon the pka value of the two .	6.99514269755815

That means the negative logarithm of the dissociation constant of the two charges .	4.726740573873683

The situation is a simplified situation where we are assuming that only two terminal amino acids are ionized .	5.518505798970019

It will always happen that it will have residues like for an example these R ’ s which are also ionisable and the system might become a little more complex .	4.774034203509019

For example consider a protein chain in which you have amino acid like aspartic acid .	4.695951262497512

It has two carboxylic groups instead of only an amino group .	4.689080629636124

It has an additional carboxylic group .	6.910795994252798

At low pH , again similarly here it will have only one net positive charge , amino group will be ionized .	5.248004571928338

As we move further , increase the pH it will have one carboxylic and one amino group ionized .	5.275101377536327

When the pH is increased to a level where both the negative ions are ionized and the amino group is not ionized and ultimately you will also meet here a situation where you have zwitterions where one amino group and one carboxylic group are ionized , the other carboxylic group is non - ionized and that is a status .	4.321872541987302

This carboxylic group may be different than your amino group or the carboxylic group known .	6.086876026565222

A similar situation will be in the case of lysine for example when you have more than one basic amino group .	6.4285868692022

Some of the ionisable groups found in proteins are not only aspartic acid and lysine or glutamic acid that contribute to the ionization state of a protein .	4.005394897354171

There are other amino acids particularly like histidine or cystine or tyrosine .	4.3241375478047575

They also play a role in ionization and they also have ionization behavior and their approximate pKa values are indicated here .	4.052803642074631

The net charge in the protein will depend on ionization state at a given pH of all the contributing proteins in the system .	5.637597666300022

That is a very important property which we must keep in mind when we look at enzymes for a variety of functions .	4.956321726579311

Whether it is a catalytic function , whether it is a purification of enzyme protein the ionic behavior plays a very key role .	5.15686980706615

That will depend entirely on pH .	7.492684831437046

For example you look at let us see the approximate pKa values .	6.174027525027022

For the C - terminal alpha carboxylic group the pKa is three and for the aspartic acid beta carboxylic group , the pKa is 3.9 .	3.7139950900462515

It is because it is linked to another carbonate which is not in the basic chain .	7.1215367797259574

The pKa is different and ionization will totally depend on the pKa value of the functional group .	5.8720176916185824

Usually yes but it cannot be cited as a rule .	6.237137750241659

The nature of amino acid has a very important role to play in the conformation .	5.23523246590436

In the case of proteins the beauty lies in that it is a very highly folded molecule .	4.944580671578126

That means its volume is very much conserved .	7.5323981975966

The molecule is very compact .	9.421509889066519

It is not extended like a rod .	5.54698787436914

Not that there are no proteins which are not in the extended form .	7.147190536741471

Many of the structural proteins will be in the extended form but most of the proteins which constitute enzymes are globular proteins and they form almost a spherical shape under ideal condition .	4.408404562479085

But usually they will be in the ellipsoid kind of the situation where you can determine the conformation by their minor and major axis .	6.131296239613134

In fact there are relationships available where many of the hydrodynamic and transport properties of these polymers solutions can be related to the major and minor axis of the ellipsoid particle and these are broadly the methods which are used in general to determine the dimensions of the protein molecule or the nature of conformation , if suppose we know about the native conformation , we know the dimensions and after certain treatment if the dimensions are altered we tend to understand that they have under gone a conformational change .	4.075366388333382

These conformations are the result of the nature of the amino acids , the side chains of the amino acids , the principle functional group .	4.9574979099065635

The principle interactions that are present in the case of any given protein or that applies to an enzyme are peptide bonds .	5.712658250194473

They form the backbone of the total protein chain but the conformation is a result of a number of non covalent interactions .	5.306379217406011

Individually they may not be very strong in terms of bond energy but collectively in terms of number of bonds present they provide a very stable structure to a molecule .	5.981892827507181

The hydrogen bonds are attractive forces between a hydrogen atom attached to an electro negative atom .	4.2736453907965535

That means the electro negative oxygen atom of the carbonyl group is attached to the hydrogen of - NH group .	3.8934199693251212

This kind of a bond particularly between different peptide bonds can create a hydrogen bond and a large number of these bonds are present in any given molecule .	4.95134279148667

The next important interaction , non - covalent interaction is electrostatic force .	4.675266737121495

I mentioned that the molecule will consist of a number of ionisable amino acid residues and these ionisable amino acid residues might have molecules at a distance having positive and negative charges and when they interact they might exhibit the an electro static interactions and provide stability to the molecule .	4.331901585344931

Hydrophobic forces are very often considered to be a major force which is involved in the globular structure .	6.216302171995818

That means when you consider the wet side , on the surface there will be most of the charged groups and most of the non polar side chains will be located inside the three dimensional molecules .	5.521439813440958

It doesn ’ t mean that on the surface there are no hydro phobic patches .	5.477749191268901

Most enzymes will have certain hydrophobic patches on the surface which are required for many functional purposes because many of the interfacial actions will involve the hydrophobic patches on the surface and have an important role on the functional aspect .	4.445065884780291

Another covalent bond , disulphide bonds which have an importance in the case of stability of these conformation are the oxidation of cystein residues .	4.912199580574262

Two cystein residues oxidize to give S - S bond and that can come at different points in the chain .	5.1334172365538615

After the folding is over , two cystein residues can join together to form a sulphydryl and thereby provide a stability to the conformation .	3.989676461262294

The conformation resulting from the forces of these interactions that take place are usually classified into four categories .	4.096164793620094

The simplest and the primary structure is the sequence and the content of different amino acids present in an enzyme sample .	5.209855781939437

Both the content and the sequence will vary from enzyme to enzyme .	4.509186771964689

Then this chain can fold itself locally in the shape of either an alpha helix or a pleated sheet so as to give a secondary structure .	4.348025694296929

If you look at secondary structure in the form of a right handed alpha helix , the helix moves upwards and basically their structure results from the formation of hydrogen bonding between the peptide bonds .	3.7099998917511146

A hydrogen bond is formed between the - NH group and the - C0 group in the chain at a distance by four amino acid residues .	6.088550226231519

That means the folding of the polypeptide chain into an alpha helix results with hydrogen bonding between the –NH and - CO residues located at the distance and this interaction results in a very smooth and regular dimensions of the chain in the case of alpha helix .	3.944746818596676

That mean the distances between these two turns is about 0.54 nm per turn 3.6 amino acid residues going to 0.5 and these dimensions have been extended over a large number of proteins and are found to be uniform .	4.076299540397774

When the protein molecule gets folded into a secondary structure of alpha helix , the side chains of the amino acids are projected outwards like a rotatory form .	3.9345405673805502

The side chains are also free to interact with each other and provide you electrostatic interactions and other features .	5.308908422130743

This alpha helix and other type of conformation which many proteins will have will be again as the result of hydrogen bonding will be in the form of beta pleated sheet .	4.43028587985344

They can be parallel or anti parallel .	5.081372424423406

The hydrogen bonding between two sections of the polypeptide chain can form beta pleated sheet and because the poly peptide chain has polarity , either parallel or anti parallel , beta sheet can be formed and you come across in any given protein sample the alpha helix as well as beta pleated sheet structures very commonly .	3.831840148052009

After these secondary structures are formed again the molecule as the result of Vander waal forces and electrostatic interactions force into a compact globular molecule .	3.8220713454754986

In the top figure different shapes indicate different amino acids and the linear chain of that is termed as primary structure .	4.726066549269239

The folding of these polypeptide chains into alpha helix or the alternative could be the beta pleated sheets , the secondary structure .	4.150385791055269

This structure again folds itself into a globular form as a result of disulphide bridges .	5.327791163099618

In electro static interactions also hydrogen bonding and Vander Waal interactions forces into a globular mass and the basis of that ultimately leads to minimum energy level because at the minimum energy level it will be stable .	4.1897986232547115

Any deviation from the minimum energy level will lead to its denaturation or inactivation of the catalytic function of the enzyme sample .	5.459364409178127

When I use the term denaturation , the term denaturation does not in any sway consider the break down of the covalent bonds .	4.285502333613966

That is the basic backbone of the peptide bond .	5.527113317453487

The disruption of the non covalent interaction is good enough to lead to denaturation .	5.273743485899932

In a destructive way you can also break the peptide bond but then you will be destroying the protein itself .	6.168349074790155

But the destruction of or disruption of non - covalent bonds , non - covalent interactions will retain the protein molecule but we lose only the catalytic activity , catalytic function and that is what is the usual meaning of denaturation .	4.566669298875866

The globular form of the folded protein is termed tertiary structure .	6.657204003147368

Many proteins may be oligomeric proteins that means they may consist of more than one chain and the arrangement of these chains into a particular fashion so that they are able to bring about certain catalytically active sites is called quaternary structure .	4.163509380763967

The quaternary structure is only applicable if the enzyme protein consists of more than one chain .	5.922992593799177

In case of a single chain enzyme the quaternary structure question doesn ’ t arise but possible in the case of a multimeric enzyme or what we call as oligomeric enzyme .	4.2552637438392855

The quaternary structure could be a dimmer , it could be trimer , it could be a tetramer depending on the number of chains present and the organization will really lead to the final conformation .	5.074403562094972

I was talking about the formation of sulphydryl bridge .	7.042595678369637

The two cysteine molecules can undergo oxidation to give you cystine molecule which acts as bridges and these bridges is very strong contributor to the stability of the protein molecule in its tertiary structure .	3.9431649848878587

Whenever we look into any method particularly the protein engineering methods we tend to increase the number of sulphydryl bridges .	5.855901769145625

Because ultimately if we can have more sulphydryl bridges , it is likely to result into higher stability or in other words most of the enzyme samples which are obtained from thermophiles that means the organisms that can survive in the extreme temperatures will contain higher content of sulphydryl bridges and they are probably the features that results into the higher stability .	4.288559802402192

The other issue a very general issue about the feature of enzymes and proteins is the bio synthesis and regulation .	4.416695284245039

The biosynthesis of enzymes in any living system is exactly the same as biosynthesis of any protein .	5.23707738682318

The central dogma of molecular biology covers the biosynthesis of enzymes and proteins .	5.095241333922056

The enzyme in many cases , particularly the oligomeric enzymes have to undergo some modification .	5.747233111330228

There are certain organizational changes that lead to enzymatic protein or enzymatic constituent but otherwise the synthesis of the protein that leads to enzyme synthesis is identical .	3.6307093409293856

The whole set of information about the synthesis of a protein is coded in the DNA molecule .	4.7977746391424745

That means the sequence of nucleotides in a DNA determines the amino acid composition of a protein and that particular portion of DNA gets replicated , transcripted to mRNA and other forms of RNA and then translation of ribosomes to protein .	3.458030458213642

These are the steps for protein synthesis and in case of enzyme synthesis also the same principle applies .	5.5942193814509436

Most of the hydrolytic enzymes are regulated by the mechanisms commonly known as induction or repression or catabolic repression .	3.613370387826758

That means the structural gene of the particular protein is bound to a repressor molecule and unless an inducer is added it cannot be relieved .	4.205193397960114

Most of the inducers for many enzymes very often are the substrate molecules themselves .	4.462088698122673

There are a lot of structural similarities with xylose and glucose .	4.871734409321646

Xylose is the inducer .	16.344665036517434

In the case of cellulase for example the cellulose act as an inducer and for many of the hydrolytic enzymes which are regulated by induction the substrate itself act as an inducer .	4.208991541293905

Then they also undergo catabolic repression that means the availability of an easily assimilable carbon source and the most easily assimilable is glucose represses the synthesis of the enzyme .	4.35352659681368

Various other mechanism of ……… and all that will also a play a role in the regulation of the enzyme synthesis .	6.092183623591856

Another important feature of a regulation here besides biosynthesis , is regulation of the enzyme activity itself .	4.778510078808307

Most of the enzymes are known to have a mechanism by which even their activity can be regulated not only at the biosynthesis level but at the functional level .	4.477556771320909

That means there are inhibitors and activator molecule which we normally know as effector molecules which can influence the initial reaction rate of the enzyme in the …… .	4.64118649186622

If you add along with the enzyme sample a known inhibitor molecule the reaction rate which is obtained will be much lower .	6.829280905063064

Similarly an activator molecule will increase the reaction rate and that is a very common feature of the regulation of enzyme activity and which is of significance even for commercial applications .	6.037127406831591

Another property of the enzymes in terms of proteins is their solubility .	10.002485897747567

All the globular proteins are known to be soluble in aqueous medium and so are the enzymes .	5.140683041067417

Usually the solubility can be influenced by salt concentration that means ionic strength , the pH , the organic content in the solvent that means addition of a polymer , an organic polymer can affect the solubility and temperature is a universal parameter which influences solubility .	4.409659076840757

But you will notice that at least the first three parameters are very commonly used parameters for even isolation of an enzyme sample from a crude protein sample .	4.760916489675416

Finally to conclude I would like to say that today we have discussed the characteristic features of enzymes that are attributed by proteins nature , as a macromolecule in terms of assay method , their ionic behavior , their conformation , solubility and the role these properties play in the various techniques that are used for isolation , purification or application of these enzymes .	4.050006924880594

Quaternary structure has relevance in the case of oligomeric proteins that means the proteins that consist of more than one polypeptide chain .	5.814790923103826

The arrangement of these polypeptide chains into a particular formation can result in certain interaction which can form catalytic sites .	3.7409138977017005

The arrangement of different polypeptide chains in an oligomeric protein is termed as quaternary .	4.535405907171343

In fact each chain will have its known tertiary structure and then these globular structures will assemble in a format .	3.9385885900312587

Example is lactate dehydrogenase which is a tetramer consisting of four polypeptide chains .	5.614699995352773

Slight shift in these individual units can totally change the functional behavior of the enzyme .	5.378573703918368

This has led to one of the diagnostic method particularly for the patients who are suffering from cardiac problems the lactate dehydrogenase from the heart muscles undergo the quaternary structural change .	3.32201016750844

And the change in quaternary structure is related to the disease behavior .	6.066575087285039

That is one of the diagnostic tools .	6.262438066544924

So in fact even the conformational aspects are important for the applications .	5.452672871812653
